Clinton talks about her time of'reflection' during sick days

Hillary Clinton returned to the campaign trail Thursday afternoon, debuting some new intro music and telling the crowd that her sick days allowed
reference_text:
her a chance to "reconnect with what this whole campaign is about."

The former secretary of state, who took the stage to James Brown's "I Feel Good," spent the beginning of the week at her home in Chappaqua, New York, after being diagnosed late last week with pneumonia. Her campaign initially did not disclose the illness and only did so after Clinton was forced to leave an event early on Sunday commemorating the 15th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

Story Continued Below

"I tried to power through it but even I had to admit that maybe a few days of rest would do me good," she told the Greensboro, North Carolina, crowd of her pneumonia. "And I'm not great at taking it easy, even under ordinary circumstances, but with just two months to go until Election Day, sitting at home was pretty much the last place I wanted to be."

"But it turns out having a few days to myself was

her to take a second look at her candidacy.

The songs are being composed by the presidential campaign's top digital creators and composers — including the music video director, Tim Burke, and the video director, Sam Nunberg — in conjunction with the campaign.

Burke had just done a live video for Clinton, which played a preview of the campaign's plans for the campaign trail.

Clinton made a campaign stop in Virginia Friday night.

The campaign is expected to unveil its videos for the Democratic primaries in Nevada on Tuesday.

The campaign's new creative team was brought on in January, but it wasn't until Thursday that the campaign started making a concerted effort to create videos and audio for each state.

She also praised Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), calling him a "wonderful man and a wonderful senator."

"In a very personal way, he's touched my heart and I'm so grateful for that," she said.

Her comments also came as she wrapped up a series of public events around the country with donors. After a campaign stop in Pittsburgh Wednesday, Clinton returned to the trail after the 9/11 anniversary event and a meeting with police officers, including an evening appearance with the Pittsburgh Police Federation in downtown Pittsburgh.

The presumptive Democratic presidential nominee then boarded a Boeing 757, as her campaign staff said it was "for a short stop" in Philadelphia where she would deliver remarks at Temple University. A spokeswoman later told POLITICO, "She will be traveling to Philadelphia to deliver her remarks tonight."

reference_text:
his plans in a speech marking the International Day for Elimination of Violence Against Women. "The streets should not become hell for the women of France," he said. Macron noted that the Ministry of the Interior has launched consultations that will lead to new measures "in a few weeks' time."

prefix_text: The California-based electric car manufacturer joins Jaguar, Land Rover and BMW's Mini as brands opting to drive past the 2016 Detroit auto show after having a presence on the main show of Cobo Center in
reference_text:
2015. (Photo: Susana Bates / AFP/Getty Images)

Tesla Motors Inc. is the most recent automaker to bow out of next month's 2016 North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

The California-based electric car manufacturer joins Jaguar, Land Rover and BMW's Mini as brands opting to drive past the 2016 show after having a presence on the main show of Cobo Center in 2015.

A Tesla spokesperson confirmed the move on Friday.

"After much consideration, we have decided against participating at the North American International Auto Show. We've always had a very good experience at Detroit," a company spokesperson said in a statement.

"In Michigan, we have great owners, a strong supercharger network that connects the U.S. with Canada, and are continuing to hire talented employees. But as a small player, Tesla relies on auto shows to not only showcase our products, but engage with consumers and ultimately sell more cars in the region.

The next stage in the automaker's shift toward Chinese markets is a global joint venture in the country. Automakers such as General Motors, Honda, Toyota and Nissan have formed China units recently, and BMW has plans for a Shanghai-based unit. The Chinese joint venture is still in the early stages and GM and BMW's Shanghai office are not in close contact with each other, according to people familiar with the matter.

prefix_text: There's constantly some sort of plagiarism row going on in fashion. Whether it's Mango copying Gucci's silk dresses, Nasty Gal copying Saint Laurent's platform sandals, designer's copying
reference_text:
other designers, artists or, as was most recently the case, the designs of indigenous cultures and tribes. Last week, London-based fashion label KTZ were in hot water over the "Shaman Towelling Sweatshirt" featured in their AW15 collection – a design which Salome Awa says was copied from her great-grandfather Aua, one of the last Shaman of the Canadian Inuit.

"They must have seen it and copied it," Awa told The Evening Standard, "They even called the clothing Shaman... My great-grandfather was a very powerful and respected man and he has been used and violated. It was disgusting to see a sacred design used as a sweater... We are a proud people and our ancestors and traditions are very important to us. The way they have taken and degraded this design is unacceptable." The design itself featured in 2006 film The Journals of Knud Rasmussen as well as some books on the culture of the Inuit such as "Northern

generated_result.0:
their own work... it's never really an issue.

But the recent flap over a Parisian designer stealing the look for a Chinese dress is a different story. And what's going on here is even more bizarre than Nasty Gal, Saint Laurent, and Gucci.

On March 10, Parisian designer Zara tweeted out a picture of a woman wearing the look she calls the "Blessed Woman Dress". The dress is made of silk, has a full embroidered bodice and front and back pockets, and even has a garter belt. Zara's description of the dress is: "Fully embroidered in a classic silk jersey. This piece is the new holy grail of couture, it's as elegant and elegant as the best, but with the magic of China. You can easily imagine it in your life."

Zara then went on to post a photo of the women wearing the dress. But when fans took a closer look at th
generated_result.1:
someone else's boots, or the endless arguments over which version of something you should wear. There are the endless arguments over who's the best designer to own, and who can provide the best service to their clients. Bush sounded credible when he claimed that his administration adhered to federal and international legal standards.

prefix_text: Several people have asked about the techniques we used when cleaning out my mom's fabric stash last week. There are of course many ways to purge, sort, and organize fabric, which I'll write about
reference_text:
later. But first, I wanted to address questions about the folding station and the folding method we used.

It's the same method I've been using as I've been sorting and organizing fabric in my own apartment. Here you see an in-progress picture of my new studio corner with stacks of uniformly-folded fabric. This is a method I first read about from Monica, the Happy Zombie and later from Marilyn Bohn's video.

Of course there are other ways, but this is the cheap, easy, quick one that works for me. The goal is to end up with a stack of fabric that is uniformly folded — the same length and width.

The height of each folded piece varies according to how much yardage you have to begin with.

To accomplish this, you'll need a stack of fabric (45″ wide works best, though other widths can be accommodated), a flat surface, and a large quilter's ruler. My

The solution

I found a great little article written by a blogger named "Bobby" at The Home Depot. The tip of the swab should be about one inch deep, and the back swab should be about one and one-half inch deep. Then gently wipe the swab away with your cloth or wet paper towel.

The pace of the race to the top of Fortune's Unicorn List continues to hasten as startups raise ever-larger sums of money to fuel growth and expansion.

Airbnb, the well
reference_text:
-known home rental service headquartered in San Francisco, has closed a new $1.5 billion funding round, according to reports from the Wall Street Journal and Financial Times. The round, which has been rumored for weeks, values the company at $25.5 billion—billions more than publicly traded neighbor Twitter (TWTR), which had raised far less ahead of its highly anticipated 2013 IPO, and hotel giant Marriott (MAR), which runs more than 4,000 properties around the globe.

At the time of its previous investment earlier this year, investors valued Airbnb at $20 billion. Among venture-backed startups, only Chinese phonemaker Xiaomi and car-hailing service Uber carry higher valuations.

Investors backing the young company this time reportedly include General Atlantic, Hillhouse Capital Group, Tiger Global Management, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, GGV Capital, China Broadband Capital, and Horizon Ventures.

Airbnb isn't alone.

"There's a lot of competition in the space, as the competition has gotten more and more intense," says Patrick McGovern, chief investment officer at Renaissance Technologies, which oversees $4.2 billion.

At least half of these companies are privately held, and half have raised billions, McGovern says.

generated_result.2:

One of the reasons why Facebook can continue to get rich on social media is the fact that the social media juggernaut still has more than one billion monthly active users who continue to pay Facebook to use its services, a huge pool for advertisers and venture capitalists to tap. Facebook continues to spend on ad campaigns to increase traffic to its network. In the town of Thisted in the north of the country, authorities admitted there
reference_text:

Lars Sloth of the town's children and families unit said: "Several young women have felt unsafe on the streets, where they have been accosted by asylum seekers. The same thing has happened on the dance floor out in the nightlife."

The Local reports that several migrants based at the camp have also been arrested for being intoxicated, he added, and police will now conduct a campaign to educate them about what constitutes acceptable behaviour in Denmark.

"First and foremost we want it to be safe and comfortable for all of our residents to move around in Thisted – including in the city's nightlife. Therefore we are initiating extra measures that will contribute to better understanding, fewer conflicts and thus better security," Mr Sloth said.

reference_text:

"The growth in higher education spending over the last 20 years or thereabouts has essentially gone at double the rate of the economy, so that is not of course a sustainable trajectory for higher education to continue on," he told Sky news.

prefix_text: Most economists agree that advances in robotics and AI over the next few decades are likely to lead to significant job losses. But what's less often considered is how these changes could also impact social mobility. A
reference_text:
new report from UK charity Sutton Trust explains the danger, noting that unless governments take action, the next wave of automation will dramatically increase inequality within societies, further entrenching the divide between rich and poor.

The are a number of reasons for this, say the report's authors, including the ability of richer individuals to re-train for new jobs; the rising importance of "soft skills" like communication and confidence; and the reduction in the number of jobs used as "stepping stones" into professional industries.

"Traditionally, jobs like these have been a vehicle for social mobility."

For example, the demand for paralegals and similar professions is likely to be reduced over the coming years as artificial intelligence is trained to handle more administrative tasks. In the UK more than 350,000 paralegals, payroll managers, and bookkeepers could lose their jobs if automated systems can do the same work.

"Traditionally, jobs like these have

generated_result.0:
growing number of people in their 20s and early 30s are living at home and have not yet achieved the middle class, which would imply a significant risk of falling behind.

In this paper, we study an interesting new development in the labour market and inequality, the 'age stratification gap'. Since the 1970s, the gap between workers in the most educated and those in the least educated has widened sharply. Our research suggests that for every year of increase in automation, wages for workers in the least well-educated age group are increased by just 0.18% (relative to a zero-sum outcome). For those in the most educated groups, the difference between their wages and the average is only 0.1%. This has significant impacts on inequality within groups and potentially the mobility of groups.

Can Dundar, editor-in-chief of the Cumhuriyet newspaper, and Ankara bureau chief Erdem Gul are accused of trying to topple the government with the publication last May of a video purporting to show Turkey's state intelligence agency helping to ferry weapons into Syria by truck in 2014.

Their case has brought international condemnation and raised concerns about freedom of expression in Turkey. At their first hearing a week ago, the court took the case behind closed doors and accepted Erdogan as a complainant in what critics said was a move that undermined judicial independence.

Turbo lag is a defining characteristic of older forced-induction cars. These large turbochargers were used to feed high-performance engines and generate significant power.
reference_text:
The problem would come when you called upon that power. Your right foot mashes the gas—then nothing. A shock of power would eventually make its way to the drive wheels, sometimes mid-corner. Turbo lag is notoriously finicky (and in the case of old race cars, a killer) and automakers have been working on ways to reduce or eliminate it. Volvo has its own solution and it involves a bit of engineering that we need explained.

The system is called Power Pulse, and it works with the help of an air compressor and an electric motor. The motor waits for the driver to ask for more power, and it keeps the air compressor tank ready to go with clean air pulled in from the intake. When the throttle is pressed, the air tank can then force compressed air into the exhaust manifold and send it along with the exhaust gases to spool up the turbo.

This is almost similar to what the Fast and Furious crew would be doing when they hit their "

generated_result.0:
In today's racing, turbo lag is the difference between winning and losing.

Turbo lag results in higher fuel consumption in a car where performance is the goal.

If you're in an F1 car, then you know what I mean. And if you're not in an F1 car, you're also aware that the engine in your car has a turbo lag -- some people claim it's over 50 percent. Turbo lag is a consequence of a car's design and its design is often influenced by the number of powerplants. It is a consequence that can be attributed to factors such as the car's design, whether the car is homologated or not, and what turbo lag-inducing technology is installed on it.

Turbo lag is something of a problem in the F1 world, because as I mentioned above, it results in more consumption when it is enabled. There are several factors that can help you avoid turbo lag in your car.

Her
generated_result.1:
But these early turbos would also generate a large amount of lag due to their large bore.

Most turbo lag is caused by a high-pressure, low-volume exhaust valve which opens at low speeds for fuel and air. The valve then closes at high speed for water and air, with a small amount of lag.

But in an engine built for a more compact cylinder head, a smaller engine and a longer cylinder duration, there is a greater chance for the valve to open on the low speed at high velocity. That means the engine is pushing a lot more air and water into the cylinder. With the low speed, the air and water mix together, and as the piston moves forward, the high-pressure gases and pressure move back together and start the combustion.

With this increased pressure, the car accelerates more quickly and the lag builds up. It also means it takes longer for the power to come on, so the car has less fuel to work with.
generated_result.2:
Turbo lag can also lead to a lot of backpressure at low revs and very high fuel loads.

In 2012, a team of researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) discovered that the same thing happens in forced induction cars. By comparing the behavior of cars that operated under the "normal" conditions with those in a race setting, the researchers found that turbo lag is indeed caused by higher peak power and lower peak fuel consumption.

The MIT team used a new design of turbocharger with two turbos mounted in the same engine block. By comparing the performance of those two turbochargers under a race setting against the baseline conditions, they found that the two turbos have about the same amount of time to boost to peak power and burn as much fuel as a diesel engine would under that baseline driving regime.

Turbo lag may not seem to pose a problem when it comes to driving enthusiasts. But when it comes to racing, turbo lag can be pretty detrimental

prefix_text: Google has wired its worldwide fleet of servers up with monitoring technology that inspects every task running on every machine, and eventually hopes to use this data to selectively throttle or even kill processes that cause disruptions for
reference_text:
other tasks running on the same CPU.

The search giant gave details on how it had developed the planet-spanning technology in a technical paper (PDF) due to be published next week – and its contents will be of major interest to anyone running massive Linux-based infrastructure clouds.

"Performance isolation is a key challenge in cloud computing. Unfortunately, Linux has few defenses against performance interference in shared resources such as processor caches and memory buses, so applications in a cloud can experience unpredictable performance caused by other program's behavior," the researchers write.

"Our solution, CPI2, uses cycles-per-instruction (CPI) data obtained by hardware performance counters to identify problems, select the likely perpetrators, and then optionally throttle them so that the victims can return to their expected behavior. It automatically learns normal and anomalous behaviors by aggregating data from multiple tasks in the same job."

In essence, CPI2 lets Google engineers isolate poor performance down to a single task

generated_result.0:

other Ayush doctors may soon be allowed to conduct non-invasive abortions. The health ministry has worked out changes to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Amendment Bill. The revised bill proposes to allow Ayush doctors to conduct non-invasive procedures on women seeking to terminate pregnancy. The draft bill will soon be sent to the Cabinet.

"We have made revisions to the earlier draft and proposed that Ayush doctors who are registered healthcare specialists be allowed to carry out non-invasive procedure, which would mean prescribing medicines etc," a senior health ministry official told TOI.

Another key amendment seeks to increase the period for abortion to 24 weeks from the present 20 weeks. The government's proposal, originally formulated taking a cue from a study conducted by Population Council, is aimed at increasing access to safe abortion by expanding the number of healthcare providers. Estimates show around 7 million abortions are conducted in India every year and over 50% of them are said to be illegal.

prefix_text: Enforcement of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) continues to be a high priority area for the SEC. In 2010, the SEC's Enforcement Division created a specialized unit to further enhance its
reference_text:
enforcement of the FCPA, which prohibits companies issuing stock in the U.S. from bribing foreign officials for government contracts and other business.

The following is a list of the SEC's FCPA enforcement actions listed by calendar year:

2018

Stryker Corp. – The Michigan-based medical device company agreed to pay a $7.8 million penalty for insufficient internal accounting controls and inaccurate books and records. (9/28/18)

Patricio Contesse González – Agreed to pay $125,000 to resolve charges that he violated the FCPA while serving as CEO of Chilean-based chemical and mining company Sociedad Química y Minera de Chile S.A. (9/25/18)

United Technologies – The Connecticut-based company agreed to pay nearly $14 million to settle charges that it made illicit payments to facilitate sales of elevators and aircraft engines. (9/12/18)

For example, in 2011, the SEC began investigating a major U.S. financial institution, HSBC, for the creation and marketing of a fraudulent trust. The SEC is also investigating HSBC's practices related to the unauthorized, improper, and fraudulent deposit of over $1 billion, including over $500 million that originated with offshore clients, in the U.S. The SEC, ICE, the U.S. Attorney's Offices, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and state authorities are continuing to investigate HSBC, and the company has agreed to a resolution of its FCPA violations.

Analysis of Cincinnati shooting's aftermath reveals how multiple officers discussed claim – disputed as the basis of a murder charge – that Ray Tensing was 'dragged' by unarmed black man's car

University
reference_text:
police officer charged with murder for shooting of Samuel DuBose Read more

Police officers in Cincinnati appear to have corroborated a false account of the fatal shooting of Samuel DuBose in the immediate aftermath of the incident, a detailed analysis of body-camera video released on Wednesday shows.

DuBose, an unarmed 43-year-old black man, was shot dead by white University of Cincinnati police officer Ray Tensing on 19 July. The officer claimed he was "dragged" by DuBose's vehicle following an altercation during a routine traffic stop, and was therefore forced to open fire, shooting DuBose once in the head.

On Wednesday, Tensing was indicted for murder after Hamilton County prosecutor Joseph Deters said body-camera footage, which he released at a press conference announcing the charge, showed the officer was not dragged during the encounter.

"It is our belief that he was not dragged. If you slow down this tape you see what happens

generated_result.0:
of Cincinnati police Officer Ray Tensing told officers at a traffic stop that his partner had just murdered a black man in broad daylight, according to police and court documents.

But a court document in the case against him has shown that it was police officials at the scene – not Tensing – who claimed he had been stopped and handcuffed by a man who was not white.

The document, obtained by the Cincinnati Enquirer, reveals how the officer told officers: "He dragged me, it was my fault. He was driving a black Ford Escape."

Tensing had been on his way to a traffic stop for a suspect in an armed robbery, when he was stopped by the driver's side window of a car that had fled the scene.

Tensing said the man had been in the back seat with a pistol, with Tensing's gun. When police reached Tensing, they said he was standing around the car while holding the suspect at gunpoint.

It is the second time in less than a year the city has been shaken by a high-profile fatal shooting incident that has sparked nationwide protest.


A few hours after the incident, police in Cincinnati released surveillance video of a car they believe Castile, a 32-year-old black motorist, was driving during the shooting.

Tensing has been charged with second-degree manslaughter, a felony, as well as two counts of attempted voluntary manslaughter, a misdemeanor.

His attorney, Thomas Demetrio, said Monday that the video is consistent with the officer's claim that Castile's car was "drivable at high speeds," before the officer shot him after finding the gun in his pocket.

The London Symphony Orchestra has had an unprecedented career, and its latest achievement is an extraordinary achievement: The London Symphony Orchestra's extraordinary performance of Bach's Final Symphony.

This is the most comprehensive interpretation of the original performance yet produced. The orchestra performed the work on five separate occasions, beginning with its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera in London on 19th July 1971. It performed the work in the concert hall of London's Royal Albert Hall on 2nd August 1974, the BBC Symphony Hall in London on 23rd September 1975 and the St. Paul's Cathedral concert hall on 22nd October 1975.

It then embarked on a tour to perform it in several countries around the world during its final year at the Metropolitan Opera.

For the occasion of its 50th anniversary, the London Symphony Orchestra performed the music again with the same musicians, musicians and conductor, as originally planned for the final performance.

Donald Trump would like for the United States to spend $1.1 billion less on HIV-treatment programs in sub-Saharan Africa, and
reference_text:
$524 million less on contraception for the global poor.

On the plus side, these cuts will make it easier to finance the president's border wall, which he hopes to spend $1.6 billion on in 2018.

On the downside:

At least one million people will die in sub-Saharan Africa and elsewhere, researchers and advocates said on Tuesday, if funding cuts proposed by the Trump administration to global public health programs are enacted.


… With a huge share of Africa's population reaching sexual maturity in the next four years, the virus could again imperil much of the continent if fewer people are treated, said Brian Honermann, deputy director at amfAR, a foundation that invests in AIDS research.

Imagine if you could plug an external graphics card into your MacBook, then use it for for virtual reality or other gaming. You'd never need a dedicated gaming computer again.

That's the dream
reference_text:
behind The Wolfe, an external graphics card for the Mac that hits Kickstarter tomorrow. Two versions of this Thunderbolt accessory, The Wolfe and The Wolfe Pro, offer an Nvidia GTX 950 and GTX 970 respectively.

The card fits into a case that's a 7.8 inches deep by 5.4 inches wide and 2.6 inches tall, which weighs between two and 3.2 pounds. Stick this in your bag with your laptop, the theory goes, and you've got a portable gaming MacBook.

Related: No Rift support for Mac until 'Apple releases a good computer,' says Oculus founder

Macs, shall we say, do not have the best reputation among gamers. Apple builds its laptops with portability and battery life in mind, not graphical performance. And in general, laptops built specifically for gaming tend to be heavy with awful battery life.

The Wolfe could offer a third path, if it works well. It gives you graphics when you need it, but leaves

prefix_text:
A little about me

My name is Jen or "Jennifer" if I piss my parents off enough. I am born and raised in Ontario, Canada and no, you don't get used to
reference_text:
the winters, at least I haven't yet in my thirty something winters here!


I have always had a magnetic pull towards creative endeavors. My earliest activities were drawing, sculpting (horrendously) and painting whatever I could. At the age of 6 or 7 I decided that my father was completely wasting his tool shed with such nonsense as lawnmowers and gardening tools, and took it upon myself to take over and make it my painting studio.


Let me tell you, it was hot as hell in that little wooden shed at the back of our yard, but I was determined to make my art and my dad didn't complain, in fact he was my very first customer, and still has the misshapen, heat stroke induced portrait of our family dog somewhere.


I went to school for photography, and while that is still a major passion and hobby for me, I quickly realized that I didn't have the drive or will to deal with the horrors of wedding photography

generated_result.0:
it as a teenager or a college student.

I am from an unpretentious family and have always considered myself a "good looking" type of girl, but my family also has lots of gay dads, so that is the kind of side to me I am more familiar with, though I am certainly not the only girl with that side. So now that I have been out of the closet a while, I am able to express who I am and have come to terms with it more. I am not married and I live in Mississauga, Canada and am currently single.

Where to from here?

As a gay man, you have probably been faced with the question "Where do you want to be now?" And this is what I had to think about for some time. As a kid and as a young adult, my life was dominated by being with a female figure. I knew a lot of people and in some ways they were like family, but the "da
generated_result.2:
it. I do enjoy spending most of my days running around city streets to my school's music class, but even here, I will occasionally be given an extra hour for lunch so that I can learn about something that interests me. I am an extroverted personality and a little shy, but that doesn't stop me from hanging out with my friends, playing with my sister, and dancing the most in the school's football league. I will be able to play pretty much any sport I want, and in doing so, I am hoping to be able to work at my university as a teacher. I hope to be able to finish my Master's degree, as well as become a lawyer for my area of interest!

Thanks for the Feedback here and on Reddit – a few updates below:

Anytime Star Trek Online introduces an entirely new set of STF's (Special Task Force), there is a period of
reference_text:
adjustment that the community goes through to absorb the new mechanics and establish teamwork to overcome the new challenges. Sometimes they are relatively easy and reward well enough that they become popular. Other times it takes significant effort and planning just to get through an STF, and those queues get ignored by most of the community.

One thing is for sure, a queues popularity will change over time, as do the techniques used to get through them. The best example is "I've got Kang!" has evolved from being a job you took out of necessity, to something that's little more than a speedbump in the race to complete a CSA in under 30 seconds.

The new missions have their fair share of confusion at the moment that's impacting not only the normals but advanced and elite queues as well. I've had greater success with runs set up privately through Redditchat or the various DPS channels – but at the same time, I've also watched Elites fail in the first 30

What happens at a Yu-Gi-Oh! Championship Series Event?

If you are attending YCS London or the MCM ComicCon that is taking place alongside the YCS, please click here to read important information regarding registration for the event.

The Yu-Gi-Oh! Championship Series events are big, exciting 2-day tournaments where hundreds of Duelists from around the globe compete for fame, glory and all sorts of exclusive prizes. These events are also the perfect opportunity to Duel, trade and hang out with hundreds of other Yu-Gi-Oh! fans.

In addition to the main Championship Series tournament there are numerous Public Events, including tournaments specifically for Duelists born 2001 and later. Competitive or casual, there is something for everyone to do at a Yu-Gi-Oh! Championship Series weekend event.

The Yu-Gi-Oh! Championship Series tournament is an open event. No invite is required - everyone can participate!

reference_text:
describe yourself in 500 words or less. Sum up all of who you are — your aspirations, perspective, strengths, intellect, personality, all of it — in one page, single spaced.

Hit the panic button.

You know what I do when faced with a problem? I ask the Internet. So do a Google search — I dare you — for the phrase "admissions essay advice" and see the mess you get.

One list on a prominent Web site includes the following suggestions (in order, with some paraphrasing): be cautious and then, immediately afterward, be controversial.

WASHINGTON ― The Jones Act waiver for Puerto Rico expired Sunday night, and "it is not being extended at this time," Department of Homeland Security spokesman David Lapan told HuffPost on Monday.

D
reference_text:
HS had temporarily waived the Jones Act ― an arguably outdated law that imposes exorbitant shipping costs on the U.S. island ― on Sept. 28. The waiver had meant that Puerto Rico had the option of importing food, fuel and supplies more quickly, and for half the cost, in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria.

With the 1920 law back in effect, the island is now required to pay much higher costs to import supplies. The Jones Act requires that all goods shipped between U.S. ports be carried by U.S.-owned and operated ships, which are more expensive vessels than others in the global marketplace. That's meant that Puerto Rico pays double the costs to import goods from the U.S. mainland compared with neighboring islands ― and that U.S. vessels are making bank.

The return to higher shipping costs won't help Puerto Rico as it tries to climb out of economic devastation. Nearly half of the 3.4 million Americans on the island still don

generated_result.0:
HS also said it is preparing to expand its work on the Jones Act.

Puerto Rico, a U.S. territory, is part of the United States. The Jones Act imposes a 50-year ban on shipping cargo from other countries to the island.

"This is a major setback to recovery efforts in Puerto Rico, and it is not being extended at this time," Jones Act spokesman Michael Toner said.

The Jones Act prevents foreign shipping companies from transporting goods, including goods that the Jones Act says are "necessarily carried on board a vessel of a foreign nation for the passage of goods between its port of entry and its destination."

Congress passed the act in 1918 with the understanding that it would not affect commerce in Puerto Rico. But the U.S. territory's situation has proven far different from that.

Puerto Rico's debt and financial crisis was exacerbated by decades of Puerto Rico's reliance on debt. After a 2012 federal bankruptcy

In a statement, House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady, R-Texas, blamed the issue on "technicalities with the Jones Act and we regret that."

"When the current waiver expires, we hope that the House will reconsider this measure and take action on what is a very important, bipartisan issue," Brady said.

On Friday, Republican Sen. Pat Toomey of Pennsylvania, who had been an early backer of the Jones Act, issued a statement opposing the waiver.

"My constituents want relief from high shipping costs on Puerto Rico that the Jones Act created. I remain concerned that this measure does not resolve the situation," he sai

HS said it does have the authority to renew the law.

The Jones Act, a 1930s law designed to prevent the passage of ships laden with American goods between U.S. ports, requires that ports and harbors in the U.S. maintain a minimum of 27 shipping lanes. It makes this a requirement of international shipping, and the government has enforced it as a norm ever since World War II, even though it has long since been viewed as an unfair barrier that forces American-flagged ships to operate across foreign ports.

But this year, Congress voted to let the Jones Act stay in place ― and the Trump administration is moving to roll back it. President Donald Trump ― who has long called for its repeal ― signed an executive order on Friday afternoon that would exempt U.S.-flagged ships from the law and impose the same requirements on shipping vessels that use an international border.

That order will now move to the desk of the White House. L

For the first time, scientists have studied clouds and wind on the night side of Venus, and they've found that it's very different from the day side, IFL Science reports.

That
reference_text:
data comes from the European Space Agency's Venus Express spacecraft, which entered orbit around Venus in April 2006 before being crashed into the planet in December 2014. Led by the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA), the study was published in Nature.

We already knew that Venus has a weird super-rotation, where its winds can rotate 60 times faster than the planet. But it seems that on the night side, this process is even more chaotic than on the day side.

"This study challenges our current understanding of climate modelling and, specifically, the super-rotation, which is a key phenomenon seen at Venus," said Håkan Svedhem, ESA Project Scientist for Venus Express, in a statement.

The team found that night-side clouds form large, irregular patterns, dominated by waves that appear to stand still in the atmosphere, called stationary waves. In January of this year, a huge stationary wave was seen on Venus by the Akatsuki spacecraft, stretching

generated_result.0:
's the good news. In the bad news, the bad news is that the good news isn't quite as good. Because Venus is so far away from Earth, its atmosphere absorbs much of the heat coming from the Sun, and Venus's thin atmosphere doesn't seem to help keep the planet warm or cool.

"We see a lot of this on Earth," says researcher Jonathan Webb, from the Max Planck Institute for Solar System Research. "We also see an additional fingerprint of the atmosphere in Venus' atmosphere, on its atmosphere you see more dark bands, but we don't see the warmest, driest Venus atmosphere ever seen."

When Venus was still hot, it was covered with clouds. Now the atmosphere is much thinner, which makes it less efficient at trapping heat. This is an important detail because Earth is also covered in clouds.

"It's hard to imagine a more extreme place to go to study Venus than on the night side," Webb said. "
generated_result.1:
's because the night side of Venus, which is much colder and denser, has a lot of more particles that can impact clouds and reduce their ability to form. The temperature difference between the day side and night side is 2.1 degrees Fahrenheit, compared with a little less than 1-degree of difference between day and night on Earth.

That means Venus isn't as similar to Earth as we're usually led to believe.

But because it has such dense clouds, the scientists have to calculate how many molecules that are ejected into space during every hour of the day and night. If Venus has more than one day day, the amount of particles is more important because they'd have to pass through the clouds and interact with the clouds before reaching us.

The answer is that for each hour of day and night there's roughly 4.7 particles per hour, about 1 million on Venus, which is about 10,000 times the amount on Earth. For the night side, th
generated_result.2:
's because the night side of Venus is actually cooler, meaning it doesn't produce enough heat to make the clouds and wind so hot that scientists believe they were the source of the Venusian winds.

That's the conclusion reached by a team of scientists from the University of Hawaii at Manoa and the University of Arizona in Tucson. According to The Guardian, they used radar and ground-based telescopes to look for clouds and wind during daylight hours on Venus' day side.

They found the temperature of Venus was significantly lower than on Earth, which explains why the winds don't blow as strong.

Although the scientists were using very low-resolution data, they can infer that on the night side of Venus, there are fewer clouds, and they can also detect that Venusian wind speeds are much higher.

in the presidential battleground state.

The Virginia-based 4th Circuit Court of Appeals declared that the measures violated the Constitution and the federal Voting Rights Act by targeting black voters "with almost surgical precision." It marks the third ruling in less than two weeks against voter ID laws after court decisions regarding Texas and Wisconsin.

Friday's opinion from a three-judge panel states that "the legislature enacted one of the largest restrictions of the franchise in modern North Carolina history" when it rewrote voting laws in 2013.

The appeals court also dismissed arguments by Republican lawmakers that the law was aimed at preventing voter fraud.

"Although the new provisions target African Americans with almost surgical precision, they constitute inapt remedies for the problems assertedly justifying them and, in fact, impose cures for problems that did not exist," the opinion states.

prefix_text:
About

Description

C.U.B.E.S is a VR-Puzzle Game developed for the HTC-Vive.

The player finds himself in a cryptic labyrinth
reference_text:
of rooms and riddles. The goal is to complete each room and their tasks, in order to maybe find a way out of the complex.

The gameplay consists of various rooms, which represent in themselves a puzzle.

Every one of them uses a different gameplay features.

Logic, combinatorial skills and stamina are necessary to solve the tasks and move forward from room to room.

The diversity ranges from rooms in darkness and light over Laser barriers up to gravity and time. Each puzzle or room consists of its own paradigms

The game is designed for an immersive roomscale experience and relies on interaction and diversity in its gameplay.


Brief History

We are Students of Multimediatechnology at the University of Applied Science in Salzburg and C.U.B.E.S is our graudation project.


Technical Information

This game was made with Unity

The target VR hardware is HTC Vive.

generated_result.0:
of a room where time and space have been shattered. In this world, nothing can be seen or heard except the sound of water flowing, the sound of rain falling, and the sounds of a cat purring. The goal is to escape the labyrinth without being trapped in it.

To achieve his goal the player must solve a series of puzzles that each solve different puzzles in a different game. Each puzzle involves moving the player around the room and solving certain challenges for additional prizes. In total there are 16 puzzles to solve. These puzzles are each linked together to form a longer story.

The game is designed with the use of room scale VR headsets in mind, and players will use a combination of touch and head tracking to solve each puzzle.

Once you have reached your destination the gameplay gets a bit more interesting. You will have to navigate the puzzle while avoiding obstacles, and use different puzzle pieces in an attempt to avoid an impending trap. The player can also plac

A unique VR-Puzzle gameplay experience!

Challenging puzzles requiring precise movement skills.

Exploration, discovery, and mystery.

A fully 3D environment with varied environments and obstacles to overcome.

Multiplayer & Oculus Rift Support.

Animated GIFs!

Music by C.U.B.E.S: https://soundcloud.com/cbeses

C.U.B.E.S is available on Steam for Vive, Oculus, and Windows 10.

BASIC (or "Hello World") BASIC is a low-level (1 to 2K) text-based computer language invented by AT&T. It is mostly used for writing command lines. There are five main components of BASIC:

Text: each line is stored in memory as a series of characters.

Input: a single instruction (code) is executed to generate an output.

Output: any other data. The code for an object may be stored in variables, strings, or tables.

Object: a single object can have variables, tables, and many other variables, called attributes.

This time, she had to wonder if their safety was in her hands, or if it lay with the police, who were doing a job that most of them could never do.

They are not police officers, but they have become increasingly visible in Chicago, the nation's third-largest city, which is grappling with its most violent decade in decades. The city is the victim of what critics say is a militarized police force, with its high-tech, militarized response to everything from street fights to carjackings to mass shootings.

Many African-Americans in Chicago have complai

And, she said, she did.

The boy, who had no visible injuries, was not in a wheelchair or a walker, the statement said.

Police later said in an alert that witnesses said they "saw the subject jump into the river and then run down the west side of the street to the rear of the house."

In order to provide you with a fresh start to your degree program, you must cancel your BCIT course at the end of your program.

prefix_text: It's an odd time in the DC Extended Universe. Patty Jenkins' Wonder Woman has made a huge amount of money, and became an example of how to bring a hero to the screen with style and
reference_text:
substance. We're awaiting Aquaman's first movie and the new Justice League film, a long-held dream for DC fans, with a sense of quiet anticipation. The sequel to Suicide Squad is being fast-tracked, and there's a Martin Scorsese-produced Joker movie on the way… Strange things are afoot at the circle DC…

Yet with a roster of the most recognisable (and profitable) comic book characters on its books DC appear to be having trouble finding their feet. We're post-Logan, post-Deadpool and each new direction a comic book movie succeeds with could well become a template for all that follow.

So, all eyes are on DC for the foreseeable future. Today we received confirmation that Matthew Vaughn is in talks with DC about the sequel to Man of Steel, and it could be a whole new take on the cinematic Superman.

The Kick-Ass director was in the mix at Warner Bros. when they were looking to

I'll come back to Wonder Woman later in the column, as I am looking more closely at the rest of DC's films. For now, though, let me talk about one of the few DC Comics adaptations in which Wonder Woman can actually have a positive impact on the world. It's called Batman V Superman: Dawn Of Justice, and in addition to its massive success, it also helped usher in the superhero genre we know today.

For those of you unaware, the film is based on the DC Comics universe created by Bob Kane and Bill Finger, which was formed by the merger of the Superman comic book series and the Watchmen film. class. In that sense, the first installment of The Flash is just another movie in that series, with a different cast and a different tone. But this one has a darker and deeper tone that's both fun and deep.

The film's villain, King Shark, is such an iconic figure that it seems crazy that he hasn't been used in a movie before (even though, again, DC Comics has had a Shark in some form or another since the 1930s). When this version of Shark comes into the picture, it's clear he's different. He's not an obvious threat like Superman's evil counterpart, nor is he a familiar, familiar face like Batman's. Instead, we see a young, hungry shark who is just trying to get by on the scraps he's collected from the ocean, as he attempts to outrun the law.

Not to mention, all of the big movies are not making as much money as they used to. So DC is looking for a different way to show that money is pouring into the universe.

Inception might seem like a less ambitious project, and that might be true. It is, after all, a dark, futuristic sci-fi film. There's no room for superhero action, which I'm going to point out is not a genre that Warner Bros. knows well. But the studio has been on the money with these superhero movies for a long time. prefix_text: There are, as the cops would say, several facts "pertaining" to Mr Khan's kidnapping. Firstly, his son Hafiz Zaenullah, his brother Asif Iqbal and another
reference_text:
man – a stonemason called Khaliq Dad – were killed by a drone attack on Mr Khan's home in December 2009. Secondly, he had filed a legal case in Pakistan against the American drone strikes, arguing that they constituted murder under domestic law. And thirdly – perhaps Mr Khan's most serious crime – he was about to leave for Brussels to address European Union parliamentarians on the dangers of American drone strikes in Pakistan.

In Madiha Tahir's recent documentary film Wounds of Waziristan, Mr Khan had talked about his family loss. His son Hafiz was a security guard at a local girls' school, and also studying for Grade 10. Asif, who had a Master's in English, was a government employee. Karim Khan saw what was left of their bodies, "covered in wounds". He found some of their fingers in the rubble of his home.

Thanks to constant reports of his kidnapping in the courageous Pakistani media and to

generated_result.0:
brother, Faiz are all in Karachi. They were out of town in November 2013 when Hafiz was kidnapped from his wife in an upscale neighbourhood in Quetta, Pakistan. Asif, the eldest brother, was on his way to visit his father and brother-in-law in Rawalpindi.

They are believed to have made it to Karachi on November 16 when the kidnappers made a second attempt to abduct them.

They say they have since left Karachi, but are currently staying in a guest house in Chagai. Hafiz and Hafiz Zaenullah remain missing. Asif, Faiz and Asif's cousin, who were in Rawalpindi when the kidnappers took them hostage, are now in Karachi, allegedly in the custody of the Pakistan Army.

Asif's relatives say that, since they had just moved to Karachi in November, his parents had already told him to hide somewhere. However, he went out with his
generated_result.1:
brother, Abdul Rehman Zaenullah are all currently in the police custody. The three are being questioned by the investigators.

The third, most important point is that Mr Khan has denied involvement in his son's kidnapping. He says he gave the police Rs 1 lakh ransom. The CBI wants the three arrested to be tried along with his son.

That raises some questions. Is it necessary to wait for them to be captured and tried and if not, then by whom? The case of Mr Khan and his son, of course, will be heard in a courtroom.

Then there's the question as to how the authorities, not being satisfied by the evidence presented in his case, have decided to go ahead with the court proceedings against Mr Khan. This is an extraordinary move, especially as the prosecution in this case claims it will prove that Mr Khan was involved in the abduction of the two other young men: Rafiq Zaidan Khan and Mohsin Khan.

These facts are not the only ones that are known to him. There is also the fact that his sister Zohra Ali, who lived in London, was on the flight when it crashed.

A Coors Light truck struck a bicyclist this morning in Cambridge near the corner of Massachusetts Ave. and Sidney Street. The bicyclist suffered leg injuries but no head injuries and has been taken to a nearby hospital, according to Jeremy Warnick, a spokesman for the Cambridge Police.

The incident occurred at approximately 8:21 a.m. Warnick said the department's traffic enforcement investigation unit was investigating the scene and working to reconstruct the accident.

Warnick did not immediately have data available on the number of accidents involving cyclists that have occurred this year. According to the city's Community Development Department, "the crash rate in Cambridge has been decreasing with the steady increase in numbers of people bicycling."

The Timberwolves will attempt to snap a 15-game skid to the Los Angeles Lakers by taking advantage of their struggles on the road Sunday night. For the third time this season, Minnesota (9-10) is close to evening its record. In the most recent attempt, the Timberwolves were 7-8 before a 108-98 loss at Utah on Jan. 21 but have gotten another chance after two wins over teams from the Lone Star State. After a 105-90 victory in Dallas on Wednesday, they topped San Antonio 87-79 on Friday when Ricky Rubio scored nine of his 18 points in the fourth quarter. Dallas officials have confirmed the first case of Zika virus in the US being transmitted locally via sexual intercourse.

Just one day after the World Health Organization deemed the virus as an international health emergency, officials
reference_text:
in Dallas County said the patient had contracted the virus via sexual contact and not through a mosquito bite, as reported by NBC.

Dallas County Health and Human Services said the patient was infected after sexual contact with a person who had the virus and had returned from a country where the virus is known to be present.

The patient, their condition and address have not been identified.

Officials said this is the first case of the virus to be transmitted locally in Texas, although there are seven others in Houston and Harris County who have confirmed cases of the virus after traveling abroad.

Common symptoms include fever, rash, joint pain and conjunctivitis or red eyes. The virus is usually mild with symptoms lasting several days to a week. However, there is thought to be a link between the virus and a rise in cases of microcephaly – a birth defect, which causes abnormal smallness of the head in babies – in the affected countries.

"Now that we

"Our investigation indicates the mosquito that is responsible for this infection is found in the city, and we're looking into what the source is of infection."

McNeill says the city has not gotten any evidence that the person with the virus was pregnant.

He added: "We are trying to find out as much as we can, and make sure that we address the vector and provide additional mosquito control measures that are necessary to prevent the spread of this infection."

Zika virus is spread through direct contact with an infected mosquito. There is no known treatment for it, and its symptoms, including severe headaches, a rash, joint pain, and fever, vary from individual to individual.

It is estimated that thousands of cases of Zika virus are currently under investigation across Africa, Central America, and the Caribbean.

But unlike the recent outbreaks in the US, most of those have occurred in Latin America, Africa, and the Middle East.

At the 2008 Child Neurology Society meeting in San Jose, California, I presented six
reference_text:
children with a unique syndrome I called "Exorcist Syndrome"


1. Hyperacute onset - parents point to hour of change

2. Ballistic tics - forceful, unrestrained, violent - can put holes in walls, etc.

3. Disinhibition - expletives, capable of serious physical harm to self or others

4. "Falsetto" vocal change - voice is clear, no aphasia but change in quality of voice - gruff/demonic, Bugs Bunny, infantile

5. Symptoms seem to turn on and off like a switch. At times appear completely normal, then symptoms above suddenly rage.


These previously normal children acquire this illness suddenly and appear to be demonically possessed. It is not an encephalitis or encephalopathy as the sensorium remains clear, there is no significant cognitive dysfunction.


Every one of these children was fully alert, could recall the episode entirely. Video EEG

Can you describe

your journey for those who did not follow you in the last 5 years?

We are Karol "Charlie" Lewandowski and Aleksandra Ślusarczyk, and we are young travel bloggers from Poland, authors of Bus Around The World blog, who did not have a lot of money but wanted to see the world.

We bought an old van for $600 an painted it. We brought our tent, food and just took off. In 6 years we visited more than 50 countries and we traveled more than 100,000 miles on 5 continents. So far we never paid for accommodations and we almost always cooked our own meals.

Our car broke down at least 50 times, but we learned how to repair it during the trip. Followers from our blog helped us along the way and people even supported fuel costs. It feels like people from all over the world traveled with us!

Is the cost of proof of work in bitcoin mining fair? Tomaso Aste of the UCL Centre for Blockchain Technologies at the University College London's Department of Computer Science thinks the current
reference_text:
cost large and wasteful, but nonetheless, fair. Aste recently examined the factors that determine the current proof of work cost in a study titled "The fair cost of Bitcoin proof of work."

Aste noted that bitcoin has proven that untrustful peers can exchange value over the Internet without any third party intermediary or trusted authority, as bitcoin has surpassed $10 billion in capitalization and processes tens of thousands of daily transactions with any serious challenge of attack.

Computationally Intensive Process

The verification and cryptographic sealing mechanism that is critical to the bitcoin network involves a computationally intensive process. A large number of nodes in the bitcoin network engage in the verification process.

The process provides a mechanism that avoids false duplications of voters and forces voters to demonstrate computational capacity. To secure a qualified majority, the system employs a cryptographic sealing process that is computationally intensive. The process includes a challenge called "proof of work." The first node that solves this challenge receives a bitcoin reward

generated_result.0:
cost for mining a block is "fair" for what is likely to be the slowest process in mining bitcoin, since it is still a very conservative method to mine the currency.

In a paper titled "Bitcoin mining and the fair-coin-selection problem", Aste explains that the reason why there is so much confusion about bitcoin mining is because the system of mining bitcoins is so complex, unlike in other cryptographic currency. Bitcoin is based on the concept of a proof-of-work algorithm that is based on a random seed, a hash that contains the hash values of all the possible bitcoin addresses that may exist at some point in the future. As the algorithm is made more complex, so more of the hash values of bitcoin addresses that may be created in the future are found, and a block is created. The algorithm is also used to solve the cryptographic hash function SHA256. The difficulty of finding a block in the system is determined by the difficulty of finding the SHA256 function, which

In fact, he has even recommended investors not try to mine bitcoin, telling the BBC that he doesn't think mining it will make a difference to the currency.

He explained: "It is certainly not a good investment, I think it will not be of any use and I don't think the long-term growth in this sector is going to see much benefit either."

Refugee groups now predict that entries into the United States could increase so rapidly that the total number of refugees admitted by Sept. 30, the end of the fiscal year, could exceed 70,000. That is well below the 84,994 refugees admitted in fiscal year 2016, but not by nearly as much as many advocates had feared.

Refugee advocates were delighted by the State Department's decision.

"This is long overdue, but we're very happy," said Mark Hetfield, president and chief executive of HIAS, an immigrant aid society.

But many of the advocates said they were worried that any reprieve would be temporary.

"The president's proposed budget cuts for 2018 would mean we would have a much smaller program next year no matter what happens with his executive orders," said Erol Kekic, executive director of the immigration and refugee program at Church World Service.

prefix_text: Django or Drupal for Content Management: Which Fits your Needs? If you're building or updating a website, you're probably wondering about which content management system (CMS) to use.
reference_text: A CMS helps users — particularly non-technical users — to add pages and blog posts, embed videos and images, and incorporate other content into their site. CMS options You could go with something quick and do-it-yourself, like WordPress (read more about WordPress) or a drag-and-drop builder like Squarespace. If you need greater functionality, like user account management or asset tracking, or if you're concerned about security and extensibility, you'll need a more robust CMS. That means using a framework to build a complex website that can manage large volumes of data and content. Wait, what's a framework? Put simply, a framework is a library of reusable code that is easily edited by a web developer to produce custom products more quickly than coding everything from scratch. Django and Drupal are both frameworks with dedicated functionality for content management, but there is a key difference between them: Drupal combines aspects of a web application framework with aspects of a CMS Django separates the framework and

And when the time comes to move your site over to a new CMS, or to update it, you're likely to go through more trial and error than you ever expected. So what's the best solution? As it turns out, the answer is pretty complicated. But before we dive in to how different web and mobile-friendly CMSs may differ, it's worth thinking a little about some facts. While these CMSs are used for building, maintaining and publishing applications, they're also used for building and distributing software. LOS ANGELES -- Federal Communications Commission Chairman Tom Wheeler wants consumers to be able to say goodbye to their cable set-top boxes.

In a Los Angeles Times op-ed piece published Thursday,
reference_text:
Wheeler is proposing a new rule that would require cable and satellite video companies to offer consumers the option to receive their channels through apps that provide streaming video over the Internet. Consumers have long chafed at having to pay for set-top boxes to get a cable signal.

"If adopted, consumers will no longer have to rent a set-top box, month after month," Wheeler wrote. "Instead, pay-TV providers will be required to provide apps -- free of charge -- that consumers can download to the device of their choosing to access all the programming and features they already paid for."

Wheeler's proposal comes six months after the Federal Communications Commission voted 3-2 along party lines to begin crafting rules intended to spur competition in the set-top box market by developing technology standards so that third-party devices and apps could decode pay-TV signals.

Such a service would enable consumers to watch cable channels over on an Internet-connected television or device such as an Xbox

generated_result.0:
Wheeler and FCC staffers argue that Americans have become addicted to the pricey box and have become disillusioned with the cable industry.

It may be time to pull the plug on your cable box and use the Internet instead.

"Cable boxes are increasingly the source of the consumer frustration with cable," Wheeler wrote in the op-ed. "They're too big. They require constant access. They require a hefty monthly fee, which can force families to make difficult decisions, like which family member to cut off and cut out of the cable package."

That could lead to a loss of customers and a rise in cable prices.

"If Americans have to pay for their entertainment needs over and over again, that will threaten a valuable customer base," Wheeler wrote. "At the same time, if they're forced to keep paying for cable and pay for more and more services, they will ultimately become less desirable to advertisers."

Under Wheeler's proposal, consumers could instead opt
generated_result.1:
the three-term incumbent chairman argued that he is ready to begin the move to a device that will let consumers cut the cord completely if they want.

The proposal represents a dramatic shift away from a technology that for most Americans is already a staple of their lives, the chairman wrote in the Los Angeles Times, pointing to the success of Netflix's DVD-by-mail service and streaming of hundreds of movies and TV episodes.

The FCC is preparing to discuss the proposal on Thursday and has said the proposal would cover the set-top box market -- or what Wheeler called the "cord cutter" market -- which comprises about two-thirds of subscribers. In addition, the proposed rules would apply to any device that provides video or audio services to a small number of TVs, set-top boxes and other devices.

"Today's technology is different from what consumers use today, and the FCC must respond to the changing nature of the business and ensure consumers have the ability to enjoy their
generated_result.2:
Wheeler says that as Americans move away from cable boxes and online video over the next year, cable companies will soon face a choice -- move to an online platform or simply vanish.

The FCC chairman says he hopes the new rules will lead to an "innovation revolution" and help consumers get an entertainment experience they have not experienced previously.

"That's the hope," Wheeler writes.

He says the FCC rules will help cable and satellite providers "gain the competitive advantage in the marketplace by providing choice and increased flexibility for consumers and small business."

Wheeler says there are several possible new innovations on the horizon. And he doesn't believe the current set-top box model is enough to guarantee a better service.

"In today's technology world, consumers can enjoy video services over multiple devices including phones, tablets, and TVs. Our competition in television set-top boxes is weak, so consumers are forced to purchase the latest set-top box," Wheeler writes.

Background

For bodybuilders, beef is an important part of a
reference_text:
healthy diet. Shopping for the different cuts of meat can be difficult sometimes, especially if you don't know the nutritional value of the beef. In this section, we will show you the following:

Most American cattle breeds are descendents of animals imported, possibly by the Vikings, during the early 1000s. Columbus and other early explorers also brought cattle on board their ships. Today, over 100 million head of cattle live in the United States and Canada. Beef is available in many different cuts, including steaks, roasts, brisket, stew meat, and ground beef. Tender cuts come from the ribs and loin. Tougher cuts come from the rump and shoulder. Prime beef has thin layers of fat, called marbling, running visibly through the muscle. Choice beef has little or no marbling but a layer of pinkish fat on the outer edges.

The Importance Of Beef

Many of us are trying to eat healthily. We are adding

generated_result.0:

A typical 1-ounce steamed cut of beef contains 9 g of protein and 45 calories.

Because it is high in calories and protein, beef is important for fat-reducing diets because it can decrease appetite. You can get your total daily protein intake from whole-wheat bread (2 servings per day) and lean proteins such as meat and poultry (about 3 servings per day) but the meat and poultry should not be completely ignored. The bug has been confirmed on Windows 10, with both Windows 7 and Windows 8 working as of now.

A bug has been discovered in Windows 10 which causes files copied from one location to another
reference_text:
on a PC-connected Android to vanish completely if the built-in file manager File Manager is used for the operation.

The issue affects only files that are being moved or copied from an Android folder or storage device to another location on the same Android phone or tablet using an MTP or PTP USB connection, and it does not seem to impact copying data on a Windows 10 PC.

This means, when users connect an Android device to a Windows 10 PC and try to move files with File Explorer from the phone to an SD card or vice versa, this will result in data vanishing completely. The transfer appears to be working, but the files do not reach the destination folder, with no recovery possible for the time being.

The bug has been confirmed on Windows 10, with both Windows 7 and Windows 8 working correctly as of now. Also, there are a number of Android phones which appear to be affected, including OnePlus and LG models, Google's Nexus and Pixel, HTC

generated_result.0:
to not be recognized by a USB flash drive. The error is caused due to a USB drive's internal data partition not being recognized as FAT32 on all systems.

A fix for this issue is currently in development on Microsoft's end. However, due to the complexity of the issue, users will probably see this bug be patched more quickly in Windows 10.

As we reported previously, a similar bug has been observed in Windows 8 which causes files to be copied to drive E:\, but still appear as FAT32 on Windows 7 and Windows 8.

How To Fix This Bug On Windows 8

To fix this bug on Windows 8, you need to boot into the Recovery mode, and select 'Advanced Options' and uncheck 'File System check' on the system settings.

You should now see a new option at the bottom of the screen that states 'Reformatted drives.' Select 'Yes' to finish the process.

Windows 10 has been experiencing this issue lately, although it might have been a bit of an over-reaction from Microsoft. However, it is quite a common issue in software that handles multiple files in its system.

Who Stands Where In A Crowded Elevator And Why?

She's in Finland now, getting her Ph.D. at the University of Jyvaskyla, but before
reference_text:
that, when she was in Adelaide, Australia, she studied elevator behavior. Rebekah Rousi hung around two tall office towers in town, riding elevators up and down day after day, looking for patterns. When a bunch of people get into an elevator, she wondered, do they segregate in any predictable way? Do tall ones stand in the back? Do men stand in different places than women? Who looks where? She says she wasn't expecting or even predicting a particular configuration, but she found one.

Over and over, she noticed that older "more senior men in particular seem to direct themselves towards the back of the elevator cabins."

Younger men took up the middle ground.

And in the front, facing the doors, backs to the guys, stood "women of all ages."

She's not sure why. It wasn't segregation by height. It wasn't age, since older and younger women co-mingled. Clearly,

generated_result.0:
that she had a two-year research fellowship at a lab in Finland, where she was a researcher on some of the most groundbreaking applications of artificial intelligence. There she had worked with the computer vision team of the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, an affiliate of the European Organization for Nuclear Research, to build what is arguably the most accurate computer vision system ever developed. It was even better than some of the best artificial vision systems today.

In 2010, Google recruited her to become a professor at the company's deep learning research lab in Mountain View. She was given an opportunity to use this research to figure out just what this machine vision system was capable of in the real world, and whether it could potentially replace some of the more complicated work done by computer vision algorithms in the field of video and image recognition.

How Google Built An AI System That Could See Images That Were Too Unclear To See, and Could Replace Human Vision Experts

In early 2011, when Dr. Sh

she arrived she was part of the crowd of 200 people who waited for the train to get to the station. She watched the people get off, she saw where the train was coming from, and all of a sudden she was in the elevator with 500 other people.

That makes the experience a bit different from an elevator ride in the United States. There, you've got to wait for a while, so some of the people in the elevator are more anxious than others, and the people in the elevator tend to talk a lot, and that's where the conversations get interesting.

I'm in the elevator with two people in a conversation. I can tell that both of them are anxious, but I'm not sure that either of them is complaining. They've sat there for almost an hour, and the elevator is now slowly descending. I turn on the microphone and ask: "Do you think it's worth it?"

The first answer I get, "Maybe," is th
generated_result.2:
that she's known for her original thesis on standing alone in a crowded elevator, with the doors and windows open.

As a child she said she wanted to be a writer in her family, and then, as an adult, realized she wanted to live on the East Coast. So here she is, with both a degree and a dream.

reference_text:
UPDATE: The Birth of a Nation set a new sales record Tuesday at the Sundance Film Festival, netting a $17.5 million distribution deal from Fox Searchlight. According to Variety and The Hollywood Reporter, an overnight bidding war included escalating offers from The Weinstein Co., Netflix and Paramount.

PARK CITY, Utah — The Birth of a Nation got a standing ovation, and it hadn't even started yet.

Monday afternoon, the crowd rose to salute director/star/writer Nate Parker before it had seen a frame of his slavery drama, which centers its powerful story around a slave rebellion led by Nat Turner in 1831.

The timing was nothing short of incredible. Diversity discussions had dominated Sundance Film Festival for five days, after the Academy Awards announced all-white acting nominees for the second year in a row.

Then The Birth of a Nation arrived, starkly and thoughtfully excavating the roots of American racism.

"I made this

generated_result.0:
THE MOST ANCIENT BREAD.

The film is set in the era when slaves were able to claim slaves if their master so chose.

But, while Nat Turner was eventually freed by his master, his rebellion took on a much darker tone. His slaves were terrorized by white men.

Parker stars as Nat Turner, a slave leader who became a national leader of the abolitionist movement.

The movie is based on a Pulitzer Prize-winning book by Booker T. Washington that focuses on the life of Nat Turner, a South Carolina slave who led the attack on the local post office.

The film is set in the 1831 slave rebellion led by Nat Turner, a South Carolina slave leader who became a national leader of the abolitionist movement. (Photo: Sundance Institute)

The movie centers on an intense and sometimes brutal fight between two factions of rebels. During one battle, Parker's character is shot with a crossbow bol
generated_result.1:
What's most striking about 'Birth of a Nation' is the audacity of its premise. The movie's title refers to an actual event, but it is in its depiction of the events that gave birth to a violent, murderous rebellion in the Jim Crow South that has defined race relations for nearly 200 years.

Parker is playing a slave named Nat Turner who is a leader of the Sons of Confederate Veterans. He was responsible for the death of two men and the rape of two women by members of his own slave crew when he captured them in an effort to end their rebellion. It's a story so rich, so rich with violence, that it might as well be a film about slavery. The movie's premise seems like it would be a good way to wrap up a film series based on a novel, but in fact, the plot only really begins in the late 19th century.

By Mike De Souza

OTTAWA — The federal government has acknowledged that it deliberately excluded data indicating a 20% increase in annual pollution from Canada's oilsands industry in 2009 from a recent
reference_text:
567-page report on climate change that it was required to submit to the United Nations.

The numbers, uncovered by Postmedia News, were left out of the report, a national inventory on Canada's greenhouse gas pollution. It revealed a 6% drop in annual emissions for the entire economy from 2008 to 2009, but does not directly show the extent of pollution from the oilsands production, which is greater than the greenhouse gas emissions of all the cars driven on Canadian roads.

The data also indicated that emissions per barrel of oil produced by the sector is increasing, despite claims made by the industry in an advertising campaign.

"The oilsands remain Canada's fastest-growing source of greenhouse gas pollution, and they're the subject of a huge amount of attention and scrutiny in Canada and internationally," said Clare Demerse, director of climate change at the Pembina Institute, an Alberta-based environmental research group. "So it's very disappointing to see Environment Canada publish a

generated_result.0:
analysis to prepare for the 2010 federal election.

In its annual report on the economy released Tuesday, the government said its calculations were based on "a range of assumptions" that were "subject to change over time."

For example, in its 2009 budget, the government claimed a 40% increase in emissions for the oilsands for 2009 to 2022 "due to continued increases in emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases" and assumed they would be met through reductions in federal taxes.

That was then the government's interpretation of the government's own data from 2009.

But now, an update to that 2009 budget shows "the underlying assumptions were revised downward" and that pollution was predicted to rise by 19% from 2007 to 2016 based on a range of new data.

The report notes that "no new emissions data for the oilsands were released for 2009 or the 2007 to 2014 period to take account of these revisions, which could explain why emissions in the forecast for 2010
generated_result.1:
climate change report.

An April 11 report by the federal Environment Department's Climate Change and Canada's Natural Capital Program identified significant emissions from Canada's oilsands as the source of "global warming-related greenhouse gases" between 2005 and 2009.

However, the federal government's Climate Change Strategy and National Energy Board's National Offshore Drilling Strategy did not include that data, an omission that angered environmentalists, who said it is now the "fog of the unknown" in the energy sector.

The new oilsands data was included in the 2009 edition of the Strategic Environmental Assessment for the 2009 National Energy Program, a report produced by the national energy board, which makes recommendations for future energy investments to Canada and the U.S.

The oilsands' oil and gas emissions have accounted for a quarter of Canada's total greenhouse gas emissions between 2005 and 2009, the government says.

In an April 15 press release, Environment and Climate Change Canada said the omission was du
generated_result.2:
independent federal analysis of environmental impacts from the controversial oil sands.

The 2009 National Roundtable on the Environment and the Economy report stated there was a 1.1-per-cent increase in emissions from the oilsands from the start of production in 2008. But the government's own data contradicts the claims in the report.

This week, the report's authors and others released a follow-up report, which concluded that there was no increase in emissions from the oilsands in 2009 compared to the previous year.

The independent review team, the Climate Change Working Group, looked at emissions related to the oilsands by using data supplied by Canada's industry.

"The report and others have been met with great skepticism by some in the industry, which says the new study doesn't have a clue about what they're talking about, that it's trying to manipulate a result to fit its own ideology," said Doug Taylor, director of the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers' Oil Sands

reference_text:
