Overview Edit

Like in the Floating Garden, the Underground Reservoir doesn't contain a boss, although a Big Golem can be encountered here. Many of the enemies here are water-borne. This area is the also the only place where the Sky Fish can be found.

In one of the rooms, Soma will witness Graham Jones stabbing Yoko with a dagger. Arikado arrives at the scene and sends Soma after Graham, while he stays to take care of Yoko.

Behind the big waterfall located in this stage, lies the entrance to the Forbidden Area. The trick to access it, is to equip Undine's soul (to be able to walk on the water's surface), and then equip and activate either the Curly's, Manticore's or Devil's

The Under Waterway of Memories is a subterranean cavern found by Skula's soul as part of the Underground Cemetery in Castle of Dreams, during the course of his journey back to the castle of his childhood. The Underground Reservoir (or Oreshika for short) is one of the many areas of the city where Dracula sleeps in his castle. It was home to many of the local inhabitants, including the vampire hunter, the vampire hunters, and a large population of monsters.

The underground is actually a hidden compartment of the castle that allows Dracula to maintain his powers during the daytime. It is here that he prepares his spells and other rituals to control others and use the power of his curse for his goals.

In the morning of December 24, 1936, Dracula, his servants, and his followers were attacked by a group of the village people who were searching for an undead creature that had escaped from their fort and attacked the hunters. The villagers killed the monster, however Dracula then summoned his own shadow to fight.

Description

The Underground Reservoir is a small dark cave in Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow that the protagonist, Vincent, must enter in order to reach the upper levels of the Sanctuary. It is said to be an entrance to a larger underground reservoir in the town of Silent Hill.

Contents show]

History

The Underground Reservoir is located in the middle of the town of Silent Hill. The entrance is located directly beneath the church and is guarded by two enemies, a red-dressed woman and a red-dressed man, as well as another two demons which stand guard outside the entrance on opposite sides. Once inside the underground reservoir, Vincent finds himself in a cavernous underground area in which he must fight a number of various enemies and obstacles until he reaches the upper level.

The concerns center on the extent of foreign investment in a series of finance entities Mnuchin helped manage, including one based offshore in the Cayman Islands, aides tell CNN.

It's an issue
reference_text:
-- which Democratic aides and lawmakers say hasn't been addressed in subsequent follow-up questions in the weeks since -- that has raised concern about the extent of the influence those investors may hold, and the potential for conflicts of interest not unlike what has tailed Trump throughout his campaign. On its face, it echoes a prime point of contention for Democrats probing all of Trump's Cabinet picks, many of whom boast extensive private business and finance ties.

But Mnuchin is slated to be the Trump Administration's top economic official, making those ties even more susceptible to potential conflicts, aides say -- the types of potential conflicts Mnuchin himself appeared to draw attention to inadvertently during his confirmation hearing.

The focus has trained on a series of finance entities, all offshoots of the hedge fund run by Mnuchin up until he was selected as Trump's pick to be the country's economic point person.

In the Treasury Department, Mnuchin oversees the Foreign Investment Review Board. The board is charged with scrutinizing foreign investments in U.S. companies.

The group reviews overseas investment for national security risks, and if a given company is operating in an area in which there's a high incidence of corruption or criminal behavior, Mnuchin needs to review whether the investment is in the national interest.

Mnuchin took a leave of absence from the Treasury Department in July after the Washington Post reported that he failed to disclose financial holdings that could potentially violate government ethics rules.

prefix_text:
Military forces were deployed Sunday to help thousands of displaced people in Malaysia's northern state of Penang, officials said, as floodwater rose from more than 24 hours of incessant rain.

At
reference_text:
least 2,000 people had been evacuated and 80 percent of the state was hit by typhoonlike winds and heavy rain, chief minister Lim Guan Eng said in a statement.

He said floodwater had risen to 3-4 meters (10-12 feet). Lim also warned in a Facebook post that more rain was expected and advised residents to stay at home.

Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi said the National Security Council was coordinating with police and the military to assist flood victims after a request for assistance from Penang.

Hundreds of trees were toppled and roads were submerged, leaving many areas practically paralyzed, Malaysian news agency Bernama reported. At least two people had been killed, it said.

"We remain fearful that there may still be untoward incidents because of the strong winds, the like of which have never been experienced before, and flash floods might recur," Lim told reporters in Penang, according to Bernama.

Hundreds of people

generated_result.0:
least 24 people have been reported dead and hundreds injured in torrential rain in southern Thailand over the weekend as the island of Phuket came to a standstill after almost three feet (one meter) of rain fell in a matter of hours.

Penang's emergency services said the number of people missing rose to 100, with 14 of them reported missing in Pertamina, about 70 kilometers (43 miles) from the city of Chiang Rai.

"We have a lot of people, and the floodwaters are rising. We are still trying to rescue them," said a military spokesman in Chiang Rai, where he was speaking on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to be quoted on the record.

There were conflicting reports as to whether the death toll had reached 100 or not.

A navy helicopter rescued six people from the flooding in Pertamina early on Sunday, while the government confirmed it had rescued six people after three people were killed.
generated_result.1:
least 25,000 are expected to be rescued as authorities deal with one of the world's biggest humanitarian crises.

People wait to hear whether they are rescued by rescuers or military, at the evacuation centre of the Kelantan state government in Penang, Malaysia, Saturday. (Dawid Radomichao/Associated Press)

Thousands of stranded people in the state have been sleeping on the roadside for days, fearful the floodwaters will overwhelm them.

Pemba, the police chief in the state, said more than 3,000 people had sought shelter Saturday at the four evacuation centres set up in the nearby villages of Bambu, Merah and Merikong.

Pemba said the authorities had reached out to the Red Cross and United Nations to assist with food and shelter. The Red Cross declined to confirm or deny reports it has distributed food and water.

The Red Cross' head of operations for Penang, Mohamad S
generated_result.2:
the center of the chaos, at an old pagoda-fortress known locally as Pangulipa, hundreds of people have sought shelter in one of the temples. Many were staying in shacks, others were sleeping in the parking lot, and a few were in boats.

"I'm so lost," said Pangulipa's Hindu Brahmin priest, who asked that only her first name be used. "My family can't take me."

Pangulipa, which was devastated by Typhoon Haiyan, is in a region prone to major floods, with some parts already showing more than 4 inches of rain over a six-day period.

About 2,000 people live in one of Penang's largest settlements. The floods and landslides are wreaking havoc on small villages scattered across the mountains and on the coastline.

The authorities said they evacuated about 5,000 people Saturday from the tiny village of Vang Pung.

reference_text:
Dublin restaurant, effective today.

The Montgomery Inn restaurant located at 4565 West Dublin-Granville Road in Dublin is closed for business effective January 2, 2017.

The Cincinnati-based restaurant chain opened the location in 2009.

In a statement, the Gregory family expressed their appreciation for the restaurant's loyal customers, "We want to thank the community of Dublin and the entire Columbus area for their loyalty and support. We have enjoyed serving you and we invite you to visit our other locations when traveling to the Cincinnati area."

Montgomery Inn gift cards will continue to be honored at all Cincinnati area locations. They also may be redeemed online at the restaurant's internet store, CincyFavorites.com. Or, if you prefer a refund, Montgomery Inn gift cards may be redeemed for cash at the Dublin restaurant only.

Refunds will be distributed Monday through Friday, between 9 am and 5 pm through the end of January. If you have any

prefix_text:
Modmail is the shared messaging system that moderators use to handle incoming requests from their users.

Enabling Modmail

Modmail is enabled by default for newly created subreddits. To enable it
reference_text:
for an existing subreddit, click the 'Enroll' button on the subreddit settings page.

Accessing Modmail

Modmail is accessed by clicking on the green shield icon in the user area in the header.

It can also be accessed directly by navigating to mod.reddit.com

Folders

Modmail is comprised of several folders:

All Mail

New

In Progress

Archived

Highlighted

Mod Discussions

Notifications

The location of a conversation is shared between moderators. For example, if you archive a conversation, it will appear in the archived folder for you and all the moderators of your subreddit.

All Mail

prefix_text: I had some issues getting MathJax running smoothly alongside Markdown. The main issue stemmed from Markdown not providing a way to temporarily escape from its text transformations, so some L A TEX would
reference_text:
get interpreted as Markdown.

The only way I know of to prevent text transformations in Markdown is through the code block (prefix with 4+ spaces) and inline code (surround with ` ) features. However, both of those wrap the result in some HTML tag ( <pre> for the first, <code> for the second). I decided to use the inline code feature as the basis for inserting my math.

I can insert math by typing, for example \`\\\( \\del \\cdot \\vec{B} = 0 \\\)\`. To make this work, I had to use the following MathJax configuration:

MathJax.Hub.Config({ tex2jax: { skipTags: ['script', 'noscript','style', 'textarea', 'pre'] } });

This prevents MathJax from skipping <code> tags. This could potentially cause issues if I used the sequences \\\

I don't know if this was a clerical oversight, or a deliberate move to avoid talking about the juror's conversation during the deliberations, or a misunderstanding about what the jury actually deliberated about. MINNEAPOLIS (AP) -- A federal court has overturned a U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service rule that said wolves can live with people who keep livestock.

The Federal Register today lifted an order by a U.S. District judge in June to halt the rule that was intended to prevent conflicts between wolves and livestock, pending a lawsuit.

The rule was part of a package of regulations in a National Wildlife Refuge System overhaul called the Endangered Species Act rulemaking process.

The Fish and Wildlife Service said the rule's repeal is consistent with the agency's statutory and regulatory authority to manage the national refuge system, as well as other wildlife management plans.

BOULDER, Colo. (AP) — The Obama administration is taking another crack at wolf reintroduction this spring, taking an important step to halt the widespread loss of a population in the Great Plains.

The Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday announced that it is considering rule changes to allow state and federal agencies to cull wolves in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan and Montana.

States and federal agencies have been allowed to kill wolves in Michigan since 2000 under a law passed by President George W. Bush. It gives agencies discretion in choosing which wolves to kill.

reference_text:
security. Every time I write an article or blog on wireless LAN security, someone has to come along and regurgitate one of these myths. If that weren't bad enough, many "so called" security experts propagated these myths through speaking engagements and publications and many continue to this day. Many wireless LAN equipment makers continue to recommend many of these schemes to this day. One would think that the fact that none of these schemes made it in to the official IEEE 802.11i security standard would give a clue to their effectiveness, but time and time again that theory is proven wrong. To help you avoid the these schemes, I've created the following list of the six dumbest ways to secure your wireless LAN.

Wireless LAN security hall of shame

MAC filtering: This is like handing a security guard a pad of paper with a list of names. Then when someone comes up to the door and wants entry, the security guard looks at the person's name tag and compares it

When I used to do this, my old router didn't run a wireless option, it ran "Wan". I would go to my home directory and run "wpa-config". If I thought someone was trying to get my Wi-Fi password, then I'd open the terminal and type "passwd -L wlan1". If I wanted to know the network name of the router, then I ran "netstat -anv wlan1". The next morning, I woke up in the middle of the night and realized that I hadn't changed the password, because it had been changed by someone else. A former intern working at Marvel Entertainment is suing the company for unpaid wages, a new report is claiming.

According to documents obtained by The Wrap, Kenneth Jackson claims he was "wrongfully" classified as an intern while working for Marvel from August through December 2008, and is now seeking minimum wage back pay.

Jackson has reportedly filed a class action lawsuit against Marvel Entertainment, LLC in the Supreme Court of the State of New York, seeking to "recover unpaid minimum wages owed." The recovered documents claim that all of Marvel's interns - "in excess of 100 individuals" - during the period were similarly owed.

The lawsuit says that "during his employment with Marvel, the Named Plaintiff worked from approximately 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. five days per week" in the second half of 2008.

The following year, Marvel was acquired by Disney for a cool $4.64 billion dollars.

The "Internship Program for New Employees," which was created by Microsoft in 2000, was designed to let new employees learn from the mistakes of seasoned engineers. But after a series of complaints from current employees, and with no specific evidence of wrongdoing by Microsoft employees, The New York Times reported that the program has been widely used to "cut the costs" of recruiting and firing.

The most famous case is that of Kevin Zeese, who worked as an intern at Microsoft. Zeese is asking the Times for $3 million in damages for the unfair dismissal and "pain and suffering" he suffered after Microsoft fired him for being unfaithful. He's now a lawyer.

prefix_text: If you thought the Raiders cutting Rolando McClain was good news, you're going to love this. As it turns out, according to Joel Corry of the National Football Post, there was language
reference_text:
in McClain's contract that voided all remaining guaranteed money should he be suspended for conduct.

This brings his dead money against the cap from its previously assumed figure of $10.895 million down to $7.26 million - just $585k more than his 2013 cap hit would have been had he remained on the roster.

Basically what this means is it the cost of cutting him is negligible compared to keeping him. But keeping him would have been far more costly to the team dynamic and you can't put a price on that. By Robert Mullin

CAISO last week provided an explanation of its decision to increase regulation requirements in response to the growing variability on its system.

The ISO's Department of Market Monitoring last
reference_text:
month called attention to the sharp rise in costs from the requirements, prompting the California Energy Commission to ask the ISO to justify the move. (See CAISO Regulation Costs Quadruple as Price, Procurement Jump.)

During a Market Performance and Planning Forum last week, CAISO said it doubled its frequency regulation service requirement from late February to mid-June in response to recurring short-term generation forecasting errors stemming from variable wind and solar resources during late winter and spring.

The forecasting problem is mostly isolated to spring, when high renewable output often coincides with periods of low loads in California. At the same time, weather patterns tend to be more erratic, often making it especially difficult to predict renewable output on a moment-to-moment basis.

The Problem of Panhandling

This guide addresses the problem of panhandling.† It also covers nearly
reference_text:
equivalent conduct in which, in exchange for donations, people perform nominal labor such as squeegeeing (cleaning) the windshields of cars stopped in traffic, holding car doors open, saving parking spaces, guarding parked cars, buying subway tokens, and carrying luggage or groceries.

The guide begins by describing the panhandling problem and reviewing factors that contribute to it. It then identifies a series of questions that might help you in analyzing your local problem. Finally, it reviews responses to the problem, and what is known about those responses from evaluative research and police practice.

Generally, there are two types of panhandling: passive and aggressive. Passive panhandling is soliciting without threat or menace, often without any words exchanged at all—just a cup or a hand held out. reference_text:
key research findings.

Augmented Reality's potential for Architecture is huge. "AR" is any system that overlays, or 'augments,' the real world with digital information that seemingly co-exists. Today's AR applications hint at a future to come: virtual furniture may be overlaid in real time to check its size and appearance in a room;'see-through' walls on a construction site allow builders to view pipes and mechanical ducting behind; and overlays of past and future buildings render the city a canvas for virtual data. As tech giants race to release wearable interfaces for ever greater augmentation of the physical world, the number of worldwide users consuming AR via portable media devices is expected to exceed 1 billion users by 2020.

It's Getting Better All The Time

We've all been expecting a techno dystopia, a world shattered by climate change and deadened by social media. But what if the reverse is true?
reference_text:
2833 views

Copy and paste the embed code on your website, blog post or article. Make sure Javascript is enabled.

Journalism New York, New York 50,000 words 75% complete 2 publishers interested View publishers

I'm John Biggs and I've been a professional cynic for the past decade. I saw where technology was headed and I was upset, not amazed. But something is changing and I want to tell you about it.

"Yearly reminder: unless you're over 60, you weren't promised flying cars. You were promised an oppressive cyberpunk dystopia. Here you go," wrote Kyle Marquis in February 2015. For most of my life Marquis' words rang true. I saw the future as a slide into darkness, all Blade Runner and dirty bombs. But we are living in an era of unprecedented access to information and increasingly improved access to the resources needed to build a better world. All is not peaches and cream

generated_result.0:
Could we have this much more peaceful planet and future? As we go to print, the idea seems absurd, but we have to face it. Our children, our grandchildren, the children of the present and the past are going to be living in less violent societies for thousands of years. As such, as much as we will strive for a technologically improved planet, we are going to be creating an increasingly peaceful planet, where technology and technology's ability to provide a new and improved life will not be a factor.

In his book, The Great Transformation, journalist Mark LeVine argues that this is going to happen. He suggests that the future will be a kind of Golden Age, where technology will be used for things that do not create problems for the human race in the long run. generated_result.1:

The players were not randomly chosen, but rather randomly selected participants in order to make sure that they were as similar as possible.

prefix_text: The TTIP trade treaty talks re-open in Brussels this week. We should not be reassured by the convenient 'leak' of a private letter between key TTIP advocates claiming the treaty poses no
reference_text:
threat to the NHS.

NoTTIP Day of Action on July 12. Rachel Megawhat / Demotix. All rights reserved.

The NHS has become a key battleground for the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), the controversial treaty currently being negotiated in secret between the European Commission and the US government.

Now that more and more people are becoming aware of the threat that TTIP poses to public services, the European Commission and its friends have found a new and inventive way of trying to bamboozle people into accepting it.

On the eve of the sixth round of talks, which begin in Brussels this week, a 'private' letter from the EU's chief negotiator, Ignacio Garcia Bercero, to John Healey MP was conveniently leaked to the Guardian and Financial Times. The letter attempts to downplay the fact that public health services are included in TTIP, suggesting that there is no need to fear for the NHS as a result

generated_result.0:
threat to human health. The letter was actually written just before a debate on TTIP, but it was leaked to the press to cause maximum anxiety – and we see nothing to worry about.

On one side, we have the pro-trade, pro-EU camp, which argues that trade agreements must be good for the environment. On the other side, we have the anti-trade, anti-EU camp, which claims that it's the EU's responsibility to prevent 'intrusive regulation' such as TTIP. They say we have to accept some 'legacy laws' such as those on cigarette packaging, labelling, food additives, as well as food inspections, which they call'regulatory dumping' (that is, the EU taking away the industry's market to make the EU appear to be more restrictive than it actually is). The 'legacy laws' that they want us to accept involve so much law-making that they can destroy the European public health system.

Nowotny forwarded this letter to the European Commission and the European Parliament's trade committee, asking them to take up the matter. He was assured that they would do so "soon".

"Magic mushrooms," the recreational hallucinogen long associated with music festivals and hippies, may also one day prove to have a powerful pharmaceutical effect for people with treatment-resistant depression.

In
reference_text:
a small pilot study at the Center for Neuropsychopharmacology at Imperial College London, more than half of participants who took psilocybin, the active compound in psychedelic mushrooms, showed a marked improvement in their depression symptoms while also demonstrating the compound's safety in a supervised setting.

This is the first clinical trial to use the active chemical compound in so-called "magic mushrooms" to treat major depression. If the findings are confirmed in larger studies, it could mean a change in the way we treat depression symptoms in those who don't respond to therapy and traditional medications, like selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors.

What we knew before:

Mushrooms from the genus Psilocybe contain psilocybin, which the human body breaks down into a substance called psilocin. This psychedelic substance then crosses the blood-brain barrier and binds to a specific serotonin receptor known as 5-HT2A, creating a profound alteration of consciousness that has been described

generated_result.0:
a new study, researchers at the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) analyzed the relationship between the frequency and duration of the use of certain mushroom species and antidepressant symptoms among 5,000 individuals. The results were surprising.

While most people who have never used a hallucinogen have experienced no significant effects, those who use at least a few times per month report increased mood, increased energy, and reductions in depression compared to those who do not use hallucinogens. For people who report using mushrooms at least weekly, the results are even more significant: The duration of use was associated with less depression symptoms.

"These results are not unexpected," said co-author Jennifer L. Kuk, MD, of NIDA and the Department of Psychiatry, Harvard Medical School. "Recent research shows that many of the chemical compounds in hallucinogenic mushrooms are antidepressant-like. Some of them have even shown promise for depression prevention."

The current study is the first to describe th

a paper published this week in PLOS ONE, researchers at the Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard University report that the combination of psilocybin and a different psychedelic, LSD, helped some patients cope with their depression for one month.

Researchers at the Harvard Medical School tested 26 patients suffering from major depressive disorder for two weeks after a month spent taking the hallucinogen psilocybin, or "magic mushroom," either alone or with LSD. The participants, all from the United States and Canada, reported a decreased level of sadness after the psilocybin session, the study found.

"Psilocybin has been shown to be very effective as a treatment for depression," Daniel J. Mithoefer, who headed the research team at the MGH, told LiveScience. "It is also potentially very useful as a treatment for depression-related nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea. So it's very promising."

But while some previous studies have found psilocy

A study of the effects of psilocybin in people with treatment-resistant depression found that the drug may help to prevent the onset of episodes of anxiety, depression and suicidal thoughts.

"A treatment protocol based upon current recommendations for the use of psilocybin has been described previously. Our preliminary study suggests that it might be a useful drug for the treatment of patients with treatment-resistant depression," said lead author John Krystal, a clinical professor of psychiatry at the Bloomberg School. They were joined by more than 100 other staff members and vendors from the last thirty years of the company — including the owners and operators of nearly 30 businesses, as well as a full service restaurant for both live events and private parties. prefix_text: PORTLAND, Ore. – A man from South Korea has a dream to cycle from Canada to Argentina on a solo trip. But his dream has been cut short by a thief in Portland.
reference_text:
Minhyeong Kim's black-and-red Scott Sub 40 and the racks on the front and back holding his possessions were stolen last Friday night.

Kim parked his bike and locked it up outside the Fred Meyer store on Southeast Cesar Chavez Boulevard and Hawthorne Boulevard last Friday night. He went in to to buy some food and the bike was gone when got back outside 20 minutes later.

The bike and almost all his gear, from a tent to a laptop, had vanished. He said it was his entire life, his home on wheels.

Kim is a young man who spent the past two years saving and planning, to fly from South Korea to Edmonton, Canada, and then to ride his bicycle all the way down to Argentina. He had made it 1,500 miles in 35 days. But his trip was stopped in Portland.

Kim said he loves Portland, but what happened hurt him, and he wants the thief to know that.

prefix_text: In these days of anxiety and alienation, Thanksgiving offers the warm embrace of inclusiveness. Particularly for many people with families and faiths rooted in other lands, no other holiday, not even the Fourth of
reference_text:
July, has so great a capacity to make them feel American.

A child of Orthodox Jewish immigrants could feel his apartness on other festivals celebrated by the larger society. Christmas, Easter, Halloween — all are distinctly Christian observances, no matter how temporal and commercialized they have become. They are inevitable reminders for some Americans that they are different.

Thanksgiving's origins are also Christian. But it has evolved into something both secular and spiritual, a day devoted to family and amity. Perhaps that explains its unwavering appeal for believers and nonbelievers alike (even if many Native Americans understandably choose not to partake). Thanksgiving is at heart more than parades, or football or even country; there's no flag-waving or chest-thumping. It is about shared bounty and shared humanity.

That's why the writer Saadia Faruqi, a Pakistan-born Muslim, welcomes the day. "For a Pakistani-American, Thanksgiving is as wholesome and

generated_result.0:
July, can seem like such a gift from above.

As American Indians, we are privileged to enjoy the freedom to choose which holidays to celebrate as we choose our own traditions. It is not enough to make a commitment to be here for one season or another. We must not simply choose to live our culture. We must celebrate our traditions. When the holidays come around, we must choose to make them into something better.

There is much we can learn from our ancestors' stories about holidays that they and we celebrate today. They, too, lived in an era when the winter solstice was a time of celebration and renewal and when the winter solstice was observed to recognize the seasonal changes in the seasons.
generated_result.1:
July or Veterans Day, brings them out of their homes and homesickness to celebrate the American Dream. These holidays are special occasions for them, but they are also occasions when they bring out the family members who have never had that same sort of event before.

Here are 14 ways to celebrate Thanksgiving as part of the American family.

1. Give a small, warm dinner in your home and a few thoughtful gifts for everyone who comes over.

Here's the deal: The more you celebrate Thanksgiving this year, the more you're going to appreciate your time with loved ones. Consider giving a small, warm dinner in your home. For most families, this means preparing three small meals for two and sharing them with each guest. It doesn't have to be fancy. Just bring something like roasted potatoes or mashed sweet potatoes, or turkey or mashed corn. Or you could make a light meal out of whatever you can think of, from mashed potatoes and vegetables to fruit and yogurt.
generated_result.2:
July, represents as much as a sacred space to share family and faith in a meaningful way. And it's easy for those who live elsewhere to have a hard time understanding these differences in a culture that often lacks the words to describe it all.

For many people, this holiday has become one of the few times a year where the holiday is even remotely sacred. Some people consider Thanksgiving a holiday of fasting and devotion, and even those who consider themselves spiritual have a profound connection to the holiday. For a while, it seemed as though the entire tradition might collapse altogether, but the year 2016 has seen a resurgence. There are many churches and groups that still celebrate Thanksgiving—or, at least, celebrate it on some form of occasion—while others have made efforts to reach out to a broader audience—both those of us who have come to think of this holiday as a secular holiday, and those who have come to think of it as a spiritual holiday.

prefix_text: Just when I thought we'd have a long weekend without a big news dump, the WaPo published its story revealing Jared Kushner asked Sergey Kislyak to set up a channel of communication with Russia at Russian facilities
reference_text:

Jared Kushner and Russia's ambassador to Washington discussed the possibility of setting up a secret and secure communications channel between Trump's transition team and the Kremlin, using Russian diplomatic facilities in an apparent move to shield their pre-inauguration discussions from monitoring, according to U.S. officials briefed on intelligence reports. Ambassador Sergei Kislyak reported to his superiors in Moscow that Kushner, then President-elect Trump's son-in-law and confidant, made the proposal during a meeting on Dec. 1 or 2 at Trump Tower, according to intercepts of Russian communications that were reviewed by U.S. officials. Kislyak said Kushner suggested using Russian diplomatic facilities in the United States for the communications. The meeting also was attended by Michael Flynn, Trump's first national security adviser.

prefix_text: LONDON (Reuters) - At least 3 million barrels of Iraqi Kurdish oil are on ships heading to Asia, with trade sources naming China as a possible destination as the autonomous region expands efforts to establish independent
reference_text:
oil sales in defiance of Baghdad.

A flame rises from a chimney at Taq Taq oil field in Arbil, in Iraq's Kurdistan region, August 16, 2014. REUTERS/Azad Lashkari

Two sources with knowledge of the matter said Iraqi Kurdistan was in talks to potentially supply China with 4 million barrels of oil.

Reuters was unable to identify the Chinese parties involved in the talks, which the sources declined to name, and it was not clear if the cargoes currently on the water were part of the discussions.

A deal could place Beijing on a collision course with Baghdad, one of its major crude oil suppliers, which has tried to block the Kurdish sales that it says are illegal. The Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) argues they are allowed under the Iraqi constitution.

"The Kurds are in the process of negotiations with the Chinese," said one of the sources, who asked not to be identified due to the sensitivity of the matter

The oil-and-gas company PetroChina is believed to be looking to tap the Kurdistan Region's oil wealth in the face of a government plan to shut the pipeline that leads to China to pay for an independence referendum it is holding in a largely Kurdish-populated region.

Talks are also continuing with other oil majors including Russia and the United States to set up a trade hub in the Iraqi Kurdistan autonomous region, which has strong links to China.

"This is the only way to get our oil to Asia," said a representative of a large oil industry company operating in the Kurdistan region of western Iraq.

The Kurdistan Region's oil production surged to more than 3 million barrels per day in June, up 30 percent from

People cross an oil-related road on the outskirts of the Kurdish capital Erbil June 12, 2014. REUTERS/Azad Lashkari

The shipping sources also named China as the biggest buyer of Iraqi Kurdish oil, accounting for a quarter of exports worth about $100 million in December.

China had made a tentative offer to sell oil at a low price to Iraq - which has struggled with high prices for a decade - but the Iraqi government had declined to accept it, according to the shipping sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Iraq could be looking to bolster its oil exports to China through the oil export pipeline and on tanker routes through the Persian Gulf after sanctions on Tehran were lifted on Jan. 1.

But with no pipeline under its territorial waters and heavy local oil transport costs, the region relies heavily on its regional neighbours to supply it.

China has long been a major supplier to Iraq, which is seeking to diversify away from the dependence of Iraq's OPEC exporter on Iran, but China is also expanding oil exports to Iraq on its own and its efforts are likely to be aided by Iraq's increasing regional power.

prefix_text: As a human species we tend to have an explosive curiosity for the world around us. I feel it is what makes us unique, and probably is what makes humans the dominant species. I was in the
reference_text:
store the other day and I overheard someone else's child making the inquiring "why" repeatedly. I have to admit I often ask the question why in my own life, it's what drove me to study science. However, it's the obsession with the "why" that also causes us to sometimes think irrationally. There are absolute truths in the universe, but what makes something true? Often times we have our minds set so much on the "why" that we miss the entire "what" and "how". I feel the one absolute truth (no matter what you believe) is that we have no idea what absolute truth and knowledge is.
                I have always studied science to get answers to why things are the way they are. It wasn't until my last year of undergraduate that I realized that science doesn't have the answer why (I know that took a long time, but I always thought I just needed to learn more). That caused a deep sense of depression

generated_result.0:
world of the ancient Greeks, where even a single person could be an expert on multiple fields in a day. It was an exciting time.

I also see that as a human species, we tend to try to do things with a focus on what we know best, and how that works. I am a huge fan of the movie Frozen, in fact I still have the album Frozen (I own both the digital and vinyl versions). I think it is the most gorgeous film ever made, a breathtaking example of one of the most elegant forms of animation. I know that most people see Frozen and instantly feel the same kind of wonder for what happened in it, and I try to explain this to my kids from the time they are six years old. It is in that sense that Disney seems to create characters, worlds and story lines that make the world around us real. This works perfectly for our human nature.

I'm sure your son will be in school now, I think his school

prefix_text: Doug Schoen, a former consultant to Bill Clinton, argued the case that the Democrats should keep their ties to Wall Street in a NYT column this morning. While he does advance his argument with some red
reference_text:
-baiting and bad logic, he uses tradition as a starting point.

"Many of the most prominent voices in the Democratic Party, led by Bernie Sanders, are advocating wealth redistribution through higher taxes and Medicare for all, and demonizing banks and Wall Street.


"Memories in politics are short, but those policies are vastly different from the program of the party's traditional center-left coalition. Under Bill Clinton, that coalition balanced the budget, acknowledged the limits of government and protected the essential programs that make up the social safety net.


"President Clinton did this, in part, by moving the party away from a reflexive anti-Wall Street posture. It's not popular to say so today, but there are still compelling reasons Democrats should strengthen ties to Wall Street."

Donnie Wahlberg is showing some love for Waffle House … again.

The 47-year-old Blue Bloods star and New Kids on the Block singer made a stop at the
reference_text:
popular chain restaurant in Charlotte, North Carolina late on Wednesday night — where he rewarded the staff with a $2,000 tip as well as front row tickets and backstage passes to his band's Total Package Tour.

"My mom waited tables, and my dad tended bars– for years!" Wahlberg wrote on Instagram, captioning a photo of his $82.60 check and the Waffle House staff. "So, when I walk into a #WaffleHouse, and the staff treats me like a king, you better believe I treat them like queens! Thanks to the team at @wafflehouseofficial Charlotte, NC!"


This isn't the first time Wahlberg has shown his generosity for Waffle House employees. In late June, Wahlberg stopped in for a meal at the restaurant in Edgewood, Maryland and left the overnight staff a $500 tip — tweeting a photo with Waffle House staffers Tyler Spangler and Angi Silen, whom he

generated_result.0:

The star said the restaurant is great.

"They always give me the time of day and a smile," he said.

Fitness fanatics should reach for the mustard and NOT spinach if they want to look like Popeye


Fitness fanatics looking to build muscle should consider reaching for the mustard, a study has
reference_text:
found.


The steroid homobrassinolide, found in the mustard plant, increases muscle mass, the size of muscle fibres and appetite, research suggests.


In addition, the effect when tested on rats was similar to anabolic steroids, which promote the growth of muscle and which are used illegally by athletes to improve performance.


Spinach is out, and mustard is in as one way to build your muscle strength, according to a new study


A team of scientists exposed rat muscle cells to different amounts of homobrassinolide and measured protein synthesis – the process in which cells build proteins – in cell culture. The result was increased production – vital for building muscles – and decreased breakdown of protein in the cells.

Researcher Dr Slavo Komarnytsky, at North Carolina State University, said: 'We hope that one day brassinosteroids may provide an effective, natural, and safe alternative for age and disease-associated muscle

generated_result.0:
shown. The more protein they consume, the more muscle they can build.


Strictly following a diet high in protein is the first step in building muscle. The second step is to use the correct training methods.


Scientists at the University of Connecticut's School of Medicine took samples of muscle and liver from athletes to examine protein and exercise.


They discovered that the more protein that they ingested, the more muscle they built.


'In this study we showed that protein intake was an important determinant of muscle growth in humans,' said Professor David Burd, director of the Center for Sport and Exercise Science at the University of Connecticut School of Medicine.


'While previous studies have suggested that protein intake may be an important determinant of muscle size, the results here were the first direct evidence that protein intake is an important determinant of strength and size in humans.


'When it comes to building and maintaining muscle mass, protein is not the only determinant,
generated_result.1:
revealed.


Researchers have found that men with high strength training scores in the general population have a lower risk of death than the general population in that same study, which was done in the Netherlands.


'We found that those participants with higher muscle strength reported greater body fat, less fat mass, lower resting metabolic rate and higher body fat percentage during exercise,' explained lead author of the study, Prof. Peter van den Broek of the Institute for Applied Sport Sciences at the University of Groningen in The Netherlands.

'Strength training increased testosterone levels, and testosterone plays a key role in muscle mass.'


Strength training, the study found, could boost testosterone and improve health.

The research team found that the general population had a higher risk of death from heart disease compared with elite athletes.


'Our study showed a lower risk of death among those in the general population with higher muscle strength in the general population compared to elite athletes.'

generated_result.2:

It's good news for those who are trying to build muscle, and who are often hampered by the thought of going for the kale and kale chips, in particular.


The researchers at the University of Leeds were interested in whether the body's natural reaction to eating certain foods is changed when a person eats more of those foods. The researchers were looking for evidence that eating more of a particular food, with the expectation that the body would naturally adapt, would lead to fat gaining.

The United States' plans to beef up its missile defenses against North Korea are likely to inflame tensions that are running high over Pyongyang's nuclear program, China said Monday.

"Bolstering missile defenses will only intensify antagonism, and it doesn't help to solve the issue," Hong Lei, a spokesman for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said at a regular news briefing in Beijing.

The United States will deploy additional ground-based missile interceptors on the West Coast as part of efforts to enhance the nation's ability to defend itself from attack by North Korea, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel announced Friday.

The U.S. announcement came after North Korea recently threatened a pre-emptive nuclear attack on South Korea and the United States in response to stepped-up U.N. Security Council sanctions over its latest nuclear test last month.

prefix_text: Roman Polak didn't want his teammates to visit. The big scowling Czech defenceman was lying in a hospital bed, drifting in the fog delivered by his post-surgery painkillers.
reference_text:
He is pretty sure he didn't have a TV, but he had a laptop... yes, he definitely had a laptop. When asked about those five or six days, he can't remember much of what he did. But he remembers that he didn't want his teammates to see him like that. That stuck.

It's been a long, slow, painful recovery for Leaf blueliner Roman Polak. ( Graig Abel / Getty Images )

"They had a tough schedule, and I didn't want them to see me, there," says Polak now, five months after 13 screws were installed to repair the broken leg he suffered in Game 2 of the Toronto Maple Leafs' first-round series against Washington. "I'd rather stay by myself. I don't know. I didn't feel good after the surgery, and it was painful, and I didn't want anybody to see me as I'm laying there in the bed, you know, struggling. I don

generated_result.0:
"I just wanted to see the world, to see things and relax," Polak, who is the league's third leading shot blocker with 32, said last month.

The Flyers' team doctor was trying to keep the centre down for as long as possible. Even before his injury, Polak's face was swollen with pain.

"He was thinking, 'How am I going to play with all these painkillers?'" said Flyers coach Dave Hakstol. "And he decided to try to slow him down."

At home, Polak could make a living eating chocolate-chip pancakes, a dish he grew up with his father, Poul, and grandfather, Jose. And then, one day, when the pain in his face became unbearable, his mother, Yvonne, had to ask him if he wanted to take an epidural, a spinal tube.

The drug allowed Polak to do something he'd had difficulty doing his entire career
generated_result.1:
He had a large cyst in his left shoulder blade. It was his second operation, a fifth when he was 12 and an eighth when he was 13. The doctor told Polak that the cyst would need to be removed, but Polak had another option: he could try to return to the ice and try again in 12 weeks. If that happened, he'd play again.

Story continues below advertisement

Story continues below advertisement

Polak was 16 in October, and it was the first time he'd thought about hockey again. "I always wanted to play again," he says.

Polak, who lives in the Czech Republic, was one of several children who fled the Soviet Union with the rest of the family when he was a toddler. He went to the former communist state in the 1980s. There, he met his wife, who was studying psychology. There, he learned to skate, a sport he began playing with his father. Later, they
generated_result.2:
He had fought off two separate MRIs and another MRIs to fight off a recurrence of his cancer. He was told he was lucky to have made it through the first stage – a procedure that could easily have ended his football career.

Polak is just 29 but had already begun playing the game he loves when he underwent his surgery in November, 2014. His playing career had been in limbo since the 2014 World Cup, when he was dropped by Chelsea and subsequently signed by Dynamo Zagreb but was then released. When Polak returned to Czech Republic from Germany, the club had decided to cut him loose and have him sign with another team, which was what made the news that Polak was in a hospital bed in Austria.

Polak's wife, Anna, was in London on holiday and contacted me to let me know about his situation. I reached out to the Czech Republic football federation, and they were keen to help but Polak was an unwilling participant in the process

Sprite Ordering

Normally in a 2D game there is no concept of depth, so if you simply place the sprites in the world, you'll most likely have objects appearing in the wrong order than what you'd expect in an isometric game.

Thankfully Unity exposes Sorting Layer and Order In Layer properties for Renderers.

A quick fix is to set the value of Order in Layer to depend on the Y position of the object.

reference_text:

"The cause of tree death, called yellow-cedar decline, is now known to be a form of root freezing that occurs during cold weather in late winter and early spring, but only when snow is not present on the ground," explains Pacific Northwest Research Station scientist Paul Hennon, co-lead of a synthesis paper recently published in the February issue of the journal BioScience. "When present, snow protects the fine, shallow roots from extreme soil temperatures. The shallow rooting of yellow-cedar, early spring growth, and its unique vulnerability to freezing injury also contribute to this problem."

Kudzu and the California Marriage Amendment

by Rick Moen

August 25, 2008

(last updated August 6, 2018)

This past century, large portions of the
reference_text:
American South have been consumed by an unintended side-effect.

I refer to the infamous "kudzu" vine, imported from Japan for its stunning erosion-control properties. This tactic worked: Crumbling riverbanks and hillsides were stabilized all over the South — but, then, everyone realized with mounting horror that this hardy legume is almost completely unstoppable anywhere protected from hard freezes, growing at the awesome rate of a foot per night and reaching heights of 100 feet. Entire abandoned houses have been observed to vanish under a kudzu carpet, over a summer growing season. It's now considered a pest; sometimes, an outright menace.

The plant can be used with caution, where its invasive side-effect is known and planned for — but the point is that it was deployed without understanding its full effects.

Which Spanish language paper should I enrol in?

The appropriate entry point for Spanish language papers depends on your current level of Spanish. Each enrolment is ultimately at the discretion of the Spanish Programme,
reference_text:
but the following broad guidelines apply.


Students who have never studied Spanish or whose experience of Spanish is minimal and dates from many years ago, or who have only completed one year at high school, should enrol for SPAN131. This paper is designed for complete beginners.


Students who have studied Spanish for two or three years at high school in the relatively recent past, or have completed SPAN131, should enrol for SPAN132.

For students who have completed four to five years at high school, or who have NCEA Level 2 or 3 in Spanish, or an equivalent qualification, SPAN231 or SPAN232 might be the appropriate paper to enrol for. This paper reviews and consolidates the major grammar points from NCEA Levels 2 and 3.

Spanish language papers at university, school, college and vocational training are usually issued by the University Council or the Faculty of Education and are designed to provide an overview of how Spanish may be used in daily life in Spain. They may be printed, hand-printed or electronic.

The university and college papers are usually issued by the Spanish Agency for Higher Education (PECAS) or the Faculty of Applied Science, Technology and Management (FECTM) but may also be hand-written or produced by a third party. All of these papers require a pass/fail grading of 85% or higher. This pass/fail grading system is based on performance, the difficulty and complexity of the subject or the difficulty of the language used.

All of these papers should be used in tandem with a full-length academic course. Spanish papers are useful for studying courses such as English, Spanish, and Spanish and Spanish language courses a

to get a handle on what the heck this Bitcoin thing is. The tech behind Bitcoin is so cool I personally get almost apoplectic when I think about it. It can be used not only for money, but for the transfer of anything that conveys ownership of property. However, this is the primary reason Bitcoin is failing. Techno-geeks tend to get wrapped up in the technology -- not the conceptual potential -- and end up talking about topics only a small group of people (other techno-geeks) can understand.

To help better explain what Bitcoin actually is, take a $20 dollar bill (or any other amount) out of your wallet and look at it. What is it worth? "Well, $20 dollars of course," is most likely the usual indignant reply. But what does $20 dollars mean? Where does it come from? to learn the word 'Bitcoin' and its derivation. It is pronounced as BUM-buh-NEE-gus [BUM-buh-nee-gus] or BUM-buh-nee-gus. That is the origin of Bitcoin. There are two variants of the word, with the "Gus" form being more common.

Bitcoin is a decentralized online currency, with no central authority. It was created in 2009 as a payment system for the use of computers in computers. These computers could be connected to form a computer network, which could then connect to other computers around the world. So when someone receives a Bitcoin, or Bitcoin money, it is just like sending money from the computer or the Internet to an individual person or institution. The Bitcoin computer network acts as a payment system, and the computers (and anyone else connected to that computer or to the Internet) are connected together so that all transactions are recorded and monitored.

Why would you want to get into Bitcoin if you are not planning on storing your money in the Bitcoin network?

Bitcoin is a way for people to store their money using their computer or smartphone, and to spend their money with little or no fees or restrictions.

The main advantage of Bitcoin is the ease of transfer – to anyone on the planet.

The Bitcoin network offers the widest variety of payment methods, including most countries and the world financial services.

In order to spend money that you've stored in a Bitcoin wallet, you need a Bitcoin wallet.

Wallet is just a word used to describe the Bitcoin software program that provides access to digital wallet.

So, let's have a look at the most frequently used Bitcoin wallets to see which ones are recommended by people.

in Michigan increased from $5.15 an hour to $6.95 an hour. That year, the number of people on food stamps increased from 1.1 million to 1.2 million. In 2008, the minimum wage increased again from $6.95 an hour to $7.15. Again, the number of food stamp recipients went up from 1.2 million to 1.26 million.

Yet, the left-leaning Center for American Progress recently released a report that claimed raising the minimum wage to $10.10 would get at least 110,000 families in Michigan off food stamps. President Obama and political allies are pushing for the higher mandated wage. The Center for American Progress has strong ties to the Clinton and Obama administrations. Playboy magazine is putting the clothes back on.

Executives for the magazine's parent company revealed that the publication will no longer publish fully nude photos of women as part of an upcoming redesign
reference_text:
in a piece published Monday by the New York Times.

The change will take effect in March 2016.

According to the Times, Playboy editor Cory Jones approached magazine founder Hugh Hefner last month with the idea to drop nude photos from the print edition. Hefner, who is still listed on the masthead as editor in chief, gave the idea his blessing.

Polymorphism is about one thing behaving multiple ways. So, generics/templates are a "polymorphic" feature in so far as they allow a single piece of code to vary its behavior with types. In-fact, this type of polymorphism is really the best behaved and is generally referred to as parametric polymorphism because the variation is defined by a parameter.

Many languages provide a form of polymorphism called "overloading" or ad hoc polymorphism where multiple procedures with the same name are defined in an ad hoc manner, and where one is chosen by the language (perhaps the most specific). There are so many areas of conventional democratic governance being challenged or eliminated by the Stephen Harper wrecking crew it is hard to keep up. Those searching for a line in the sand that even
reference_text:
this government won't cross still haven't found it. So far, it seems, there is nothing (save the military and prisons) that is sacrosanct.

Minimally, all governments take seriously the protection of their citizens; otherwise there is scarcely any point in having one. Yet recent reports reveal that that the Harper government has virtually eliminated monitoring of the ozone layer over Canada. The government has shut down four of five very sophisticated monitoring stations leaving only a single station – at UBC in Vancouver – still gathering information about this critical aspect of our environment.

In doing so, Canada is once again demonstrating that it is becoming a rogue state. It has already established this reputation by walking away from its Kyoto commitments. The monitoring of the ozone layer – which protects the earth from harmful radiation – is an international task requiring the co-operation of many countries. In any democratic society the rules set by the democratic community should apply equally to all participants; that is how they are supposed to work. This includes the rule of law, which means there should be equal and public access to the law — including the rights of whistleblowers. The courts, which are supposed to provide a check on arbitrary powers, must also be accessible and accountable to the same general public, which is the very purpose of our judicial system, which means equal access to the court system.

They are not in the business of changing things. At worst, Harper's leadership style is a good example of a successful leadership style. It is a great example of how the democratic process works. reference_text: Steve Christie (Peter Brouwer) re-opens Camp Crystal Lake after many years during which it has been cursed by murders and bad luck. The young and nubile counselors all begin to die extremely bloody deaths at the hands of an unseen killer during a rainstorm which isolates the camp. A woman is chopped in the face with an axe, another has her throat sliced in amazingly gruesome fashion, a male counselor (Harry Crosby) is pinned to a door with arrows, and a young Kevin Bacon has an arrow shoved through his throat from below a bed. Victor Miller's script is not particularly impressive, but Cunningham's tense direction, and some remarkable special-effects by acclaimed makeup artist Tom Savini are enough to make it worthwhile. 1950s quiz show regular Betsy Palmer appears as the cook whose son, Jason (Ari Lehman), drowned 25 years earlier while neglected by romancing counselors. reference_text:
went airborne hitting two other vehicles. Many first responders called it one of the "worst" crashes they'd ever seen.

The crash occurred around 9:35 a.m. near Exit 68 on the LIE, and the Suffolk County police said that Carmelo Pinales, 26, was driving east in the Subaru Outback that barreled into the westbound lanes, hitting a Honda and a BMW. Suffolk County Chief of Detectives Gerard Gigante said, "It looks like the Outback went airborne, hit the top of the Honda — the Honda doesn't have front-end damage, but has significant roof damage. And it appears the BMW and the Outback collided. The engine of the Outback was thrown several hundred feet into the woods. The car is pretty much destroyed. It's broken up into numerous pieces."

Has Dyson's robotic dream become a reality?

Has Dyson finally cracked its 16-year mission to create a robot vacuum cleaner? The company's teaser video hints at a new release which
reference_text:
looks a lot like a rival for the best-selling Roomba, and perfectly illustrates how fast the conditions necessary to create viable robotic products are evolving.

Dyson's mysterious video, posted on YouTube (below), heralds a 4 September release. The only piece of information to accompany it reads: '16 years. 200 engineers. £28 million investment. The result? Tell us what you think it is.'

The device moves around a bit and zooms in and out—interesting, but not as interesting as the glimpse of what looks like its location-analysis technology. It hints at a number of other interesting features too.

What's certain is that, with one of the best-known brand names around, Dyson has done its research before going public in a market as hot as robotics is right now.

Earlier this year, the company invested £5m in a lab at Imperial College London designed to help robots 'understand and adapt to the world

But when you watch the teaser for the first time you can't help but be impressed with the engineering of the machine.

The teaser shows a cleanroom in which workers are working away at a machine which looks impressive in motion.

It even features a robotic arm which pulls the vacuum cleaner up by the handle, rather than the standard hand operated method used for manual vacuums. The hand operated operation is particularly noticeable as it helps the machine to move smoothly.

Another thing which is notable is the fact that the machine has no moving parts and uses a complex and intricate set of controls to move the system.

In the final stages of the production of the Dyson vacuum cleaner will the workers be able to look inside the machine to check on the working process of the vacuum cleaner.

He's raising a lot of money for his campaign, mostly through small online donations. On social media people engage with Sanders' posts more than any other candidate. India, in a dossier, had cited the nine addresses as those frequented by Dawood. However, after verification, the six addresses provided by India have not been amended as they have been found to be correct.

Out of the three addresses, one that has been dropped as the UN Security Council's Al Qaeda Sanctions Committee found it similar to that of a residence of Islamabad's envoy to the UN Maleeha Lodhi.

The Security Council's ISIL and Al-Qaida Sanctions Committee amended its entry on Monday concerning Dawood, the mastermind behind the 1993 Mumbai serial blasts, with "underline and strikethrough".

The US embargo turned 50 years old this
reference_text:
week. It probably won't surprise most folks to learn that the night before President John F. Kennedy signed a total US embargo of Cuba into force, he asked an aide to buy 1,000 Cuban cigars (just to be safe, the aide got 1,200).

Surely Kennedy would have been shocked to learn that his massive stockpile would run out long before his embargo would; just days before his assassination, Kennedy had approved a secret meeting to take place in Havana between a senior US diplomat and Castro. But the meeting never took place, and Kennedy's embargo has remained a fixture now for half a century. Over at the Daily Mail, Lee Moran offers perspective on this week's milestone:

"When the embargo began, American teenagers were doing The Twist, the US had yet to put a man into orbit around the Earth and a first-class US postage stamp cost just 4 cents."

How is it that 10 presidents and a Cold War ago, the United States cut off

generated_result.0:
year, and the embargo continues to be a strong and powerful force in the global affairs of the world. It has had a profound impact on the United States, both in its own affairs, and in the policies of other countries. For the first half of the 20th century, the US economy continued to grow and create more jobs than any other nation on the planet, although it also experienced inflation and huge unemployment. It was also a very stable and powerful power in the world.

While it continued to have many positive characteristics over the past 50 years or so, the world has changed dramatically since the late 1950s. Not only has the US economy become the most unequal in history, the US is now the greatest threat to global peace and global security, and many other issues in the world have deteriorated. The US has become economically, politically, militarily, and militarily entangled in many of the biggest global problems of our time: nuclear weapons, climate change, terrorism, nuclear proliferation, th
generated_result.1:
week, and it doesn't look like the nation's health care system is in any immediate danger, at least for the immediate future.

According to the World Health Organization's Global Status Report, "there were no new outbreaks of communicable diseases in 2011 and there were no new cases of HIV, hepatitis C or tuberculosis (TB) in 2012 in the United States." As for its overall health, the WHO added that "the US does not currently face a public health emergency or a health emergency of international concern."

But the American-led embargo of Cuba and the US blockade of Cuba (known as the "Castro regime") has created one—or more—serious problems for Cuba.

First, there's the Cuban economy. Since the fall of Castro in January 1959, the US embargo of Cuba, and more recently the blockade of Cuba, have effectively cut off the Cuban government's most productive industries: manufacturing and agriculture. The Soviet embargo was similar, and more effective a
generated_result.2:
year, which means that this year has seen yet another round of debate and revision over the way the embargo on Cuba was imposed. In the decades since the ban, the embargo has become a political symbol, and has played a major role in the US-Cuban relationship.

Many American politicians — and their Cuban counterparts — have tried to explain the ban's meaning. A few have argued that the embargo was enacted for humanitarian reasons, as the US was fighting Nazi Germany, and therefore the ban should have been designed to stop the Nazis from carrying out war atrocities. Others have pointed to the embargo's humanitarian purpose, saying that America needed to keep a close eye on Cuba after Hitler became a menace and that the embargo prevented that.

prefix_text: If you have ducks as pet, you will need to take proper care of them while examining their way of living. Ducks need to have a secure place where they can live and can be safe from any
reference_text:
predators and it is easy to clean their housing area. Ducks do not prefer spending time inside their housing area as they prefer roaming outside for most of the time, regardless of the weather or the season.

There are many people who want to know how to build a duck pen? If you are looking forward to build a nice yet practical duck pen then you need to follow the guidelines that are discussed below.

First of all, you need to make sure that the structure of the duck pen offers proper protection to the ducks and is a defensive structure actually. It is important to keep your ducks safe from other animals and predators. You can allow them to roam about during the day time and lock them later during the night. Ducks love to spend their time in water and you can make a small pool near their pen and allow them to beat the heat of sunny days.

The design of duck house is just similar to chicken house design except some minor differences such as it doesn't require ro

generated_result.0:
predators. Ducks need to have plenty of space to swim and to climb, they can swim to higher areas like trees or buildings, so don't keep them too close to the ground when you have them.

Ducks are best when they are housed in a small pen or cage in which you can keep them for several months. Make sure that the pen is at least 4.5m x 4.5m, there will be a place for the duck to stand in and they can climb out of the cage. Ducks like to be in the sunshine for a few hours a day, so give them plenty of room.

They should also have a place to do their business, so make sure that there is plenty of shade where the ducks can stand and do some exercise. Ducks are very active and enjoy playing and roosting in trees, but don't keep them too close to the trees as they can quickly get injured.

Most of the time, they are easy

For a bird to get sick in his home he must become too cold and uncomfortable and must stop growing. If you have been keeping the ducks indoors, this is impossible to avoid, because the ducks will grow when outside or in the sun. They have to become so comfortable that they feel safe.

Ducks can never go to another part of the earth. It is too dangerous for them in this climate, because they are afraid to go out in the sun. There are several breeds of duck that can live outdoors. Dune Ducks are generally found in the tropical rainforests of the Pacific Coast. The Eastern European-Eurasian Duck, which is a little bit bigger than a normal duck, is found mainly in the Baltic Sea and in the Gulf of Finland.

prefix_text:
Your prize cow

Persona 4 was a story about acceptance. We all have a dark side, some aspect of our personality we dislike about ourselves, something we choose to repress and hide away
reference_text:
from the rest of the world. This isn't the healthiest practice, though. Atlus shows us a cavalcade of otherwise normal, healthy people become consumed by the enemy within. By the time the Investigation Team solves the mystery behind the Inaba murders, it's more than clear that accepting our personal weaknesses, flaws, and undesirable traits are key in becoming a stronger, more successful human being who can connect with others and the world around us.

Dancing All Night explores a similar motif, revolving around a group of Rise's peers, a band of pop idols named Kanamin Kitchen, who have been made to lead double lives. Having been manufactured by a record label, these girls are made to act and dress in certain ways that aren't reflective of who they really are. Nobody knows the real them. Deep down, they feel fake and isolated, trapped and forced to conform to public perception, like marionettes dancing for the crowd. All anyone sees is their masks, not the

generated_result.0:
.

There's also a part of us that has this innate ability to become accepted, and that ability is not yet a part of us; we are yet to be born.

The moment you can say that you're a cow, that's when you can start to show other people that you're not a negative person to other people, you're just a normal person, you're still that way even if you act that way in front of people.

For example, you're always a normal person that's not a bully in any manner whatsoever, but if you hear someone say that you're a bully, and then they ask for your name and say how it happened and say that your name and all your personal details and then take off, that's when you start to make other people feel bad about themselves, because there's somebody that you made unhappy, they're just a different kind of cow. They're not the normal type of cow that we are.
generated_result.1:
from the world around us. There are no simple answers. We must accept that, accept ourselves as we are and grow into our real self. Persona 4 isn't about a perfect, bright person, it's about the dark part of our lives, a reflection of our heart, just like us. We all have our darkness, a part that we've hid and suppressed for a long time.

We might have hidden our dark side from the world, but it only keeps getting stronger, and soon your friends are questioning if it's okay that you're a jerk at work or spending all your time on the internet. Your parents are questioning if you're taking too many drugs, even though you can't remember the last time you did and you can't get that off your mind. It's not going anywhere, this negativity and negativity is our reality.

And it's not just the people around us. Our fellow humans. The people you spend every day with. People you work with
generated_result.2:
, for good or ill. But it's our flaws that make us interesting, and that is why we will seek for our personal growth by doing things that are positive and encouraging.

And that's why you see so many people who have taken their love of video games to the next level by creating the Persona series. You see it in the character designs, the soundtrack, the series' fan-service. You see it in the fact that the cast members are all talented, skilled performers, and we can't blame them for wanting to express that in the name of love for games and a passion for this medium.

Even if it's not their personal favorite Persona.

Two weeks ago, a group of students at the University of California at Irvine removed a U.S. flag from a common area of the student government suite.

Shortly afterwards, six undergraduate members
reference_text:
of the Associated Students Council of UCI passed a resolution banning the display of the flags of any nation in the office lobby. The resolution was authored by student Matthew Guevara of the School of Social Ecology.

Among the reasons the legislative council objected to the American flag were:

--"The American flag has been flown in instances of colonialism and imperialism."

--"A common ideological understanding of the United States includes American exceptionalism and superiority."

--"Designing a culturally inclusive space is taken seriously by ASUCI."

--"The removal of barriers is the best option at promoting an inclusive space."

--"It is a psychological effect for individuals to identify negative aspects of a space rather than positive ones."

--"Freedom of speech, in a space that aims to be as inclusive as possible can be interpreted as hate speech."

Two days later a higher ranking student panel, the executive cabinet of ASUCI, vetoed the

generated_result.0:
from the club who had taken down the flag were suspended for several months. A third member, a sophomore, and one student who had been removed after the flag flap received formal reprimands.

"These suspensions came at the exact moment when students were in the thick of a conversation about national pride," said Matt Ritchie, the group's chair of student government, in a recent statement, adding that the three were removed because of their actions in the flag flap.

Although UC Irvine students have an abundance of flags, according to Ritchie, students are not required to have their own. The student government association recently voted to change its rules so that students can have up to three of their own flags on campus.

This article is going viral, having been shared on Xenosystems, Slate Star Codex, and elsewhere: Has Western-style democracy become too expensive for capitalism?

This short article offers a
reference_text:
lot to unpack.

The central reason why Western democracy is in decline is that its capitalist bedfellow can no longer afford the financial demands that full-blown democracy is placing upon it. History has shown that capitalism can adapt, consorting with a variety of political systems in the past 5,000 years. Looking ahead, it will probably find another political host to aid its survival. Democracy — capitalism's host over the past century — is far more brittle. …

Much ink has been spilled on the significance of 2016's one-two populist punches as thrown by Brexit then Trump. What does it mean for the West? Most analysis concludes that parts of the West are having second thoughts about globalisation, and there is undoubted — if only partial — merit in this assessment.

Q From Martin Turner, Hong Kong: A simple question, but it's bothering me. Where does crib come from in the sense of a cheat's answer sheet or illicitly
reference_text:
copying somebody else's work? It's listed as the same word as the baby's bed, but the connection is beyond me.

A It is the same word, though you may not be surprised to hear that a lot more lies behind it. The use of the term for a baby's cot is more common in US English than in Britain, where it's mainly reserved for a model of the Nativity of Christ, with a manger as a bed. The verb to crib in the sense of plagiarism or stealing another's schoolwork is mainly British English, though both US and British English know crib notes. Both varieties of English share the sense of a barred container or rack for animal fodder, a manger. This is the original, which turns up in English around the year 1000 and which is from an Old German word whose descendants are to be found in modern Dutch and German.


One sense of crib.

There are other senses of crib, especially that of

generated_result.0:
given instructions? As a kid, I was fascinated by what was done with a set of playing cards.

Richard Burton: There is no reason for it, actually. It seems to have emerged naturally as a child's favourite game. If the children play, then it's not cheating, it's playing, and it's playing for laughs, and it's really exciting.

We're not going to have children playing at our house any time soon. My wife and I have two children. They play with us quite a lot because we don't have children. I think it's perfectly OK to have the conversation that there was an evolutionary reason for cribbing; it wasn't a way to have a secret agenda.

So what it really comes down to is the belief that there was some sort of evolutionary advantage to this behaviour that was a very good means of avoiding discovery.

prefix_text: In the fall of 1962, whilst The Birds was in post-production, François Truffaut carried out extensive interviews with Alfred Hitchcock at his offices at Universal Studios. The interviews were recorded to audio tape
reference_text:
and the content eventually edited down into Truffaut's Hitchcock book.

Although Truffaut could speak a little English, he hired Helen Scott (of the French Film Office in New York) to act as the translator for the interviews.

Truffaut had intended to quickly publish the book of the interviews, but the first edition wasn't published until several years later (1966 in France and 1967 in America). To bring the book up-to-date, Truffaut conducted further interviews to discuss Marnie and Torn Curtain.

In 1984, Patricia Hitchcock donated a set of the interview tapes to the Margaret Herrick Library, where they are now part of the Hitchcock Collection. Although Truffaut claimed that the recordings lasted 50 hours, the surviving tapes — which cover the 1962 interviews — last for less than 26 hours.
