AeroComm Inc. specializes in affordable wireless data communications. The company leads the RF industry with technology breakthroughs, providing transceivers with superior price
reference_text:
and performance. These transceivers offer an instant RF solution to original equipment manufacturers (OEMs).

AeroComm was incorporated in Kansas in 1990 and is privately held. Since introducing its first wireless product in 1995, it has shipped hundreds of thousands of wireless connectivity devices for home, small business and OEM markets. AeroComm maintains headquarters in Lenexa, Kansas, as well as a regional sales/marketing branch in Salt Lake City, Utah. AeroComm's products are distributed throughout North America, Europe and Asia-Pacific regions.

AeroComm was the first company to receive FCC approval for a 2.4 GHz direct sequence spread spectrum radio in 1994. However, AeroComm's primary corporate focus since 1996 has been frequency hopping technology for the benefits of lower cost, lower power consumption, higher interference immunity and smaller size.

The company's unique proprietary methods of implementing spread spectrum technology enables wireless applications that were previously cost-prohibitive. AeroComm leverages this

The government's Disaster Management Agency (BMP) also reported that eight to 10 people were killed. The agency was notifying families of victims.

Christine Lagarde, the IMF's managing director since 2011, backed some of the inspectors' recommendations for improving internal procedures but dismissed calls from the independent evaluation office (IEO) to fortify the fund's defences against political interference.

Some of
reference_text:
this will be well intentioned; many think you'll fare better if you don't rock the boat. Others are ass-faces who find reassurance in knowing that they're not the only ones who chose the safe path.

The Alberta government has announced more funding for flood and drought protection.

The province is to invest an additional $31 million over four years in flood resiliency projects through the Alberta Community Resil
reference_text:
ience Program.

The 10-year, $500-million program has so far helped to build flood barriers, as well as other safeguards.

Another $14 million is to go to the Watershed Resilience and Restoration Program.

READ MORE: Final round of Alberta flood, drought funding announced

That program had been set to wrap up in 2017.

Environment Minister Shannon Phillips says the money will help communities adapt to changing climate and more common severe weather.

"Flood and drought events can be devastating to Alberta families and our economy," she said in a statement Friday.

"Our additional investment in flood and drought resiliency will help our communities adapt to a changing climate where severe weather will be more common."

According to the province, the Watershed Resiliency and Restoration Program grants will pay for the "restoration, enhancement and creation of more than 600 hectares of wetlands and 40 kilometres of riparian areas, the lush strips

generated_result.0:
ience Program.

The amount of funding earmarked for flood and drought protection is the same amount agreed to in the previous two funding agreements.

"When we took office in May of last year, we said we were going to build the infrastructure we needed to keep Calgary safe," Alberta minister and climate change minister Margaret McCuaig-Boyd said in a news release.

"Over the past year, our government has been working hard to meet our commitments to address climate change, and now it's time to use those resources to strengthen the city's resilience. This investment is another step towards improving the stability and well-being of our communities."

'We are going to pay attention'

The funds, part of the $5.3-billion Climate Leadership Plan announced in March, is money for projects that are expected to save lives by reducing flood risk, reduce water losses, and reducing the impacts of drought in cities across the province.

"The Clima
generated_result.1:

"We're making progress all the time," said Premier Rachel Notley. "This is just one of those investments that will really help us in these times of need."

The new funding will go towards building new water infrastructure, upgrading flood insurance policies and flood control in high-risk communities, providing more funding for the Alberta Emergency Management Agency, and funding infrastructure and stormwater projects through the Calgary Flood Centre.

Premier Rachel Notley made an announcement about the Flood and Drought Management fund in the legislature Friday. (Evelyne Asselin/CBC)

#43. @realDonaldTrump what is your administration's official stance on organized labor? #100Days100Qs

Right now, about 10 percent of American workers belong to an organized labor union, a number that has dropped significantly in recent decades — about 50 years ago, one-third of the US workforce belonged to a union.

President Donald Trump has attacked unions before, and his initial pick to lead the Department of Labor — fast food executive Andy Puzder — was decried by union leaders. Puzder ultimately didn't get the job after he came under scrutiny for employing an undocumented worker, and for allegations that he abused his ex-wife.

The president's new pick for to labor secretary — Alexander Acosta — has been well-received by some unions, though he has yet to go through a Senate confirmation hearing.

A total of 50 of Scotland's 59 seats have changed hands in an unprecedented shift to the SNP at the polls.

The party now has 56 MPs while Labour and the Lib Dems have seen their
reference_text:
standing slashed to one seat each. The Conservatives retain their single seat.

How Scotland voted

In 2010, Labour had 41 seats, the Lib Dems 11, SNP 6 and the Conservatives just one. Nicola Sturgeon's party has dramatically overturned those figures, taking 40 from Labour and 10 from the Lib Dems.

Labour now holds just Edinburgh South and the Liberal Democrats retain only Orkney & Shetland. The Conservatives keep Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale & Tweeddale.

Parties through time

A change of this magnitude has not been previously seen in Scotland in a single election.

The Conservatives went from being the largest party (by one seat) in 1955 to being electorally wiped out in 1997 but that decline took decades.

Big names voted out

Senior figures to lose their seats to the SNP include Scottish Labour leader Jim Murphy and Chief Secretary to the Treasury Danny Alexander.

Danny Alexander, Liberal Democrat, Chief Secretary

In Scotland's devolved administrations, the Scottish Government has increased spending by $14.1bn on health and education over the last four years with the Scottish Budget having risen by another $6.1bn in 2013/14.

In England, spending has increased by only $9.9bn during the same period.

The SNP has increased support among the Scottish electorate in a similar way to the results in Scotland.

In England, the SNP is now on course for a landslide victory in 2015 and will probably become the largest party in the House of Commons at Westminster, with a majority in the House of Lords of 50.

prefix_text: Heavy periods are common, but they can have a big effect on a woman's everyday life. They don't always have an underlying cause, but they can result from problems such as fibroids or
reference_text:
endometriosis, so it's important to get your symptoms checked out. See your GP if: you're worried about your bleeding

your periods have got heavier

you're also having other symptoms, such as period pain or bleeding between your periods Various treatments are available for heavy periods, including: some types of contraception, like an intrauterine system (IUS) or the combined pill

medicines, like tranexamic acid

surgery

How much is heavy bleeding? It's difficult to define exactly what a heavy period is because it varies from woman to woman. Heavy for one woman may be normal for another. Most women will lose less than 16 teaspoons of blood (80ml) during their period, with the average being around 6 to 8 teaspoons. Heavy menstrual bleeding is defined as losing 80ml or more in each period, having periods that last longer than 7 days, or both. However, it's not usually necessary to measure blood loss

generated_result.0:
ovarian cysts. These can affect a woman's diet, sleep and other lifestyle choices, or they could be simply signs that the ovaries are in danger.

What Causes a Fibroid or Ovarian Cyst?

An ovary is a small gland located in the upper body that produces hormones which produce male or female characteristics. Most women have the ovary at some point in their lives. But, ovaries can be damaged by a number of things.

These include cancer, surgery, radiation, infections and autoimmune diseases.

When an ovary is damaged, it causes menstrual irregularities.

As an example, you may have cramps if you are having irregular menstrual periods, but it does not necessarily mean that the ovaries themselves are in trouble. For instance, if you have had a small amount of an infection called an erythema migrans, and your body is not responding to the infection, a fibroid or ovarian cyst is a mor
generated_result.1:
ovarian cysts.

When your period is low, it can take longer for your menstrual blood to flow to your cervix (endometrium). This can prevent your eggs from reaching ovaries, which means you may have a low fertility rate.

You also may notice signs of a high bleeding time or discomfort, such as a loss of energy or feeling nauseous.

Low Fertility Periods

There is no set, normal time of your period. However, some women's periods can start or stop at different times in their cycle.

In some women, a very low pregnancy rate may start at the same time as their first period, and their period continues until their next period. In others, their last period may go for a number of months or years.

Other factors may affect when and how frequently your period will occur. For example, if you have some form of diabetes or high blood pressure, you may need more frequent or more severe periods
generated_result.2:

They cause inflammation in your body and lead to pain and swelling in your abdominal area. The ovaries themselves are tiny tubes that help release hormones into the blood. The excess estrogen can affect a woman's menstrual cycle and lead to menstrual cramps and bloating. If you have a pre-existing condition, you could be at higher risk. Some conditions could increase your risk of fibroids, such as: diabetes

high cholesterol

heart disease or high blood pressure

cancer You can reduce your risk of developing fibroids by addressing other health conditions at the same time. Certain medications can also increase your risk, such as: corticosteroids

medicines that can affect your liver

chemotherapy to treat heart conditions

any medications that interfere with your body's hormone system

Use this list to keep track of all your third-trimester tasks, from doing kick counts to making a birth plan and deciding on a baby name.

Activities for your third trimester
reference_text:
Keep track of your baby's movements

Pay attention to your baby's kicks, twitches, and rolls and let your doctor or midwife know right away if you notice a decrease in movement. Less movement may signal a problem, and you'll need testing to check on your baby's condition. Your healthcare provider may recommend that you spend some time each day counting your baby's kicks – find out how to do "kick counts."

Learn about third-trimester prenatal visits and tests

You'll most likely have a checkup every two weeks from 28 to 36 weeks, then switch to once-a-week visits until you deliver. As you and your provider get to know each other better and as your due date draws near, you can expect a mix of regular physical exams, late-pregnancy tests, and discussions about the coming birth.

Find out more about third-trimester prenatal visits.

Consider more classes

When should I begin doing the third trimester activities?

You should start getting active during your third trimester when you are at your best. You might need to be a bit more active during your third trimester, especially if your labour is longer or more intense, than you would normally be.

2. Make a birth plan.

WHAT IS KRATOM

A botanical cousin of the common coffee bush with hundreds of years of indigenous use as natural medicine that not only has immunostimulant properties but in addition to
reference_text:
being a possible mood booster, antidepressant and effective analgesi has more antioxidant power than a cup of green tea. It's the mitragyna speciosa, a bush indigenous to the jungles of Southeast Asia where it's known as kratom, ketum, ithang or some other name depending on the region. Kratom has hundreds (if not thousands) of years of safe and effective human use in the region where it's found and over a century of research, including an isolate of the plant being synthesized as early as 1921.

Kratom has been researched globally and to a great degree. A US patent was granted June of 2013 for a number of "Hybrid opioid compounds and compositions and their pharmaceutical compositions, as well as to methods of treating pain in humans using the hybrid compounds and mixed opioid salts." Both mitragynine and the derivative mitragynine-pseudoindoxyl are referenced in the patent multiple times. This and multiple works of scholarship in regards

WHAT IS KRATOM SOLUTION

Liquid kratom solution, an ideal alternative for treating symptoms of pain or stress.

THE KRATOM PROJECT

The KRATOM PROJECT is a multi-faceted initiative to help eliminate the problematic effects of this drug and bring it down to a science, an art and a religion. Kratom's use as a painkiller has been called into question in numerous reports as there is very little medical evidence for the use of Kratom as a painkiller and in addition it does not appear to alleviate the symptoms of chronic and severe opioid use.

Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders took some heat from CNN's Jake Tapper during an April 3 interview. The topic: The degree of public transparency Sanders has provided for his tax returns.

Tapper
reference_text:
brought up the topic: "I'm kind of surprised that you haven't gone further on transparency. You released the summary page of your 2014 tax returns. Hillary Clinton has posted on her website the last eight years of her personal returns, all of the returns. Before the New York primary, will you match her? Will you post your full returns for the last eight years?"

Sanders responded, "You know who does our tax returns? My wife does our tax returns. We've been a little bit busy lately. So we will get out as much information as we can. There ain't going to be very much exciting in that. I get a salary from the United States Senate, you know, there's not going to be anything new in it that people haven't seen for the last many years, but we will get it out as soon as we can."

Tapper wasn't satisfied. "But nobody has seen them at all, I guess, is the point, and

generated_result.0:
pointed out that Bernie Sanders had already said that he was not going to release his tax returns, but Tapper pressed him to clarify.

"I don't believe in releasing returns," Sanders said, noting that he would give the information to the Clinton campaign and release his tax returns as soon as the audits are completed.

But Tapper had some harsh words for Sanders.

"You have yet to explain why you want to stay under the 15 percent financial disclosure threshold," the CNN anchor said.

"You have been a senator for 13 years and a member of Congress for seven years," Sanders said, adding that he has not made any donations to any political candidates since he was first elected.

"My mother's name is on the phone line," he quipped.

Tapper shot back that Sanders was being "unfair" in suggesting that his finances don't come under scrutiny.

"I am under audit from the Internal Revenue Service, a
generated_result.1:
pressed Sanders to detail a number of years, and then asked him whether he would release any more, and Sanders repeated the same answer: No.

But at a June 2 campaign appearance in San Antonio, Sanders said he would not give up his "swamp tax" — that is, his tax rate — and explained that his plan is "to make the U.S. less rich by getting rid of middle class loopholes."

The public and news media have sought Sanders' returns for months.

As for the Clinton camp, a Sanders spokesperson would only say in a statement to The Huffington Post, "We do not have any comment on what Secretary Clinton would or would not release, though we can confirm that she has never released her tax returns."

Clinton does not hold a press conference with the press or hold fundraisers on the campaign trail in support of her campaign.

Instead, she is running on the slogan, "Stronger Together."

Sanders has

Definition The Subway diet is the weight-loss plan created by Jared Fogle, an obese college student who weighed 425 pounds (192.7 kilograms). The 22-year-
reference_text:
old Fogle lost 245 pounds (111.1 kilograms) in 11 months by following a daily diet that consisted primarily of two low-fat sandwiches purchased at the Subway fast-food chain. After losing 100 pounds (45.4 kilograms), the 6-foot-2 (187.9-centimter) Fogle added walking to his daily routine. His dramatic weight loss led to Fogle's appearances in Subway commercials and his role as a motivational speaker and an advocate in the fight against childhood obesity.

Origins Jared's Fogle's unique diet led to his weight loss and international fame as the star of Subway sandwich commercials. He created the Subway diet in March of 1998.By1999,heweighed 180 pounds (81.6 kilograms). In 2000, he began appearing in Subway TV commercials. prefix_text: Gavin Eugene Long, the gunman who killed three police officers and wounded three others in Baton Rouge, La., on Sunday, left a vast and angry online trail documenting his interest in black separatism and
reference_text:
fury at police shootings of black men.

Long, whose identity was confirmed by a law enforcement official, was shot to death by police after opening fire on officers on Airline Highway, less than a mile from the city's police headquarters in Baton Rouge.

One law enforcement official described him as "a black separatist." He carried out the shooting on his 29th birthday, and was from Kansas City, Mo.

It's unclear when he came to Baton Rouge.

Long went by "Cosmo" online and had registered the domain name ConvosWithCosmo.club in April using his Kansas City address. The website shows a generic page with ads but a similarly named site, ConvosWithCosmo.com, includes links to podcasts, YouTube videos, books of his for sale and various social media accounts.

In a video posted on social media, Gavin Long, the man identified by a U.S. government official as the Baton Rouge police shooting suspect

generated_result.0:
anti-American violence, along with racist and anti-Semitic content. Long was a Bernie Sanders supporter, but told a local TV station that his motivation was political, not racial.


Long's Facebook account was taken down this week. He did not respond to The Daily Beast for comment.

The Daily Beast could find no evidence that Long had ever posted a video or audio, or shared his belief in a white American republic; all the evidence shows that he simply admired the Confederate flag. He praised Black Lives Matter leader DeRay Mckesson by tweeting: "The last time I listened to @DreayMckesson was while reading this quote on how to stop police violence & how to build a movement."

anti-Semitism.

He wrote:

"You are the root of the problem. The truth about you and your Jews, or your liberal, communist Jewish agenda, is you are the only ones who have been taken over by the evil beast that is Israel. The rest of us have been reduced to slave labour in their hands or to the ranks of their thugs. I am no longer a conservative, because my country has not been saved and my family has been destroyed, no matter if I support Trump or Bernie Sanders."

In another tweet, he compared "Zionist" Jews to the Ku Klux Klan:

ZIONIST ISLAM
generated_result.2:
what appeared to be an overt endorsement of white supremacist organizations such as the KKK and the Aryan Nations.

Long's online posts indicate that he had been active in the racist and anti-Semitic movement known as Alt-Right. That term was recently co-opted by some white supremacists to refer to all those who, for ideological reasons or in spite of it, oppose President Trump.

The Southern Poverty Law Center, a civil rights group that monitors hate groups, described Long as an "active member" of the Ku Klux Klan and said his beliefs are a "revolving door of racism."

Long spent much of his time on social media writing about white pride, conspiracy theories and other far-right topics.

prefix_text: AMD formally announced its new Naples server CPU today, with up to 32 cores, eight memory channels, and its new, 128-lane Infinity Fabric. Ryzen's consumer performance may be impressive, but this
reference_text:
is a straight server play, with AMD hoping to capitalize on strong performance in the 1-2 socket market.

The company's strategy is similar to the one it adopted eleven years ago. Back in 2006, AMD's server business was one of the company's biggest success stories. Beginning in 2001, with the launch of Athlon MP and the 760MP chipset, AMD had slowly taken market share aware from Intel, particularly once Opteron launched. Its share of the worldwide server business peaked in Q2 2006, at just under 25% of the market. Today, AMD has less than 1% of the market, which is one of the reasons it's so eager to rejoin that particular fight. Intel's data center business was worth $17.2 billion in 2016, up 8% from 2015. If AMD can capture 5% of that business, that's $860 million of additional revenue per year, and it's revenue that comes with a nice margin.

AMD's Naples

generated_result.0:
performance comes with a price tag, with Naples' cost coming to around £7,000.

As always, AMD's first server CPU has been well received, with many people taking their time over its release. While the release of Ryzen is a clear and definite step forward, AMD is well aware that its server processors aren't likely to gain massive traction in the home market anytime soon. AMD hasn't yet released a server-based gaming chip, so it'll be interesting to see how much of a gaming performance boost there will be with its Naples-based desktop CPUs.

[Image credit: Tech in Asia]
generated_result.1:
is a huge jump in single-threaded performance from Ryzen's previous offering in Naples.

AMD's Naples architecture combines four "A" cores running at 1.65GHz with up to 24 threads apiece (4 threads in a 2-core Ryzen 7 1700). The high-end Naples chips will arrive with 4GB of L3, DDR4-2666, in addition to 4GB of 16GB of system memory on the lower-end Naples chips. The desktop chips will not feature 4GB of memory. AMD also revealed that Naples will support high-speed DDR4 memory in its products.

This doesn't just mean that Naples chips will get faster memory performance. There's a new Zen+ microarchitecture, called Zen+ 4.0, that has been improved in the last year or two. It's a bit more powerful than Zen, and the architectural improvements, combined with Intel's 7th-gen Kaby Lake chips, are expected to give AMD a
generated_result.2: should be enough to keep gamers busy for the short-term.

prefix_text: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un called Saturday for government officials to eliminate any remaining "non-socialist" parts of society, showing him tightening his grip on the oppressive nation as he combats sanctions and
reference_text:
ever-rising tensions with the United States and other adversaries.

Speaking to a group of chairpersons for the country's ruling Workers' Party, Kim said all party members should join the "revolutionary offensive to uproot non-socialist practices" and educate working people to become "revolutionaries" who will defend North Korean culture from outside influence.

"When our socialist culture and art prevails over the corrupt bourgeois reactionary culture, it is possible for people not to harbor illusions about the enemies' culture but to prevent ideological and cultural poisoning by the imperialists," Kim said, according to the state-run KCNA news agency.

"The Korean people should thoroughly cleanse their bodies of all un-socialist elements through a powerful struggle with the people of the DPRK to win their hearts," Kim said at an official ceremony held in Pyongyang for the "Day of the Strongly Hating Pre-emptive Strike."

North Korean leader Kim Jong Un watches military exercises with his military near Mangyongdae, North Korea, April 11, 2017. KCNA/via REUTERS

It was the first speech since a massive rally of about 10,000 people in Pyongyang on Saturday, which drew tens of thousands of people but was also the most-watched propaganda event on North Korean TV this year.

war with the United States.

The comments were likely aimed at removing the influence of political parties and officials who promote freedom in North Korea, but could also be aimed at curbing the influence of defectors to defect from the isolated state.

"People who are not part of the political system or are non-socialist are the true culprits of social ills in the DPRK," said Kim, according to a report by state media.

"Those who spread poison from the non-socialist elements into the socialist system should be eliminated one after another."

It was the latest statement from Kim that has put the North Korean leader's control over the state under a new spotlight in a time of economic hardship for the totalitarian state.

Since the beginning of last year, hundreds of thousands of North Koreans have fled to South Korea, many for a more prosperous life. But they have also attracted unwelcome attention to the country's leadership.

prefix_text: Friends, relatives, and co-workers are forever recommending movies—with mixed results. But what if those recommendations came from a more knowledgeable source? The Tribeca Shortlist is a relatively new steaming
reference_text:
platform that enlists industry insiders and experts to curate a collection of award-winning films available to stream online. One of the films available in May is Julian Schnabel's The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, which, as actor Tom Hiddleston explains in the exclusive clip above, had a profound impact on him.

The 2007 film was a festival favorite and showered with awards and nominations for tackling a seemingly impossible adaptation. As Hiddleston points out, the 1997 book on which the film is based was dictated entirely by Jean-Dominique Bauby—a former journalist suffering from locked-in syndrome—blinking his eyes. It's exactly the kind of film that shouldn't have been a success, and because it works so well, many, including Hiddleston, consider it essential viewing for movie lovers. Hiddleston's entire collection of Shortlist movies is called "Stories of Heartbreak and Humor."

"We're taking

generated_result.0:

The Shortlist's criteria is simple: "Most interesting to watch right now." No matter whether you're looking for a movie to keep you company after work or a movie you're trying to see before heading home on a cold autumn's evening, the Shortlist will probably give you a recommendation with a little something to offer, not something to force you to pick it up.

This was my original thought, anyway, so if you want your next date to enjoy your favorite films a little more, you might like to check out this list.

prefix_text: To this day, I am surprised at the number of people who complain about the Journal's binary storage format. Having spent years working as a system administrator, and after years of working with and on sys
reference_text:
log-ng - in the capacity of maintainer of the Open Source Edition for more than a year -, I am increasingly puzzled about all the hostility towards non-text storage formats. I am even more puzzled about the arguments against it. Maybe I'm living in a different world, but there are very, very few reasons I see for using text based storage, when there is a better option available. I've been asked numerous times about my logging needs, and why I am so vigilantly against text based log storage, and this is my attempt at answering those questions.

Please note that this is not a journal-apology: I've been deploying binary log storage way before the Journal happened, and my recommended solution is not the Journal either. (Truth be told, I like the idea of the Journal, and am enjoying its features on some machines of mine, but it is not a solution to my needs, and never will be.)

admins, I feel that the problem is a bit more than a technical issue. I am also a big fan of binary. Binary can be expressed in a simple but robust way:

If you write a program and call it something like this (using the compiler you used to write the program):

if(!abc)

You can compile it, and run it. It works and it behaves as you expect it to.

But if you write the same program, but instead of writing it to a file or a file system, you write it to an array in a byte buffer, like this (using the assembler, or more precisely the C# compiler):

if(abc) {

You can execute that program, and no one will notice anything strange happening.

The same is true for any file format in which all information is stored and used in one place.

prefix_text:
OTTAWA — Conservative leadership candidate Andrew Scheer says universities should lose federal funding if they fail to protect freedom of speech on campus.

A "troubling trend" has surfaced where small
reference_text:
groups on campus can shut down events, prevent guest speakers from giving lecture and ban activities or clubs they disagree with, Scheer said in an interview Wednesday. "Campuses are no longer the bastions of free speech that they once were."

Recent examples include a pro-life group having its event cancelled at Wilfrid Laurier University; a student newspaper at McGill refusing to print pro-Israel articles; and protest surrounding University of Toronto professor Jordan Peterson for his views on gender pronouns.

"There are a lot of people who come to campus who say things that are outrageous. And I vehemently disagree with them. That I find offensive. Professors or guest speakers who say terrible things about everything from Christianity to capitalism," Scheer said.

"I just don't go to them. It's as simple as that. And it doesn't bother me. It doesn't keep me up at night. It doesn't make me want to go and tip a car over."

In the video — which was obtained by Maclean's.ca — the professor argues that he will protect his students' safety if he continues to speak up about Islamophobia in the classroom.

"If a university is not committed to defending free speech by virtue of its mandate as a public institution, I can't imagine that's the first place it would look," Scheer said Tuesday. It's a trend that has prompted a national discussion that has led to a report from the University of Ottawa calling for all private institutions of higher education to undergo "significant" changes to their policies and practices in response. schools are allowing extremists to spew hate speech on their campuses, said Scheer, who won the leadership race on Saturday with nearly 57 per cent of the vote.

prefix_text: Most of us grew up on the concept of LAMP(Linux apache mysql and php) but there are times when that basic setup can become a real pain to maintain and scale. Generally the hardest

That is where NoSQL comes into play. NoSQL is a very board term and some options are better than others. At the moment my choice for a NoSQL database is set firmly with MongoDB. Despite being a relatively new comer to the NoSQL scene MongoDB is quite mature and has awesome documentation.
If you are on a *nix platform you can simply use pecl pecl install mongo
For windows you will need to download the MongoDB binaries and the php extensions
Also don't forget to add the mongo extension to your php.ini extension=mongo.so

part of LAMP/PHP is not even configuration. The hardest thing is keeping it in a clean, fast, and up-to-date environment.

When I got my head around the LAMP concept, I saw that the configuration and configuration management tasks for Apache2, a web server written in PHP, was a lot easier than the LAMP setup. The LAMP setup was a bunch of PHP files that were stored in a directory structure called conf. The configuration to control all of this was stored in conf/<module>/etc/apache2/sites-available/conf.d. The configuration was all in a single file ( conf/<module>/etc/apache2/sites-available/conf.d/<file> ), which just had a few lines and could be changed to make an example site work, without needing to rewrite the configuration.

prefix_text: JERUSALEM — A famously child-friendly country with a federally subsidized universal health care system that offers free fertility treatments, Israel has made it easier for economically distressed women to obtain an abortion.
reference_text:
The 2014 "health basket" of medical services and medications approved by Israel's cabinet Sunday (Jan. 5) includes free abortions for Israeli women aged 20 to 33, regardless of the circumstances.

The $4.6 million earmarked by the Health Ministry committee will cover some 6,300 abortions for women who cannot afford the procedure.

In 2013, almost 20,000 women received permission to abort from hospital termination committees, according to Efrat, an organization that encourages women considering abortion to have their babies.

Until now, government-funded abortions have been reserved for women younger than 19 or older than 40, and in cases where the fetus has a severe defect, the mother's life is endangered, or the pregnancy is a result of sexual abuse. If a woman believed the pregnancy would cause her harm, physically or emotionally, she had had to pay for the procedure herself.

Ruth Tidhar, who heads Efrat's assistance department, said that

generated_result.0:
In a new law that takes effect this month, abortions are allowed up to 22 weeks of pregnancy — as long as doctors can show that the fetus's viability is at least seven weeks.

"We recognize that it's a sensitive issue and I understand the need to allow for a woman to make an informed decision," Israeli Health Minister Yaakov Litzman told Israel Hayom. "In any case, the goal is to let women have an abortion, so if a woman doesn't want to give a child up for adoption or if she's not a mother by law, she can terminate it."

If the fetus is viable, the doctor can refuse to terminate the pregnancy, but there are exceptions for medical reasons — for example, if the fetus has a serious malformation or is not capable of surviving outside of the womb.

In the past, abortion in the state was mandatory only for patients who have an ectopic pregnancy or for the fetus's life outside the womb. That was one of a few provisions that critics of the law contend had loopholes. Others complained that the law's provisions were too lenient for middle-class women, and that it unfairly targeted poor women, who rarely seek abortions because of their own financial circumstances.

prefix_text: On their third album, the War on Drugs essentially continue to stake out their own particular patch of ground in 21st century rock & roll with an indie bent, nodding in equal parts toward older traditions and
reference_text: newer ones with a difference of two decades in between them, captured right down to the cover art, which is pretty much a companion piece to the art on their second album Future Weather. On the one hand, there's still a sense of world-weary wisdom and lost Americana as such at work from the start, as the extended breakdown toward the end of "Best Night" demonstrates, all silvery guitar jamming and sparkling piano following from Adam Granduciel's reedy singing. At the same time the diffuse qualities of feedback, psychedelic glaze, and textural experimentation via everything that fed into what became shoegaze (not to mention shoegaze itself) remain key, audible in the opening chimes of "Brothers" and "It's Your Destiny"'s spaced-out and exultant flow, perhaps most notably on the short instrumentals "Original Slave" and "Come for It." prefix_text: It can happen to anyone at any time. One minute you're feeling an indescribable vibrancy and next an emptiness. It has sidelined the most talented cuppers in the field for
reference_text:
minutes; hours in more severe cases. We are talking about the world of professional coffee tasting and it's most common ailment–palate fatigue!

Professional coffee tasters, like our own Paul Massard and Stormin' Norman, put their taste buds on the line every day by cupping coffee for hours. With the daily cupping process come hazards and risks like burnt tongues, self-inflicted tongue bites and worst of all, palate fatigue.

What is palate fatigue?

Also known as taste bud exhaustion or sensory enervation, palate fatigue occurs when tasting a multitude of comparable products consecutively. In the realm of coffee, palate fatigue often strikes during the cupping process. During a cupping, slurping and slurping for hours on end could take a toll on your ability to distinguish between the different flavor notes of coffee.

Why does palate fatigue happen?

Many believe that palate fatigue occurs when your nose and taste buds are simply overworked.

Are women oppressed today? If so, why is it that they live more? Why are they happier?

Long-time political activist Adam Leonas examines the arguments about the oppression of women,
reference_text:
and shows that all the supposed disadvantages are essentially trade-offs against much worse alternatives.

He takes a fascinating look into the biology of the sexes, to find where female superiority and male weakness is located: sex. He argues that the point in history when the prehistoric gender balance was overturned was during "the worst mistake in human history": the Agricultural Revolution, when what he calls "the Female Coup d'etat" took place.

The author, being unrelentingly radically progressive, concludes that in historic societies, capitalism included, women's power is greater due to their control over sex. He proposes radical ways for men to deal with their disadvantaged position, as well as radical ways to remedy the gender balance in society as a necessary prerequisite for equality and social peace.

Sweden is famous for its tolerant reputation, with politicians and celebrities alike calling for respect for religious and sexual minorities and women's reproductive rights. On Thursday, there will be another "Day of Absence" – that is, a day without work – but this one will come with much more symbolic weight.

In contrast to a country where a woman must work for four hours to cover the basic cost of her pregnancy and child's maintenance, women in Sweden can now decide whether they would like to stay in work on Fridays and Sunday afternoons, the day they give birth, or take a day off to have their baby.

generated_result.2:
gay pride parade helped her to get a message out to the general public, and she's worked tirelessly in her blog to bring information about gender equality to her audiences.

But now she's taken a much-needed step towards the mainstream – this weekend, she gave a talk at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Her talk, "Social Disadvantage and the Wealth Gap – The Politics of Gender Equality in Sweden", discussed how inequality is often defined as a male-dominated phenomenon. That's not what's happening, Ohlsson says.

"The gender wage gap is not about the difference between men's and women's wages. Nor is it about the pay gap between men and women of the same age," she told her audience. "It is about the difference between the genders' living conditions: more hours, more holidays, less freedom and more insecurity in work."

And in Sweden, women are the victims, rather than the perpetrators, of inequality.

reference_text:
he said something along the lines of, "If I can get someone's head underwater, I can get them under the ocean."

In other words, the way to get people engaged in the world around them is to first get them interacting with it.

After some reflection on that idea, Rowe decided to use his background in technology and film to "set a new bar for conservation media." He made the move from Orlando to Durham, identifying with the city's growing tech scene. And now he's on his way toward setting that bar with WildEyes, a project aimed to bring all of the U.S. National Parks to life in virtual reality.

The project launched last fall after Rowe raised $9,001 through an Indiegogo campaign. The funds went toward park and travel expenses and 360-degree camera equipment.

Also helping jumpstart the project is Doctrine Creative, a small creative production company in Orlando that Rowe runs with three co-founders.

So in 2015 he joined the Google DeepSeaLab, an ambitious project with the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), a division of the U.S. Department of Commerce, that is working on mapping the entire marine ecosystem by means of computer-generated imagery.

Using this imagery, Rowe and his team mapped the distribution and abundance of more than 100 marine animals. The Pennsylvania Railroad commissioned Ferris to design the elevated freight line on Sixth Avenue to bring seven railway lines through downtown Jersey City to Harsimus yard on the Hudson River. Washington: President Donald Trump has tapped a longtime legal adviser to serve as his private attorney while a special counsel investigates whether his campaign worked with Russia in last year's election, a
reference_text:
source familiar with the decision said on Tuesday.

Fox Business News and ABC first reported that Trump hired Marc Kasowitz, a New York-based trial lawyer known as a tenacious litigator, to represent him in a Justice Department investigation headed by former Federal Bureau of Investigation Director Robert Mueller.

One of the biggest changes in the union movement has happened mostly under the radar, but it has big consequences for union officials, workers and the public at large.

Unions used to be powerful in the private sector. But now, most union workers nationwide are government employees. It has been this way since 2009.

Since 2000 unions have lost more than 2 million members in the private sector nationwide, but gained more than 200,000 members in government. Something very similar happened in Illinois, with union membership holding steady in government while membership dropped by 244,000 in the private sector.

With a long history of private-sector unionism, Illinois hasn't quite reached that point yet, but the gap has narrowed to almost nothing. Government union members could outnumber private-sector union members as early

generated_result.0:
.

Over the past 20 years, the number of collective agreements between workers and employers has decreased markedly from 75% of all agreements to 42%.

A new report by the Institute for Research on Public Policy's Center for Labor Market Studies has found that almost half of all union contracts now do not allow for workers to opt out of collective bargaining. This means that if you sign an agreement that offers pay, benefits and more benefits than the current minimum wage, you could potentially lose the protections of collective bargaining.

Under this dynamic, workers tend to opt out of the union only when they are being exploited by their employer. This can be true even when employers are paying workers more than minimum wage. The Center for Labor Market Studies estimated that as the minimum wage has increased, the percentage of workers who have signed a collective agreement has decreased in a majority of cases.

More common: The employer has more power.

prefix_text: Acquiring the Reflectance Field of a Human Face Paul Debevec, Tim Hawkins, Chris Tchou, Haarm-Pieter Duiker, Westley Sarokin, and Mark
reference_text:
Sagar SIGGRAPH 2000 Conference Proceedings Updated 4/10/04 Abstract:


We present a method to acquire the reflectance field of a human face and use these measurements to render the face under arbitrary changes in lighting and viewpoint. We first acquire images of the face from a small set of viewpoints under a dense sampling of incident illumination directions using a light stage. We then construct a reflectance function image for each observed image pixel from its values over the space of illumination directions. From the reflectance functions, we can directly generate images of the face from the original viewpoints in any form of sampled or computed illumination. To change the viewpoint, we use a model of skin reflectance to estimate the appearance of the reflectance functions for novel viewpoints. We demonstrate the technique with synthetic renderings of a person's face under novel illumination and viewpoints.

prefix_text: The record heat that is baking Alaska is poised to smash a host of climate records in 2016, including the earliest snowmelt date at NOAA's Barrow Observatory, the northernmost point in the nation
reference_text:
.

Staff at the observatory reported snowmelt occurred May 13, the earliest snowmelt date in 73 years of record-keeping, beating the previous mark set in 2002 by a full 10 days.

The early melting follows a record-setting winter that saw temperatures average more than 11 degrees above normal for the 49th State, shattering the previous record set in 2015. At 320 miles north of the Arctic Circle, Barrow is usually one of the last places in the United States to lose snow cover.

Baked Alaska Download Image

Snow is not the only thing that's vanishing. Preliminary data from the National Snow and Ice Data Center indicate 2016 will set the record for minimum winter sea-ice extentoffsite link, eclipsing the 2015 mark. Satellite photos from mid-May depict an early sea-ice breakup with an ominous series of openings, known as leads, extending deep into the Arctic.

The earliest June snow record for Alaska, based on weather observations made in June 2010, is set at 12.7 inches.

NOAA's Alaska Meteorological Center's (AMC) annual forecasts are based on weather observations on the ground made at NOAA's stations in the region, and on a computer model that runs at least three times each year in the U.S. At the AMC, NOAA meteorologists build their models with historical weather observations.

At the time of the high and low temperatures, Barrow Observatory is one of the first observatories in the world to be able to record temperatures in real-time, without the use of satellite. "This helps with the accuracy of our records," said Barrow Observatory meteorologist James Williams.

prefix_text: Think Progress has really been all over the Florida voter purge story, finally driving the kind of attention to the issue that it deserves. It's really a case of a political party trying to steal an election
reference_text:
in plain sight. When you see the head of the Florida Republican Party admit on national television that the purge is based on flawed data, but also that it must continue, you know that the ulterior motives are clear.

As mentioned, Think Progress' coverage has led to news outlets finally paying attention to what's happening in Florida, including Ari Berman at Rolling Stone. And at least one elections supervisor, in Palm Beach County, has rejected the voter purge list citing the high error rates associates with their generation, and will not be sending out notices to voters that their rights can be taken away if they don't prove their citizenship within 30 days. According to the supervisor, the purge lists are "not credible."

Amidst all this, voting rights activists surveying the scene in Florida got some additional good news. A federal judge today blocked a separate Florida voter suppression law, which is designed to make voter registration drives more difficult.

A federal judge blocked enforcement of key provisions of a

generated_result.0:
.

But it's also really the story of the way the Republican Party in Florida has come to dominate our political process and is making it harder for voters to express their views and be heard.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The purge was originally supposed to target two groups. One was poor nonwhite voters who don't normally vote Republican but were thought to be part of the group that was being affected by the voter purge. The other was people who didn't have driver's licenses to vote on Election Day. But the Republican-controlled Legislature used state law to make this so that they would not be singled out.

prefix_text: California farmers now must abide by the nation's strictest rules for a widely used pesticide in a change designed to protect farmworkers and people who live and work near agricultural fields but is likely to raise prices
reference_text:
on produce.

The restrictions announced Wednesday target chloropicrin, a pesticide injected into the ground before planting crops such as strawberries, tomatoes and almond orchards. In recent years, the chemical has caused hundreds of people to suffer from irritated eyes, coughing fits and headaches, state officials said.

The new regulations surpass standards required by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

An Emory College German Studies professor has received a national award for her debut book examining the evolution of protagonists in modern Yiddish literature.

Miriam Udel, associate professor of Yidd
reference_text:
ish language, literature and culture, and director of graduate studies at the Tam Institute for Jewish Studies, has won the National Jewish Book Award in Modern Jewish Thought and Experience for her work, Never Better! The Modern Jewish Picaresque.

Udel, who grew up in the Miami area, graduated from Miami-Palmetto High School.

Her book examines Yiddish fiction as it grew out of the Jewish enlightenment of the 18th and 19th centuries — which, like broader literature, was concerned with the repair and improvement of readers — and into a genre less driven by change.

The title gestures at the comic spirit of one of the authors she writes about, Sholem Aleichem. His characters might have answered the question, "How are you?" with a cheerful, "Never better!" even as they feared life might not actually get better.

The genre therefore embraces the Jewish role of outsider or person living at the margins of community. In that

AMSTERDAM Campaigning for the Dutch election began on Wednesday with anti-Islam leader Geert Wilders frontrunner in a vote that will test the anti-establishment sentiment that swept Britain out of the European Union and Donald Trump into the U.S. presidency.

Wilders, a eurosceptic, anti-immigration fan of Trump, has dubbed the March 15 parliamentary election the start of a "Patriotic Spring" in Europe, where French and German voters go to the polls in May and September.

Wilders and his Party for Freedom has led in opinion polls for most of the past two years, but the fragmented political landscape means a coalition government of four or more parties is all but inevitable.

The PVV won 35.7 percent against the center-left's 36.1 percent, with the far-right party, the Freedom Party (PVV), coming second at 27 percent.

prefix_text:
Some Interesting Facts about Nikola Tesla


Did You Know?...

Tesla was considered an eccentric man who talked of death rays that could destroy 10,000 airplanes at a distance of 250 miles.
reference_text:
However, Tesla devised the AC (alternating current) system that we use in our homes today. AC offered great advantages over the rival DC system.

By using Tesla's transformers, AC voltages could be stepped up (or down) and transmitted over long distances through thin wires. DC could not (it required a large power plant every square mile and had to be transmitted through very thick cables). Tesla also invented electric motors that today are used in every appliance in your house. He invented fluorescent bulbs and neon signs. He designed the world's first hydroelectric plant, in Niagara Falls and patented the first speedometer for cars. Thomas Edison, who's money was invested in DC power systems, did his best to discredit Tesla. Edison even went so far as to claimed that AC electricity was far more dangerous than his DC power.

At the 1893 World Exposition in Chicago, Tesla demonstrated the safety AC electricity was by passing high frequency AC power through his body to power light bulbs.

generated_result.0:
However, at his death, he left $2 million to the US government.

Tesla had a strange obsession with flying saucers and other objects, and even designed and built a flying ship that he named the Skyway.

In 1904, he was invited to the US Navy's famous Blue Grass Field on the grounds of White Sands and he flew with the navy, giving them the keys to the ship that he had just created.

Afterward, he sold his share of the flying saucers to the US government.

His work with a computer was groundbreaking. In 1917, Tesla won the most prestigious science award known as the "Nobel Prize" and received a personal note from Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The first ever commercially viable radio frequency was developed by him in 1918 and he began commercial testing by 1923.

He became a leading figure in science and technology. He was credited with coining the term "radio" in 1899.
generated_result.1:
He was also known as "The inventor of electricity."


He invented wireless telegraphy, a form of communication that would have revolutionized human existence and created thousands of jobs and benefits for America.

However, the technology was so new that other nations like England, France, and Germany had already had similar technologies long before Tesla.

In 1882, a wireless telegraphy transmission system was built for England, allowing the nation's citizens to communicate with one another via the air. This was a feat of engineering in its own right!

This same system was built for France in 1901. The French also had their own system, but it was a radio system.

In 1899, Germany built its own radio system which consisted of three main parts. First was a system for all of Germany. Then they sent signals down to the German coast.

And finally, to transmit over long distances, the Germans built a huge telegraph line, much larger
generated_result.2:
That's Not What He Actually said...

Some other interesting facts about Nikola Tesla:

It's believed that Tesla was not the first person to discover that "light has electricity." It was known as the "Voltaic Light Theory" since the first book about it was written in 1891. It was first called "the Law of Conservation of Energy."

In 1891 he was at a scientific conference in Paris which included other scientists including Sir Walter Bulwer-Lytton, Frederick Law Olmsted and Edwin Hubble. The most prominent of the three was Robert Koch, the "Nobel Prize winner in Physics" and head of the U.S. Navy's Office of Naval Research. Koch's wife had been a member of the Royal Society of London and an astronomer. Her son Robert Koch died in 1901 when he was just 30 years old.

BACOLOD CITY, Philippines – Senator Ferdinand Marcos Jr is hoping to drum up support for his vice presidential bid in Negros Occidental, a known bailiwick of Liberal Party (LP) standard bearer Manuel Roxas II, as he campaigned in this city accompanied by his Negrense wife.

The vice presidential candidate was in the capital of Negros Occidental province on Tuesday, April 12, to meet with Bacolod Bishop Vicente Navarra and barangay leaders.

He also called on Negros Occidental Governor Alfredo Marañon Jr., a staunch supporter of Roxas, and Mayor Monico Puentevella at the Provincial Capitol and the People's House.

The province is a known bailiwick of Roxas, whose mother Judy Araneta-Roxas is from Bago City.

Marcos' wife, Louise Araneta-Marcos, also traces her roots to Bago City.

Leader of Bulgarian nationalist Attack party Volen Siderov (R) arrives at Sofia's investigative service building March 12, 2014. REUTERS/Stoyan Nenov

Attack holds the balance of power in the Bulgarian parliament, and its threat is an extreme example of the domestic pressures European governments face in taking a position on the worst crisis in East-West relations since the Cold War.

If the party pulls the plug on Prime Minister Plamen Oresharski's minority coalition government, it could tip the European Union's poorest member state back into political instability. Months of street protests felled one government last year and almost toppled its successor, at a time when the country was struggling to revive economic growth.

Bulgarian leaders' position in relation to the Ukraine crisis is especially precarious. On the one hand, the country has pushed for closer ties with the EU bloc, which it joined seven years ago. On the

Hovsepyan did not elaborate, but Bulgarian Deputy Prime Minister Igor Dodon said the party had made that promise a month ago and that "there is no change in that stance so far".

His remarks were later confirmed by Bulgarian Foreign Minister Daniel Mitov, who said the government supported the call.

Bulgaria's opposition and some business groups are also calling for a parliamentary vote and Hovsepyan said it was crucial to have a chance for the referendum after the Ukraine crisis.

prefix_text: SACRAMENTO — Facing a torrent of accusations, a for-profit company that operates taxpayer-funded online charter schools throughout California has reached a $168.5 million settlement with the state
reference_text:
over claims it manipulated attendance records and overstated its students' success.

The deal, announced Friday by Attorney General Kamala Harris, comes almost three months after the Bay Area News Group published an investigation of K12 Inc., a publicly traded Virginia company, which raked in more than $310 million in state funding over the past 12 years operating a profitable but low-performing network of "virtual" schools for about 15,000 students.

"Knowing that something will be done to address the schools' problems is very reassuring," said Gabriela Novak, who pulled her daughter Elizabeth from K12's San Mateo County school after a year of frustrations and difficulty communicating with her teachers. "Finally, the system is working."

Harris' office found that K12 and the 14 California Virtual Academies used deceptive advertising to mislead families about students' academic progress, parents' satisfaction with the program and their graduates' eligibility for University of California and California State University admission — issues that

generated_result.0:
over claims that it was negligent in overseeing the schools.

The settlement, which was announced by Gov. Jerry Brown on Thursday, was reached this year with a for-profit company called Academa International, Inc., which operates two-dozen "virtual" schools across California.

The schools are run for-profit by the owners' parents and provide education through online, computer-based programs that are free to students, but do not receive any state or local funding.

The suit had been pending for nearly seven years — with its original filing being filed in September 2014 — until the settlement was finalized on Thursday.

The California Department of Education and the California Public Interest Research Group filed suit, accusing Academa of operating a scheme to deceive taxpayers into giving them tuition refunds to reimburse for its expenses.

The settlement says the schools are required by law to follow standards of accountability, set out in an act adopted by the Legislature in 1996 called the Public School Law. The company
generated_result.1:
.

The settlement — the largest of its kind in California — resolves a lawsuit in which more than a dozen parents say they were denied their children's constitutionally required right to receive free and appropriate public education.

The district's charter schools — including those in Irvine, Los Angeles and Long Beach — offered private school options to roughly 350 students with disabilities.

But state law requires the state to pay for each student whose parent enrolls the child as a public school student — regardless of any financial hardship, such as financial aid disbursements.

The plaintiffs' lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Los Angeles, claimed the state violated the Constitution by failing to provide enough state aid, including for private school programs.

More than a dozen of the school's children enrolled in a public school district that was not financially willing to provide tuition for the children with disabilities to attend the private schools.

The settlement does not resolve the plaintiffs' legal claims against their
generated_result.2:
and three California attorneys general over allegations of financial mismanagement and corruption that involved fraud, mismanagement of public records and improper hiring, the companies say.

Co-opting Narratives of the Other


by Yasmine Nagaty

"There's really no such thing as the 'voiceless'. There are only the deliberately silenced,
reference_text:
or the preferably unheard."

This is the famous assertion made by renowned author and political activist Arundhati Roy. The term, "giving voice to the voiceless"- with which we are now all too familiar finds its roots in the contours of classic imperialist thought, where the "civilized" (essentially Western, white connoisseurs of knowledge and development) have gained more of a "self" by going out to "help" communities of the so-called third world. Of course, at the heart of this self-acclaimed charity lies the responsibility of representing the marginalized of those communities.

Representing women (as well as children) continues to be a profitable business for the Western media. Indeed, anthropologists Arthur and Joan Kleinman note that images of distant, suffering women and their children suggest there are communities incapable of or uninterested in caring for its own people. This logic thus suggests the need to re-write the stories of suffering of these

generated_result.0:
the'silenced' or the 'unvoiced' who are deliberately and actively excluded from the mainstream."

– The Black Swan

It's a common practice in film industry, especially for female artists, to have characters speak with an accent rather than a common American English accent. It's a matter of class and cultural capital, a tool for making film more authentic for their audience. For example, it's common to have dialogue be spoken by a character who speaks with the American accent, even though they have not used this accent at all previously in their lives. This is known as 'vocalising'.

In a recent interview on the YouTube channel of the film company The Dark Knight Rises, writer-director Christopher Nolan, who also wrote the script, described the process of vocalising as:

"…using a language that is appropriate for the character and their situation and setting, and then in the writing process of the script, using that language, re-
generated_result.1:
those people who are unable to talk. The ones who couldn't speak but are unable to think, who refuse to listen to an argument or a truth that doesn't fit a narrative that makes their life better. These are the people I'm calling the silent majority. They've done very little for human rights—perhaps very little of any kind—since they were silenced and their voices, and their culture, were used against them. They have had their voices used against them in countless ways, from violence to the suppression of dissent and dissent itself, from the silence of the State to the violence of violence." ―Hajime Isayama, Godzilla (1990)

prefix_text: One of the more common refrains during America's nearly ever-present campaign season is that this election, this year, is the most important of our lives. We documented this in July, noting
reference_text:
that it was first used in one form or another back in 1856, but has been common since at least 1980. Why is each election most important? Well, that's often a bit more nebulous.

According to a new survey from PRRI and The Atlantic, we can describe one way in which voters in 2016 felt this was the most important election in history. Forty-one percent of respondents – including two-thirds of those who voted for Donald Trump – felt that the 2016 election was critical because it was our last chance to "stop America's decline."

The fraction of Hillary Clinton voters who agreed with that sentiment was much smaller, at only a fifth.

Trump himself positioned this election as a final opportunity for his party, at one point telling the Christian Broadcasting Network's David Brody that 2016 was "the last election that the Republicans have a chance of winning" — in part thanks to shifting demographics. The idea of decline clearly also overlaps with the motto embro

generated_result.0:
the fact that Donald Trump is the only candidate in history to have actually won the most votes to appear on the ballot for the presidency — with 688 million, more than anyone but Abraham Lincoln.

And this year, he has been able to do so in a manner that has not been seen in American politics since the Civil War. He is doing all of this through an unprecedented campaign that has managed to bring in millions of new voters into the process — and that's not counting the millions of people who have abandoned the Democratic Party in a massive, coordinated way, to join the Trump camp.

The only reason the vast majority of Trump's supporters aren't already on the other side of the country are the millions of Democrats who abandoned them to embrace the GOP, leaving the GOP at just 20 electoral votes.

But there is one particular, extremely important reason why the election is happening this year instead of the one last year:

That reason is Hillary Clinton.

As
generated_result.1:
that every year, it seems, presidential elections become more important. In 2012, just before the November election, the Pew Research Center found, almost every American over the age of 18 was living in a place that was either "at least somewhat" likely to vote in the presidential election.

As we've noted before, the last time an election was as important as this one was in 2008, after 9/11, and before our national financial collapse. In both 2008 and in 2012, the "happiness" of the American people was also at an all-time high; it was the highest it was in a generation.

The Pew Research Center's numbers show that, despite the fact that this year, most Americans still have to struggle.

Despite the fact that Obama's approval rating is higher than George W. Bush's, the Pew survey finds that most people believe that "he deserves an A." That means that, as much as the president has improved in his sec
generated_result.2:
that Donald Trump's victory last November made Barack Obama's election in 2008 look like an afterthought.

But what if the election wasn't so important? What if our world didn't revolve around it? What if there wasn't so much attention to how it could affect our daily lives and our relationships with the larger world? What if instead we were focused on the ways that American elections, especially the Presidential election, affect the entire country? What if those elections didn't directly impact the course of the United States and the world?

When we look at the 2016 election through this lens, it's hard to deny that it has certainly had an impact, even if one cannot entirely pinpoint its exact extent. We can see the result in the numbers: Donald Trump is now the President-elect, the United States will no longer be a constitutional republic, and the United States has officially switched from an independent sovereign nation to an internationalistic empire. But although it is understandable that South Korean interest in the DPRK is decreasing with time, the fall of the USSR and Berlin Wall both underscore how seemingly unimaginable changes can quickly change realities on the ground. prefix_text: Irony usually conveys a difference between how things seem to be and the reality. As a literary technique it is used when a certain outcome is revealed, but is not what readers were expecting or hoping
reference_text:
for. Irony can be difficult to define; it's often subjective and depends on the audience's expectations.

Take the song "Ironic" by Alanis Morissette. There were many heated debates when it came out over whether the situations described in the song are actually ironic or just unfortunate incidents. And over the years there were more debates about whether the song really is ironic because it's called "Ironic" but nothing in the song is ironic. Confusing? Yes, that's irony.

While it is possible for one person to find something ironc that another person does not, there are several defined categories for irony that apply in life and in literature.

Categories of Irony

There are many ways to play with irony. This is great because it brings added layers and texture to a story. Irony is predominantly defined within three main categories: dramatic irony, situational irony, and verbal irony. Let's have some fun with each.

for.


Example: When a reader discovers, through the events of a book, that the main character, the hero, is an old woman who has suffered a terrible blow or injury (as in the "Hearts in Atlantis" example).


The use of a story line, a fictional character, or a real-life event to create a metaphor is called a "subliminal message".


For more information about the use of this technique as a literary device and in literature, see below.


Example: In a famous "Hercules" comic by Edgar Rice Burroughs, a young man is caught trying to steal a giant boulder. After finding the boulder, he climbs up a cliff, where he realizes that it is an enormous boulder. He runs away and hides the boulder in a well, hoping the "heroes" will come to his rescue. The only problem is that there are three of them, and the first two he has met.

for. I've had to explain to a couple of colleagues how irony is used by the writers in the past. Often the writer will write about how something he or she expects a reader to understand should be different. For example, "What the hell does that have to do with me?" Sometimes it's the fact of the situation that is interpreted as ironic. Or the fact of the character in question. But even if the reader gets something from the reader, it doesn't mean that the writer intended it to be so. The reader is the one who chooses to interpret the situation.

What is the difference between irony and irony of a sarcastic nature? In a sense, irony is about making a point by not being explicit or explicit in pointing out that you are making a point. So it can be a way to set a tone and tone of something or someone. It can mean to comment on something that has become an anachronism. Or it can mean to use something as a

for, or expect or hope for.

The two most famous examples of this are the epilogue to The Great Gatsby and The Godfather. In both cases the truth is depicted in ways that reveal it to be far more than what anyone was expecting, and then the reader is left wondering whether that was how things happened at all.

In this story from John Updike's book The Man Who Knew Too Much, the epilogue is the conclusion of the story, and thus far the end of the story. The ending is the culmination of the journey of the characters, the point at which the characters have to face the consequences of their actions. It is in this sense that it is the ultimate form of irony, because the point of the ending is the resolution of the story: "There was never any need to be saved. What we had done had been folly, and now it was time to do what no wise man had thought, that we migh

prefix_text: OTTAWA — The Ontario government is disputing NDP Leader Tom Mulcair's assertion that the country's largest province supports his plan to create one million $15-a-day child-care spaces.
reference_text:
Ontario's education minister, Liz Sandals, says the province welcomes new investments and interest from "all federal partners" on child care.

But she said Mulcair has not provided sufficient details of his plan — which would require provinces to pick up 40 per cent of the tab — to determine whether Ontario would be prepared to buy in.

The NDP is proposing to create one million child-care spaces over eight years that would be accessible to parents for $15 a day, regardless of income. The federal government would pick up 60 per cent of the cost, which the NDP estimates would cost the federal treasury $5 billion annually once fully implemented.

The NDP says Manitoba, British Columbia and New Brunswick have signalled a willingness to negotiate a shared-cost child-care program.

However, Sandals said Ontario has already spent billions on child care and full-day kindergarten and those investments would have to be recognized "in full" in any national program requiring matching provincial

generated_result.0:
NDP MP Charlie Angus says Ontario is actually "stoked" by the NDP plan and the fact that he won't have to borrow any money from his fellow Canadian provinces to fund it.

At a news conference in Ottawa on Tuesday, Mulcair insisted Quebec has no appetite to sign on to his plan because of the price tag involved in building the facilities.

The NDP leader and his aides also contend Quebecers don't want $15 per day child care because they want to be part of a larger family-friendly Canada.

"When the NDP is talking about $15 a day child care, what they mean is that is the floor," said Angus in the Commons. "Ontario, they say that they are excited by the opportunity to help provide affordable child care and support family-friendly, middle-class families in Ontario."

House Speaker John Boehner was dealt
reference_text:
a major defeat Thursday night. After spending most of the week trying to round up votes for his "Plan B" to extend tax cuts for virtually everyone, he pulled the measure without a vote and sent the House home for Christmas. The clock keeps ticking toward the end of the year, when automatic tax increases and spending cuts are set to hit.

Early Thursday, Boehner expressed confidence not only that his bill would pass but that the Democratic-controlled Senate would feel so much pressure, it would be forced to consider it, too.

"I am not convinced at all that when the bill passes the House today that it will die in the Senate," Boehner said early Thursday.

That was particularly true for conservatives like the House Freedom Caucus, who are opposed to the House GOP budget as written. They say the budget has too much government spending and too little revenue.

prefix_text: In our current culture, millennials move from job to job in order to climb the ladder. The average time spent at a company is just two years. For baby boomers and other generations, this has
reference_text:
not been the norm. Loyalty and dedication to a single company or career drove, and still drives, much of their working lives. AOL's original series Lifers features these dedicated, loyal workers who have been in their jobs for years and years. Will they retire? Are they prepared to?

Fred Vautour, 63, of Waltham, Mass., grew up in a broken home and without a lot of support, and his childhood experiences drove his choices later in life: He knew that he wanted to work "not just for the money but because you want to be your best at what you do."

Vautour ultimately took a job at Boston College as a janitor on the overnight shift. All five of his children went on to be accepted at the prestigious New England college — and because of their father's employment there, they were able to go to school completely free of tuition.

Vautour's job has saved his family more than $700,

generated_result.0:
long been the norm, but in 2016 it seems to be catching up.

This problem, called "migratory withdrawal" or "flow," is actually being exacerbated by a major change in how we work.

"Migration is the primary driver of productivity," says Daniel Kahneman, a cognitive psychologist at Princeton University. "If you change that pattern, it has a deleterious impact on people's lives."

Employers, Kahneman argues, are struggling to adapt to this new reality. They want to make sure that the workers they hire have as much time for "dynamic" tasks as possible to prevent them from losing motivation and making less of an effort. The result is a more efficient workforce.

"It seems to be true that many organizations have been struggling with this problem, with young workers saying, 'I have too much time,'" says Kahneman. "This is a problem that is particularly acute for younger workers."

Migratory
generated_result.1:
meant putting in at least three or four years on the job. But when compared to millennials, this time seems much longer. In fact, millennials spend only 10 years on the job before starting the next job.

Some of the reasons can be put down to a more formal education that prepares us to move from one job to the next. But others come from having a larger pool of choices at our disposal.

As much as millennials want the flexibility of having two careers, they also have a higher expectation of the quality of work that each job can offer, and what those jobs offer is increasingly uncertain. When someone in my family was laid off, we lost a lot of friends, one of whom was my son. He wasn't quite done with school yet, and now we can't take him to see him. In one sense, it was a tragedy; but that's nothing compared to the loss of family.

I see the same story playing out with other friends of mi
generated_result.2:
meant being put through multiple rounds of training and a grueling four- to five-year college experience.

The best way to overcome the transition from one job to the next — to get ahead, or keep a job — is to focus on what you do best. That's why the "best" jobs are so often the ones most fun to do, not the most intellectually demanding. As for what's "the best," the only way to truly know is to do it. So this weekend, you can take one of our most popular fun jobs and see what we mean.

I can only imagine the horror of being evacuated, only to return to your home to see your entire life blown away or burned down. So my good friends at the Scratch DJ Academy have started a fund, to help those who find themselves in dire straits post-Sandy.

This is specifically for the DJ community who may suddenly find themselves in a bad place. It could be that their houses have been destroyed, along with their DJ gear, and now have no means to support their families, especially if DJing is their sole income. I would imagine that any funds raised would go towards immediate financial aid rather than replacing turntables or a record collection – this is about providing the basic necessities for our DJ community when they really need it it.
