prefix_text: The recent development of open-source 3-D printers makes scaling of distributed additive-based manufacturing of high-value objects technically feasible and offers the potential for widespread proliferation of mechatronics education and participation
reference_text: . These self-replicating rapid prototypers (RepRaps) can manufacture approximately half of their own parts from sequential fused deposition of polymer feedstocks. RepRaps have been demonstrated for conventional prototyping and engineering, customizing scientific equipment, and appropriate technology-related manufacturing for sustainable development. However, in order for this technology to proliferate like 2-D electronic printers have, it must be economically viable for a typical household. This study reports on the life-cycle economic analysis (LCEA) of RepRap technology for an average US household. A new low-cost RepRap is described and the costs of materials and time to construct it are quantified. The economic costs of a selection of 20 open-source printable designs (representing less than 0.02% of those available), are typical of products that a household might purchase, are quantified for print time, energy, and filament consumption and compared to low and high Internet market prices for similar products without shipping costs.

Also Known as Alpha-Fetoprotein Test (AFP)

MSAFP is a screening test that examines the level of alpha-fetoprotein in the mother's blood during pregnancy.
reference_text:
This is not a diagnostic test. It is often part of the triple screen test that assesses whether further diagnostic testing may be needed.

What is a screening test?

It is very important to remember what a screening test is before getting one performed. This will help alleviate some of the anxiety that can accompany test results.

Screening tests do not look only at results from the blood test. They compare a number of different factors (including age, ethnicity, results from blood tests, etc…) and then estimate what a person's chances are of having an abnormality.

These tests DO NOT diagnose a problem; they only signal that further testing should be done.

How is the MSAFP performed?

Blood is drawn from veins in the mother's arm and sent off to a laboratory for analysis. Results are usually returned between one and two weeks.

When is MSAFP performed?

MSAFP may be performed between the 14th

Fetoprotein is an extremely small protein found in the fetus that is found in the mother's blood in the first trimester. The hormone testosterone has the most influence on the levels of fetal testosterone, causing the mother's body to make more androgens, which are the chemicals that cause the female reproductive process (menstrual cycle, pregnancy, and lactation). During the first trimester of pregnancy, there is a higher amount of serum testosterone in the mother's blood compared to the mother's body during the fourth trimester of pregnancy.

AFP is similar to FSH but for fetal growth. AFP is used to diagnose growth disorders such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), Down's syndrome, and Turner syndrome (children with an X-linked genetic syndrome) in infants born to pregnant women with a normal PSA.

MSAFP is based on serum samples taken at the start of the third trimester, although the test is useful for detecting any fetal exposure to HIV and, more recently, other sexually transmitted diseases.

A positive MSAFP result results in a positive result for fetal MSAFP. However, as you are not pregnant, the MSAFP test is not a pregnancy test. The MSAFP test will be negative for any HIV exposure, but testing for HIV is expensive and difficult. For HIV exposure, doctors generally recommend routine screening for pregnant women.

What happens if I test positive?

An estimated 1.5 to 1.8 million women were exposed to HIV in 2009. HIV-positive women are particularly vulnerable to developing HIV-infection or the pregnancy-related complications of HIV infection, including preterm

prefix_text: Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) will meet for their eighth primary debate Wednesday evening in Miami, one night after Sanders pulled off a huge upset and narrowly defeated
reference_text:
Clinton in Michigan.

It wasn't that long ago that the Democrats were only supposed to meet for six debates, but both candidates believed it was to their advantage to negotiate for more as it became clear that Sanders was posing a legitimate threat to Clinton's campaign. Their debate Sunday evening in Michigan focused in large part on the lead-contaminated water crisis in Flint, as well as on international trade, but immigration did not come up. That's guaranteed to change on Wednesday, since the debate will be hosted by the Washington Post and Univision, the Spanish-language television network.

Clinton's campaign hopes to blunt Sanders' bid by crushing him in Florida on Tuesday, where recent polls have had her up by 30 points over Sanders. Illinois, Missouri, North Carolina and Ohio also hold their Democratic primaries the same day. Since Florida sends 246 delegates to the Democratic convention this summer, it is by far the biggest prize of the night.

"I don't know where Senator Sanders is coming from on all of this," Clinton said. "He has yet to release anything at all to prove that he's healthy enough to be president."

"Well let's see what we've got," Sanders responded. "The fact that the secretary is the only one for one single-payer health care program for the American people suggests she doesn't know what she's talking about, or maybe she's afraid to stand up and say what she really thinks."

prefix_text:
A portrait gallery at Windsor Castle, royal residence of Charles II. (Image: Public Domain)

On a wood-paneled wall in the Communications Gallery of London's Hampton Court Palace hang 10
reference_text:
portraits in a line. All are of women, and all the women look remarkably similar: frizzy-haired, goggle-eyed, double-chinned, and swathed in great gathered folds of silk. These are the Windsor Beauties—the 17th century equivalent of the Maxim Hot 100.

The Windsor Beauties were chosen to be immortalized because they were the most alluring and powerful women at the court of Charles II, who became king of England, Ireland, and Scotland in 1660. Being selected for a Windsor Beauty portrait meant becoming a celebrity pin-up; copies of the portraits and engraved prints of the women circulated among admirers. Baptist May, Keeper of the Privy Purse and "court pimp," in the words of Samuel Pepys, kept a stash of eight portraits in his private lodgings. Half of the women among those eight were royal mistresses.

And really, at that time, who wasn't carrying on with Charles II

generated_result.0:
,000 pictures – some of the last works of art ever created in a single room.

Among them is a portrait of the Marquess of Westminster, from an engraving made by artist James Murray, which has been used as the official portrait of the monarch.

But the original painting remains in the Royal Gallery in Westminster, where it's expected to remain for centuries.

One thing the new royal residences lack, however, are traditional portraits. They've also got a new addition to their collection of artworks, namely one of a man in a blue coat.

That's because Charles II, now King George II, bought the artwork from an English collector in 1757.

It was then exhibited at the British Museum in London, where it was hung as a portrait of the monarch.

Now it's on display at Windsor Castle, a private residence built for the monarch by Prince George.

Its walls are covered with artworks from the Romantic
generated_result.1:
paintings inspired by Royal Art collections, from 17th and 18th century artworks to contemporary.

It includes a portrait gallery of artists from the 17th to 19th centuries, and an exhibition titled 'The Artists' Palace', in which 16th and 17th-century artists are seen working with a model in their studios.

prefix_text: In an undercover federal sting made public Thursday, two Bay Area genetic testing companies were found to offer information that is "misleading and of little or no practical use" to consumers who purchase their tests to
reference_text:
gain insight into their health risks.

Although Navigenics of Foster City, and 23andMe of Mountain View defended their businesses, they and two other companies were blasted by investigators from the U.S. Government Accountability Office for drawing unsupportable conclusions from the gene samples they analyzed and making health predictions that didn't always jibe with their customers' actual medical conditions.

When one investigator posing as a consumer asked whether her test data implied she was in danger of getting breast cancer, a Navigenics representative replied, "you'd be in the high risk of pretty much getting it," according to a GAO report made public at a congressional hearing Thursday.

The GAO said experts it consulted called the Navigenics' remark "horrifying" because "it erroneously implies that the tests can diagnose breast cancer and could needlessly alarm consumers."

The gene tests, which can cost consumers thousands of dollars in some cases, have come under increasing fire in recent

generated_result.0:
determine whether the individuals they're seeking in a relationship may be biologically related.

In addition to the California companies, two of the largest private labs in the country — the Utah-based Illumina and the Seattle-based 23andMe — were also found to provide inaccurate, misleading, or false information in their tests.

This marks the first time the information has been provided for consumers to make informed choices about potentially romantic partners, according to the Institute for Responsible Genetics, which developed the new guidelines.

"For couples who have an existing romantic relationship, you have to make sure that the test has enough information to decide whether you're compatible or not," said the group's CEO, Dr. Joseph LeDoux.

The organization also recommends that people using the test seek advice from a genetic counselor, who could provide them with an objective opinion about the information they have received.

Many private labs that provide these types of tests have never been accredited to provide information

determine their risk of certain diseases and genetic disorders, according to the Department of Health and Human Services.

Under the proposed rules, which the federal agency is set to adopt next year, genetic testing companies would be required to provide a list of diseases or genetic disorders that they determine could be passed from parents or siblings to a fetus from conception. That list would include, for example, the genetic risk of Down syndrome, Huntington's disease, cystic fibrosis, autism spectrum disorder, mental retardation, a number of blood disorders and many others.

The Federal Register notice of proposed rules, to be published in the Federal Register on Sept. 5, would also require testing companies to notify consumers that the information on their tests is not always accurate or reliable. generated_result.2:
find out the source of their own genetic material.

"We feel like it's an affront to consumers to have this kind of information that has nothing to do with consumer protection," says Michael Hansen, senior counsel at the Center for Genetics and Society, an Oakland-based nonprofit group that advocates for the rights of consumers and consumers' rights to privacy.

The information provided by the companies – including the tests' pricing – did not have to be disclosed by the companies, Hansen says. The testing companies also were able to offer no guarantee that customers would not suffer financial losses as a result of their results.

The testing companies in question – Genetic Health Services and Quest Diagnostics – have a large number of customers, but they've also expanded rapidly in recent years. Overview of the basic differences between Gods, Demons, Aedra, and Daedra

reference_text:

The designations of Gods, Demons, Aedra, and Daedra, are universally confusing to the layman. They are often used interchangeably.

"Aedra" and "Daedra" are not relative terms. They are Elvish and exact. Azura is a Daedra both in Skyrim and Morrowind. "Aedra" is usually translated as "ancestor," which is as close as Cyrodilic can come to this Elven concept. "Daedra" means, roughly, "not our ancestors." This distinction was crucial to the Dunmer, whose fundamental split in ideology is represented in their mythical genealogy.

Aedra are associated with stasis. Daedra represent change.

Aedra created the mortal world and are bound to the Earth Bones. Daedra, who cannot create, have the power to change.

two others, Aesculapius's and El'Jonson's Daedric Princes, are the same book.

The Aedra (gods of the sky) are more ancient than the other Gods. The first Aedra are often identified as the gods of the sky, and therefore the primary rulers of the realms of the sky. The Aedra are divided into two main schools, those that believe the first Aedra were creations of the Aedra-Almighty and that they had nothing to do with mortals and those who believe the Aedra-Almighty created the Aedra. Those who believe that the Aedra-Almighty created the Aedra, and are therefore known as the Gods, are often called Daedra. the other is called Gods, Demons and Aedra. The second is for Oblivion and Daedra and the other is for Skyrim.

I would like to present three concepts that are closely related to each other, but may not always be the same in a particular area, because they are based on different aspects of reality, in some cases different aspects of one existence (like Heaven and Hell).

God, Demiurge, Demon (Demo-God or Daemon-God or God-God), or Aedra (Divine entity with two faces).

Daedra (Demi-Daedra or God-Daedra or Daemon-Daedra) (demons, gods, gods of the mortal realm, or even god-demons.)

Demons are created out of the elements, and have souls. The Da

should not be confused with the Tarer's Diagram.

The Aedra and Daedra are the four basic types of magical beings known to us.

Aedra are immortal and the creators of our material world, the deities themselves, the divine beings, the divine powers, the gods of our pantheons and cultures, and the deities of our Daedric Princes.

There are four kinds of Daedra:

Azura: the Moon Goddess of the Seven Daedric Princes. Azura embodies the feminine principle of love and mercy. Azura's worship is the primary cause of most disputes between Daedra, and she is revered as the patron goddess of both sexes and all beings.

Salar de Uyuni

Salar de Uyuni, Bolivia is the world's largest salt flat at 10,582 sq km (4,086 sq mi). It is a
reference_text:
much sought after film location particularly for car and beauty commercials. Documentaries have also been filmed on the subject of the landscape, wildlife, and local mining industry (an estimated 50% of the world's lithium comes from Salar de Uyuni).

The southwestern town of Uyuni is the main entry point for shooting the salt flats.

Getting there you would first fly into La Paz. If you are travelling light then you can fly into Joya Andina Airport in Uyuni. If you are a larger production, you will need to transport your team and gear by land from La Paz to Uyuni which takes around 8hrs. Salar de Uyuni is a short drive away from the town of Uyuni.

Film permits to shoot at the Salar de Uyuni are quick and easy to obtain.

When To Shoot?

April to October is the best period to film salt-crusted dry lake looks

generated_result.0:
hot, dry land with a temperate climate with temperate rain season in April to October. The rain season typically lasts for 12 months from November to May. Salar de Uyuni (pronounced 'Sha-righ-uh-ee-un') is located at the top of the Americas, just south of the Equator in the north central, southwestern and northeastern parts of South America.

The world's largest salt flat, Salar de Uyuni, is located in Bolivia, in the middle of the tropical southern plains and is one of the most important salt flat sites in the world. It is a complex of a series of low salt domes, called domes de salt, that cover the highest lands of the flat as seen from space. Salar de Uyuni's high dome region has an average elevation of 2,567 feet (622 meters) and a mean height above sea level of 2,890 feet (927 meters).

sub-arctic plain which has the same latitude as the Mexican border. Its altitude is 6.25 km (3.6 mi). The salt flats are home to over 120 species of endemic birds of prey.

Photo credits: Salar de Uyuni Salt Flat (Courtesy of G.J. Soto / www.paleontology.net)

Salar de Uyuni is a World Heritage Site. The World Heritage Committee recognized Salar de Uyuni as a World Heritage Site on 23 November 2003.

Facts about Salar de Uyuni

This is the world's largest salt flat and the world's second largest salt flat. It is in the western portion of the Andes Mountains and is 6.25 km long and 3.6 km wide.

The salt flat contains over 120 species of endemic birds of prey.

The salt flats is home to over 120 species of endemic bird species.

prefix_text: The WHO is the world's leading health organisation guiding governments around the world. So we expect their advice to be up to date and evidence-based, particularly on controversial topics. One of the most controversial
reference_text:
topics of our time is the international community's approach to drug policy, particularly that relating to the most popular so-called "illegal" drug – cannabis. Yet the WHO's advice on the harms and (lack of) benefits of cannabis is based on a decision made 82 years ago, by its predecessor, the League of Nations. Thankfully, there is now hope that this is about to change.

The WHO advises the UN, which states international control of drugs – so the view of the WHO really matters. The reality is that almost every country in the world (197 in total) sign up to follow WHO advice and so its current stance means punitive measures for cannabis – including lifetime in prison in some countries. Cannabis is still scheduled as having the highest level of harm and no medical value, despite reams of evidence to contrary. It is significantly less harmful than alcohol and shows real medical benefit, particularly in the treatment of pain, spasticity, and some forms of epilepsy. Due to

issues on which the WHO provides advice is whether the use of medical marijuana is safe and well-tolerated, given the absence of any long-term safety data to support its use.

"In this issue of The Lancet, we have tried to address the uncertainties about this issue and to provide the best possible care to our patients. I hope our message to the public and to governments will serve as a good guidance for them," says Dr Peter Piot, an international professor of neurology at the University of Oxford who chaired the WHO's committee on the use of medical marijuana.

questions to be asked in the forthcoming debate is the use of GMO food for human consumption, and whether its development is environmentally or socially responsible.

But this is not simply a matter for science. This is a debate about what kind of a future society we want. As the World Health Organisation put it, a world where food is more nutritious, and where people can grow food that is safe to eat is one we should pursue. But the GMO debate has been framed as a clash of values between the values of people seeking a good life and values of a certain kind of society. This is not only misleading, it may be counter-productive.

I do not think it is fair to frame this debate in terms of competing views on values in the 21st century. The GMO debate is, essentially, an issue of science and ethics - an issue about how to best produce food for healthy humans while also providing the basic necessities of life, such as soil and water.

prefix_text: Free trade and the freedom of capital to move across borders have been the cutting edge of globalization. They've also led to the succession of crises that have led to the widespread questioning of capitalism as a way
reference_text:
of organizing economic life — and of its paramount ideological expression, neoliberalism.

The protests against capitalism at the recent G20 meeting in Hamburg may seem superficially the same as those which marked similar meetings in the early 2000s. But there's one big difference now: Global capitalism is in a period of long-term stagnation following the global financial crisis. The newer protests represent a far broader disenchantment with capitalism than the protests of the 2000s.

Yet capitalism's resilience amidst crisis must not be underestimated. For trade activists, in particular, who've been on the forefront of the struggle against neoliberalism and globalization over the last two decades, there are a number of key challenges posed by the conjuncture.

Neoliberalism's Surprising Strength

First is the surprising strength of neoliberalism.

In this book, I look at some of the key questions that have emerged in this post-industrial society and argue for a return to a vision of a world with a more sustainable and equitable distribution of wealth and power.

The book is divided into six parts, which focus on four major themes:

1. The question of the nature of work.

2. The question of the impact of globalisation on the global commons.

3. The question of the future of work and the relationship of work to life.

4. The question of the political economy of work.

5. The political economy of work: A new synthesis.

6. Toward a new political economy of work: A return to a liberal vision of the economy.

Economists at the University of California, Berkeley, and Princeton recently released a study that found that the U.S. economy lost 5 percent of its gross domestic product between 2000 and 2010 -- a period that saw a wave of "recovery" from the 2000 economic collapse.

The authors said the rise of globalization has had a dramatic impact on U.S. manufacturing. A wave of factory closures and other measures to shift manufacturing to China, India, and elsewhere have left many U.S. manufacturing workers in search of new jobs.

reference_text: ological singularity". History Use of the term "the singularity" in this context appears to have originated with the science fiction writer, Vernor Vinge, in 1993. See here for details. Vinge describes the singularity as follows: It is a point where our old models must be discarded and a new reality rules. - http://www.ugcs.caltech.edu/~phoenix/vinge/vinge-sing.html Problems The problem with using the term "the singularity" is that the phenomena in question doesn't look very singular. We are certainly in the middle of a period of exponential growth - and the rate of progress shows little sign of slowing its rate of increase. However, exponential curves simply don't have "singular" points on them. Look at an exponential curve at any point, and it appears self-similar - no part of it is much different from any other point. This misapprehension, I believe, leads many to think that we cannot foresee the future because the technology is not yet mature enough to support the social and economic transformations predicted. That is not the case. The future of technology will be shaped both by its natural evolution and by social, ethical, and political transformations. However, the technologies of our world must evolve in response to social and economic changes, and the technology we have today will not be the only technology we will have in the future. In the current situation, technologies such as autonomous cars, genetic editing, nanotechnology, artificial intelligence, robotics, and the Internet of Things (IoT) will have to evolve in a variety of directions. However, the technology needed to transform society in the near future is not yet mature enough to support the social and economic transformations predicted. Technology will, however, have to evolve, but only in a direction consistent with the economic transformation that we are already witnessing. The technological singular
generated_result.1: logical singularity". It's my belief that this is a mistake - a misconstrued notion of what is intended by the singularity. As a philosophical and scientific outlook, technology is a process. Technology can always be improved upon, but it's not a singularity. It's not the ultimate, unchanging state of the universe. It's an evolution and change, much more subtle than "singularity". It's a process, not a point in time. Instead of a singularity, it can be described as a time of a "singularity". This is more accurate. I think this is not a word to be thrown around lightly, and I know it's often misunderstood. There will always be new developments, like quantum computing, or more energy efficient materials that will make your car run better, faster, and longer than before. TechnoNations was the first to propose this term in 1988, and the term "technological singularity" has become a standard term in futurism ever since. The Singularity is a major conceptual framework and concept for considering the future. The word "singularity" has various meanings and connotations. For most people, it refers to the idea of accelerating technological advance that occurs at the rate of 10^12 revolutions per day (the number of atoms in the universe). On Tuesday morning it was announced that an agreement had been reached between Iran and the six powers—the US, UK, Russia, China, Germany and France.

The deal centres on Tehran's
reference_text:
acceptance of strict limits on its nuclear activities for 10 years. These are supposed to ensure that the country remains a minimum of 12 months away from amassing enough nuclear fuel for a bomb. After the 10-year period, those constraints will ease in the subsequent five years.

In exchange, the West will lift - though not immediately - tough sanctions on Iran.

Q: How historic is the deal?

A: On January 29, 2002, President George W Bush lumped Iran together with Iraq and North Korea as part of a so-called "Axis of evil". Thirteen years on, President Obama welcomed the deal as an opportunity to be seized and said it made the world safer. When the countries announced a preliminary deal earlier this year in Lausanne, most commentators were surprised.

Q: What has Iran agreed to?

A: According to the 159-page agreement, it has agreed to cut by two-thirds to 5,060 its centrif

The deal's text was approved by Russia and China, who have both been heavily critical of the previous US sanctions that blocked progress in nuclear negotiations.

However, the US and Israel had initially threatened to veto the deal, after it was struck on 7 October.

This morning they announced that they are officially abandoning their plans to build a coal terminal at Port Westward.

Sightline's research was instrumental in the debate. We published extensive documentation of Kinder Morgan's problems with coal dust at their terminals, as well as the company's lengthy rap sheet of fraud, illegal dumping, and lax safety. A month after we published our research, the utility PGE announced that it would not sublease its land at Port Westward to Kinder Morgan out of concern that the spread of coal dust would damage its gas turbines. Abnormality of grammar is the idea that some forms of a grammar aren't needed in English, or even in the common tongue. It's an explanation for why certain words don't have an English equivalent - like the French "parler", which is pronounced with a different pronunciation.

Another innovation is to treat a form of English as if it were another language. Many people may think of "language" as the use of words in different scripts. For example, the word "English" is used in Latin scripts, but we use it also in many non-Latin scripts (like Japanese).

In fact, as of now, 2015 is a whopping 0.1°C (0.17°F) hotter than last year, which itself was the hottest year on record.

prefix_text: Mayor Rahm Emanuel's administration is moving to the second phase of its effort to lure providers of super-fast, 1-gig Internet to Chicago, and it's offering potentially a very big carrot
reference_text:
to get them: the use of everything from the roof of City Hall to light poles and sewer tunnels.

In an action that's been expected for a while but is still significant, the city tomorrow is posting a solicitation for interested parties to list their bona fides, known as a request for qualifications. Once interested parties are cut down to a short list, the city will issue a request for bids.

The RFQ will be on the city's website at CityofChicago.org/bids.

The city began the process more than a year ago by asking interested parties to give their ideas about how to design a bid, and a healthy two dozen groups reportedly responded. But its goal remains the same: to attract super-fast Internet to certain neighborhoods in an effort to give Chicago a leg up in an increasingly competitive world.

The city says it wants bidders, at least initially, in seven neighborhoods: the Loop, West Loop and River North in the

generated_result.0:
.

According to a draft plan unveiled by the mayor's office Thursday, the first phase of the effort would allow for new and existing providers to use "a 'tiered' network that enables new providers to reach underserved areas while maintaining an established network that ensures the availability of the same high-speed service for existing providers."

That's an interesting proposal for Illinois, where an incumbent broadband provider has to carry all of the capacity to the customer's home. Under the current system, there's no way to expand an existing provider to offer faster speeds without the use of extra capacity. Under the plan's framework, however, an ISP would be required to build new connections to its existing subscribers if it decided to increase the speed.

In short, the move would potentially create an incentive for incumbent providers to upgrade their service and make customers better off.

The city is expected to have selected the companies by mid-November and a contract could be signed in September. After it does, the city would work with the companies to offer the best possible service to Chicagoans in the Chicago area.

Overview

Social Institutions

The Social Institutions and Gender Index (SIGI) measures gender-based discrimination in social norms, practices and laws across 160 countries. The SIGI comprises country profiles, a classification of countries and a database; it serves as a research, policy and advocacy tool for the development community and policy makers. The SIGI covers five dimensions of discriminatory social institutions, spanning major socio-economic areas that affect women's lives: discriminatory family code, restricted physical integrity, son bias, restricted resources and assets, and restricted civil liberties. The SIGI's variables quantify discriminatory social institutions such as unequal inheritance rights, early marriage, violence against women, and unequal land and property rights.

A building at 55 Broadway, in lower Manhattan, is home to the Lower Manhattan Security Coordination Center, the locus
reference_text:
of the New York Police Department's massive, intelligence-gathering activities. According to a 2011 estimate, the facility integrates not only some 1,000 NYPD cameras located in lower Manhattan and some 700 cameras in midtown, but an additional 2,000 private surveillance cameras owned by Wall Street firms. These cameras are principally focused on capturing license plate data. The center cost an estimated $150 million to set up.

While Mayor Michael Bloomberg and NYPD Commissioner Raymond Kelly endlessly tout the value of Manhattan's "ring of steel," modeled after the security infrastructure of London's financial district, they reveal little as to its role tracking car traffic in the city. Both back the department's Domain Awareness System (DAS), which can track individuals or incidents (e.g., a suspicious package) through live video feeds from some 3,000 CCTV cameras, 2,600 radiation substances detectors, check license plate numbers, pull up crime reports and cross-check all information against criminal and terrorist databases.

prefix_text: Combine and Conquer Combining sutureless lamellar keratoplasty, phacoemulsification, and IOL implantation in one surgery allows rapid visual rehabilitation in patients with catar
reference_text:
act and corneal opacity By Tushar Agarwal and Pooja Bandivadekar

At a Glance Phacoemulsification in patients with corneal opacity can be a challenge – patients with central but superficial opacity and concomitant cataract are common, yet do not typically require a full-thickness transplant

Conventional lamellar keratoplasty has issues, too – problems such as infection and suture-related astigmatism can make outcomes unpredictable

The use of biological glue to adhere the graft to the host cornea can bypass the problem of sutures, and has seen success when performed as a standalone procedure for treating corneal opacity

Combining cataract surgery with automated sutureless anterior lamellar keratoplasty can provide rapid vision rehabilitation, and make phacoemulsification more straightforward for the surgeon

Performing phacoemulsification in a patient with corneal opacity

generated_result.0: act or glaucoma, or in the face of advanced disease. 2. The Procedure: Patients With Cataract and Glaucoma are treated with a combination of the procedures that have the least number of complications, namely the sutureless lamellar keratoplasty, phacoemulsification, and IOL implantation. The patients are either left eye sutured on one side of the eyelid, and the other side of the eye treated with sutureless lamellar keratoplasty on the opposite side of the eye, or right eye sutured on the opposite side of the eye and the IOL implantation is placed on the opposite side of the eye. All patients have good visual outcome after the procedure. In the case of cataract, glaucoma, or other disease that has progressed to a stage that requires an IOL implantation, we recommend that the IOL implantation is placed in the opposite side of th

For this reason, surgeons with a background in ophthalmology should consider combining IOL implants with lamellar sutureless sutureless retinoblastoma for those patients who present with cataracts, as well as in patients with retinoblastomas that have a macular type of cataract or high-risk retinoblastoma.

act-telangiectasias [49].

This was accomplished by the use of multiple surgical techniques (including ophthalmic, surgical, laser, and electrical, cataract, and other surgeries) [48]. In addition to performing the surgical approach, the team emphasized a multidisciplinary approach. For example, all the team members had prior experience with cataract, rheumatology, and physical therapy. The outbreaks of police violence at a handful of polling locations served to heighten tensions in the Catalan capital, potentially boosting turnout for a vote that could have significant consequences for the autonomous region's future, and that of Mariano Rajoy's Spanish government.

After polls closed Rajoy made a televised address reiterating that voters had been tricked by Catalonia's political leaders, and that the national police had simply responded in accordance with their orders.

Ricard Gene, 56, a commercial lawyer who had volunteered to help at a polling station inside the Miquel Tarradell secondary school in Barcelona's Ciutat Vella - or Old City - said he was shocked by the images of violent police tactics that played out across his city, as ordinary citizens sought to vote in a referendum that Spain's constitutional court had already declared illegal.

reference_text:
Managua, on June 14, 2013. Workers were set to break ground on the $50 billion project on Monday. Inti Ocon / AFP / Getty Images

Workers were set to break ground Monday for the construction of Nicaragua's controversial $50 billion canal linking the Pacific Ocean and the Caribbean Sea. The mega-project — widely reported as the world's largest civil engineering enterprise — has been shrouded in secrecy and has outraged farmers, indigenous communities and citizens around the country. Vice President Moisés Omar Halleslevens and Chinese firm HKND Group inaugurated the canal in a ceremony in the southwestern municipality of Rivas, Nicaraguan media reported.

The canal, scheduled for completion in December 2019, will cut across the middle of the country and bisect Lake Nicaragua, known locally as Lake Colcibolca — the second-largest lake in Latin America and the largest drinking-water reservoir in the region. US does not have to hand over all its evidence against Dotcom and three colleagues, says appeals court in New Zealand

US prosecutors have won a court case that brings them a step closer in their
reference_text:
attempts to have the Megaupload founder and three of his colleagues extradited from New Zealand.

The appeals court in Wellington overturned an earlier ruling that would have allowed Kim Dotcom and the others broad access to evidence in the case against them at the time of their extradition hearing, which is scheduled for August. The four are accused of facilitating massive copyright fraud through the internet filesharing site.

The court ruled that extensive disclosure would bog down the process and that a summary of the US case would suffice.

Dotcom, a German national, says he is innocent and cannot be held responsible for others using the site to illegally download songs and films. Along with him, US prosecutors are seeking the extraditions of Finn Batato, Mathias Ortmann and Bram van der Kolk, each of whom held senior positions at Megaupload before American authorities shut the site down in 2012.

Dotcom, who faces more than 60 counts in the United States of copyright infringement, money laundering and racketeering, had wanted the New Zealand authorities to hand over the documents so they could be used to counter charges brought against Megaupload and four other alleged co-conspirators.

Judge James Orenstein's decision means that those documents cannot be handed over at a future date when he decides whether to keep Dotcom behind bars.

reference_text:
U.S. cities.

The measure, backed by Mayor Michael Bloomberg, Council Speaker Christine Quinn and Health Commissioner Thomas Farley, passed 43 to 8 yesterday.

E-cigarettes, battery-operated tubes that simulate the effect of smoking by producing nicotine vapor, may be a gateway to smoking regular cigarettes and make quitting harder, Quinn said. The law would take effect in four months, said Jamie McShane, a spokesman for the speaker.

Proponents say e-cigarettes don't produce the toxic and carcinogenic byproducts found in second-hand smoke. Users, who call the practice "vaping," turn to e-cigarettes to wean themselves off regular ones and shouldn't be stigmatized, according to a pro-industry website funded by NJOY Inc. a Scottsdale, Arizona-based e-cigarette maker.

But public health advocates and health policy experts have called on cities to ban vaping across town from a variety of reasons, including the health risks it poses.

prefix_text: The FTC enforces the Eyeglass Rule and Contact Lens Rule, which give you the right to get a prescription from your eye doctor – whether you ask for it or not – at no extra charge
reference_text:
. That allows you to shop around and look for the best deal.

Your Rights and Your Prescription

Your eye doctor must give you your contact

lens prescription after your fitting. It's the law.

Your eye doctor must give you your eyeglass

prescription after your exam. It's the law.

What are my rights under the FTC's Eyeglass and Contact Lens Rules?

If you get a fitting for glasses or contact lenses, the eye doctor must give you a copy of your prescription – whether you ask for it or not. It's the law. The doctor can't require you to pay an extra fee, buy eyeglasses or contact lenses, or sign a waiver or form.

Why would I want my prescription for glasses or contacts?

You have a choice. You don't have to buy glasses or contacts from your eye doctor. You can use the prescription to buy glasses or contacts wherever they

generated_result.0:
and at your own risk.

What Are Contact Lens Reviews And Ratings?

Contact lens reviews are the best way to know what the eye doctor thinks. They're also very useful if you are not sure whether the lens will fit.

Most contact lens reviews on websites such as eyewearreviews.com are very informative and detailed and may include the following:

Specifications including lens size, the type of lenses it's made for, and the manufacturer.

The name and address of the eye doctor who has prescribed it.

Other information such as color of lens, manufacturer's warranties and any contact lens recalls that have been issued.

Are Contact Lens Reviews Always Right?

No. Contact lens reviews can sometimes be incomplete or misleading. To be sure, you should always talk to the eye doctor first. If you are uncertain about the lens you received, contact the Eye Institute at eyeinstitute.org or call 1-800-9
generated_result.1:
. You may have been told the same thing the first time you saw your doctor, or maybe you've been told it by your family doctor, but now it's the law.

If you haven't already, go to the website of your local optometry office, and find out if the lens requirements of the ADA in your state apply to you. The rules vary from state to state and can be found on the Optometric Practice Act website. Check out their website and/or your state's agency website to make sure you're covered.

What if you don't have a prescription from your eye doctor?

If you're blind and can't get an eye exam at a health care facility, you might be able to have an appointment or order an eyeglasses online. There are several services that can help you get your glasses:
generated_result.2:
to you. To get your prescription filled, you must ask your eye doctor. If you don't, you'll get an eyeglass prescription without your authorization. (You can request a prescription, but you must do so before you buy a new lens.)

This section is for people who have glasses and need corrective lenses. It contains rules similar to what you'd find in a medical professional's manual, such as:

You should tell your doctor if you wear contact lenses or prescription glasses. And you must take them off during the day or immediately after you leave a room.

You may be covered by this rule even if your contact lenses are under the prescription of your eye doctor. That's because your doctor prescribes lenses for the condition you'll be wearing them for. And even if your contact lenses are off, your doctor will check them for proper wearing.

You'll only get corrective lenses from your doctor if they are prescribed by your eye doctor.

Princeton offers early-action admission to 714 students for Class of 2018

Princeton University has offered admission to 714 students from a pool of 3,854 candidates who applied through single
reference_text:
-choice early action for the Class of 2018.

Princeton's undergraduate admission office mailed notification letters to students Dec. 16, and the decisions were available to applicants via secure online access on the same day.

"The strength of the applicant pool was impressive, and the admitted students displayed outstanding academic accomplishments and a diverse set of talents and interests," Dean of Admission Janet Rapelye said. "Early action applications increased by 1 percent this year, and we admitted 18.5 percent of candidates compared with 18.3 last year."

This is the third year since 2006 that the University has offered an early application round for prospective students whose first college choice is Princeton. Applicants may apply early only to Princeton, and if admitted, they can wait to decide whether to accept Princeton's offer until the end of the regular admission process in the spring.

Of the students accepted through early action this year, 8 percent are international students, and 41 percent are U.S. students

This article is by staff writer Honey Smith.

Given that student loan debt in the U.S
reference_text:
. tops $1.2 trillion and the average graduate owed over $30,000 in 2015, it's no surprise topics like how to start paying student loans are necessary.

However, if you're still in school or are still saving for college (or you have kids or grandkids in that category), there's an option for reducing or eliminating the amount of student loans you take out: apprenticeship programs.

What is an apprenticeship program?

The basic idea behind apprenticeships is that students/apprentices learn by doing. While apprenticeships used to be a very common way for people to train for a wide variety of professions, as higher education became ubiquitous, the apprenticeship model fell out of fashion.

However, both universities and employers are starting to recognize that practicing skills in a real-life setting reinforces classroom learning, makes students more employable upon graduation, and can reduce student indebtedness. #Win-win-win.

How do apprenticeship

generated_result.0:
. exceeds $1 trillion, an influx of students to graduate schools and universities could have substantial implications for future economic growth.

But what about the money that is being loaned to these students?

A new report from the Center for College Affordability and Productivity (CCAP) offers a new way to evaluate student loan debt — by looking at the actual amount of money that students borrowed and borrowed in order to graduate.

While student loans typically represent between 1.7% to 3.6% of the total debt owed, a $10,000 loan to buy a book or a certificate of appreciation can be expected to cost between $1,900 and $4,400 in borrowing costs. And a $60,000 loan to a college — which is typically what students borrow — can cost between $25,000 and $100,000, the CCAP report shows.

The CCAP data includes both "borrowing for school" and "b

Unfortunately, the loans themselves are not the only thing students are going to be saddled with for their education expenses.

While they are getting their money from tuition, loan payments, or both, students also have to pay to put them in college, so let's examine some of the other expenses that students have to pay as well.

Tuition

Tuition is the cost of sending your child to school, as well as the cost of taking the kid out of their parents' homes for the school year.

This is how it breaks down:

Tuition (school year, average price)

A new report from the University of California, Berkeley's Graduate School of Education shows that student loan debt has grown by more than 40 percent since 2009 – almost one-third.

The average amount of debt held by a doctoral student today is around $57,000, an amount that has only been rising since 2009 and which could rise further over the next two years, according to GSS' latest analysis.

And because of their graduate status, graduate students make significantly more than all other students by a staggering margin:

For the 10 percent of students with graduate degrees, the average student loan balance is $42,800. While this figure is roughly double the amount of student debt held by those with undergraduate degrees, it is still significantly lower than the average student loan balance – $70,000 – held by all other graduate students.

reference_text:
and study in the U.S. without fear of deportation.

Hansen proved quite wrong, of course, failing to anticipate the postwar economic boom (including both strong population growth—the baby boom—and rapid technological progress). their homes, and lifestyles, Brodie has captured a marginalized segment of the American population that's not so prevalent in main stream society.

His haunting photos of hobos, punks, and squatters criss-crossing the country in boxcars are reminiscent of Horace Bristol's Grapes of Wrath era pics

That festival now is hosted annually on the third Saturday in March.

At the "Polaroid Kidd" Festival, we look at the early days of the Alaska Railroad and it's beginnings with the construction of an Alaska Rail Trail in the 1850's.

You'll see the very first railway car in this town as well as many famous railway men like Ed Koch and Fred Riesen.


The Polaroid Kidd will bring you the stories of the railroad pioneers, like Frederick Riesen who is still active today, his famous railroad trips on the Alaska Rail Trail and how one of the greatest men to have ever lived, Fred Riesen, traveled with his friend and rail historian, Mike Brodie, to Alaska for the film.

He also worked at the Los Angeles World's Fair and the Los Angeles City Hall Library. is not a collection of all the pictures taken on the railway system. Each photo is placed in its own entry of the collection, with links to more pictures.

prefix_text: While today's cord cutters are replacing their former TV-viewing activities with popular streaming services like Netflix, Amazon and Hulu, the shift away from linear television on to on-demand, online streams
reference_text:
has allowed a variety of niche services to pop up, too. Available for a few more dollars per month, viewers now have the option of further customizing their over-the-top video content bundles by subscribing to both premium and niche services offering everything from high-quality television drama, as with HBO NOW's original programming; kids' fare, as with Nick's Noggin; or, more recently, made-for-TV movies as with Lifetime's new video-on-demand app; and much more.

The problem, of course, with the unbundling of content in this manner is that you'll soon reach the point where your monthly expenditures on streaming video are no longer cheaper than cable TV.

still continues, according to Nielsen.

Nielsen found that 55% of Americans — or approximately 5.3 million households — had cord cutting between 2011 and 2014. While this number still accounts for nearly a fifth of the US population, it is a drop from the 54% that Nielsen reported as a result of cord cutting between 2005 and 2007.

In 2016, the trend continued with 55% of the US population — or 5.1 million households — being cord cutters.

With only a few exceptions, cord cutting has been going up in recent years.

The first-ever Nielsen Nielsen Cable Tracker released in 2015 found that the average subscriber viewing hours has increased by an average of 22% over the course of the same decade.

Despite the decline in television subscribers, cable bills are still soaring as more people cut the cord and pay for streaming services.

prefix_text: After his rise to power in 1933, Hitler led Germany on a mission of invasion and occupation. He had instilled into the country a desire for expansion in Europe, and in the years leading up to
reference_text:
the Second World War, he expanded the army far beyond what was agreed in the Treaty of Versailles. This was the treaty which followed the end of the First World War – it caused Germany to undergo significant disarmament, and forbade the country from forming allegiances and invading other territories.

The Treaty of Versailles included some terms which many Germans considered unduly harsh, and bred a feeling of resentment in the German population. The fiscal depressions of the 1920s and early 30s caused almost all European economies to collapse, meaning that Germany was unable to pay the extortionate reparation fees that had been set in the Treaty, and other countries – in particular, the USA – began to act with more lenience towards Germany. The Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh's (RSS) attempts at re-writing Dalit history has drawn sharp criticism from scholars and activists.

As part of its

efforts to aggressively push the Hindu nationalist agenda and consolidate the Hindu vote, the RSS has sought to introduce communal overtones to the origins of caste in a never-before-heard-of take on Dalit history.

In three recently released books on the subject, top RSS leaders have held foreign invaders responsible for the emergence of certain castes. The books, authored by BJP spokesperson Vijay Sonkar Shastri, were released earlier this month by RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat. RSS leaders have written the preface for all three books.

According to a report in the Hindustan Times, top RSS leader Bhaiyyaji Joshi states in the preface to one of the books, "To violate Hindu swabhiman (dignity) of Chanwarvanshiya Kshatriyas, foreign invaders from Arab, Muslim rulers and beef-eaters, forced them to do abominable works like killing cows, skinning them and throwing

The epic depicts a glorious battle, but the RSS's revisionism would have one of the protagonists being a male. "What I mean by that is that they want the male role taken by the Brahmin," says Harsha Bhogle, a Dalit activist with the Dalit Rights Network.

Many women experience some degree of sleep disturbance during pregnancy. For a significant number of women, the sleep disruption may be so severe as to
reference_text:
require some type of intervention. In a previous post, we discussed the use of different types of medications to treat insomnia during pregnancy. While these drugs are highly effective, many women with sleep problems inquire about the use of "natural" agents, such as melatonin, during pregnancy.

Melatonin is a hormone secreted by the pineal gland which is involved in regulating normal sleep-wake cycles. It is also sold over the counter as a nutritional supplement and is a popular natural remedy for sleep problems.

When it comes to pregnancy, however, natural does not necessarily mean safer. Although melatonin is indeed "natural" and is normally produced by the body, the amount delivered by various over-the-counter preparations typically exceeds the quantities normally produced by the body. As is the case with most supplements, we know very little about the impact these high levels of hormones may have on the developing fetus. Thus, we typically advise women with sleep problems to use medications with a better characterized reproductive

generated_result.0:
be clinically significant. Although the extent to which sleep-related problems can be reduced during pregnancy may not be completely known, it has been suggested that early maternal care during pregnancy reduces the incidence of low birth weight infants by 2-6%, and for most babies this will allow the infant to reach a comfortable sleep environment. For example, sleep deprivation, in conjunction with high maternal protein and high energy intake, has been shown to result in increased blood pressure and inflammatory markers, as well as an increase in blood pressure in the neonate.

The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) recommends that mothers and new mothers have a regular sleep schedule. Sleep deprivation symptoms include loss of sleep, drowsiness, inability to concentrate or sleep, excessive crying (crying with anxiety or agitation), decreased libido and trouble falling asleep. Some women experience a more generalized disturbance of the sleep-wake cycle and more severe disturbances in REM sleep, which is one of the stages of sleep in the body. Some women report that sleep deprivation impairs the ability of the fetus to develop normally during a critical stage of fetal development. These effects occur without the use of drugs, including anti-nausea and sleep medications, and usually begin during fetal development and generally subside with the first trimester.

prefix_text:
BACKGROUND OF THE INVENTION

1. Field of the Invention

This invention relates to bus architectures and particularly to low latency shared bus architectures.

2. Description of Related Art
reference_text:
A bus is a communication path between various devices of an electronic system. For example in a computer system, the central processing unit (CPU) communicates with main memory through a memory bus. Peripheral devices may also be connected to the memory bus or connected to the CPU through a separate IO bus.

Buses can be divided into two general categories: point-to-point buses and shared buses. A point-to-point bus connects only two bus devices together. A shared bus can be used by more than two bus devices. Thus the number of buses required for communication depends on whether point-to-point or shared buses are used. For example, four bus devices require six point-to-point buses to communicate with each other, but four bus devices can communicate through a single shared bus. With a shared bus architecture all four bus devices can share a single bus.

Point-to-point buses have the advantage of lower latency, minimal bus contention, and the

generated_result.0:
One or more common bus architectures include a "bus" in which each bus node is a device within a bus. One or more bus nodes are coupled in various ways. These bus nodes may have a physical layout such that a device may be attached to one or more nodes or may be placed at one or more locations on the bus network. In some architectures, a device may be placed at one or more locations on the bus network. In some architectures, the location of a device may also be tied to a specific bus node or a "node" within the network. Such an architecture allows for bus nodes to be located within a bus and an "on" node to be located adjacent to, for example, a bus node.

In this context, a bus node is an electrical device which is coupled to, for example, an "open" or "closed" bus node, which is coupled to a bus node or a node within a bus. A device may be one in which
generated_result.1:
In a typical computer, the memory of a computer is divided into sections such as RAM, ROM, and flash memory. There are two sets of the data within the sections of RAM that are accessible from each other. Two bus architectures commonly exist for accessing these sections: the standard bus (SBR) architecture and the flash-to-RAM (FTR) architecture.

SBR (Synchronous Broader Bus)

The SBR is a single-chip bus that allows for simultaneous transfer of multiple data elements in a single clock cycle. SBR uses a large number of synchronous communication elements that are capable of operating in the low latency region between these data elements. The SBR is implemented on an Intel (NASDAQ: INTC) XMM7 processor that is capable of executing on a Intel 32/64-bit X86 platform and is also capable of executing on a 128-bit ARM architecture. The SBR utilizes the Intel 64 architecture hardware in its architecture.
generated_result.2:
Broadband communications is widely used in public and private enterprise. For instance, in the United States, approximately two dozen public telecommunications companies operate across the United States. The use of such communication technologies has become critical for business and social needs.

In a distributed bus architecture, a single bus system can communicate on both sides of the wire (see figure 1). With the use of a distributed bus architecture, there is no single point where a single bus device is physically connected to the memory of the shared bus, or even on the same bus. Consequently, the communication technology that uses shared bus architectures also needs to be able to accommodate a large number of shared devices.

Briefly, in a distributed bus system, a single bus device that runs a full-duplex TCP connection, in particular, can communicate on both sides of the wire in a wide range of communication modes and over many kinds of communications paths. The shared bus can thus support a large number of devices in various communicati

prefix_text: Michael Gove once waxed lyrical about Labour's last elected Prime Minister Tony Blair, "I can't hold it back any more; I love Tony!". Well, it's about time for a
reference_text:
paid-up member of the liberal left to repay the compliment, because I can't hold it back any more; I love Govey.

Gove is now a secret liberal sleeper cell in the heart of the British establishment and remains our last hope of a nicer, more progressive society under the Tories. He's begun to make his mark as the new Justice Minister by putting a clear divide between him and the sheer ghastliness of the former incumbent Chris Grayling. Gove has the potential to be the most liberal Justice Secretary since Roy Jenkins, a true reformer who could take Britain away from its Victorian attitudes towards prison and justice, save the European Convention on Human Rights, while pushing back against autocrats like the Saudis. There's so much potential, but will the Tories let Gove be Gove?

It was inevitable that Corbyn, a man who has been criticised for his lack of focus, would be elected leader. But this may have been his turning point.

The establishment was wrong to write him off in the summer of 2015 and they are wrong to believe that he is incapable of delivering the change Britain needs.

do not write the null character after the pathname.

How to Run Tools

All tools run from the command line in a shell with the following syntax:

java tool. XXX [options] files

Tools all live in the file Mult
reference_text:
ivalent.jar, and that file is made visible to Java by adding its path to your CLASSPATH environment variable. For example, for UNIX (including Mac OS X and Linux), depending on your shell, setenv CLASSPATH $CLASSPATH:/path/to/Multivalent.jar or export CLASSPATH=$CLASSPATH:/path/to/Multivalent.jar. Alternatively, you can set the classpath explicitly as an option, as in

java -classpath /path/to/Multivalent.jar tool. XXX [options] files

lib/ext

java -Xmx192m tool. XXX [options] files

Weapon and Armor Proficiency

In addition to the standard monk weapon proficiencies, a far strike monk is proficient with all thrown weapons.

Flurry of Blows (Ex)

A far strike monk can make a flurry of blows as a full-attack action as long as he's attacking with thrown weapons. He can't make a flurry of blows with his unarmed attacks or any other weapons.

A far strike monk's flurry of blows otherwise functions as the standard monk class feature.

A far strike monk can't use Rapid Shot when making a flurry of blows with a thrown weapon.

This ability alters flurry of blows.

Bonus Feats

A far strike monk adds the following feats to his list of bonus feats at 1st level: Far Shot, Point-Blank Shot, Precise Shot, and any targeting feat.

At 6th level, he adds the following feats:

prefix_text: Ye Olde Server Pack (YOSP) is a fairly lightweight pack intended to recapture the feeling of old packs from the earliest versions of modded Minecraft, specifically those on Minecraft 1.2.
reference_text:
5. It made made for use on a private server, hence the name, but will work perfectly fine in singleplayer or for use on your own server. In updating to a modern version, we included some newer mods that fit the theme of the original packs, along with many of the quality-of-life mods now available. (Not to mention some much nicer terrain generation, courtesy of Biomes O' Plenty and Alternate Terrain Generation!)

YOSP includes several tech and magic mods, allowing for multiple styles of play. The main tech mods available are Buildcraft, IC2, Mekanism, and Immersive Engineering. IC2 Experimental's recipes have been extensively changed to be more similar to IC2 Classic and to generally reduce microcrafting. Mekanism has been heavily nerfed (especially power generation options) to keep it balanced with IC2. Applied Energistics is excluded in favor of Logistics Pipes, as a complicated pipe network stretching throughout your factory is iconic to

It's mostly distributed using the SourceForge Project which hosts all the files that make up this pack as well as a number of public download mirrors.

If you'd like to try it out you can download it from the Nexus Mod Manager.

This pack is still actively being developed but is largely feature complete.

[This post was jointly written by Nuno Lopes, David Menendez, Santosh Nagarakatte, and John Regehr.]

A modern compiler is a big, complex machine
reference_text:
that contains a lot of moving parts, including many different kinds of optimizations. One important class of optimization is peephole optimizations, each of which translates a short sequence of instructions into a more desirable sequence of instructions. For example, consider this LLVM code that first shifts an unsigned 32-bit value 29 bits to the left, then 29 bits to the right:

%1 = shl i32 %x, 29 %2 = lshr i32 %1, 29

As long as %1 is not used anywhere else, this computation would be better written as:

%2 = and i32 %x, 7

Unsurprisingly, LLVM already knows how to perform this peephole optimization; the code implementing it can be found here.

Although most peephole transformations are pretty straightforward, the problem is that there are a lot of them, creating a lot of opportunities to make mistakes. Many of LLVM's peephole optimizations can be

generated_result.0:
, with an immense amount of instruction and data paths. For a language, its architecture is just another big set of variables, a set of local variables, a set of data objects, and a single data structure.

The structure of modern compilers varies depending on the language you use. The same compiler with a different syntax or syntaxes may produce different output. The same compiler with different semantics or semantics for different targets may yield a vastly different output.

In most languages, the type system is a crucial part of a modern compiler. Type inference is key to understanding how a compiler works: compiler authors can be almost completely confident that the program will behave as expected. The result is that type inference is often a part of the development process for a modern compiler, and even for older compiler implementations.

However, some modern compilers do not have sufficient type inference support. For example, the C99 C compiler (C, version 4) uses a completely different approach to type inferenc
generated_result.1:
with lots of internal resources and a lot of interdependencies. Even the most powerful compiler must be able to produce fast code.

I think that we have to recognize the fact that most optimizations that are possible are not trivial to implement, and that the standard library doesn't have a huge amount of internal resources and doesn't have a lot of interdependencies.

I think that as long as you don't have to resort to a custom toolchain, the standard library shouldn't need much in the way of special-purpose optimizations and optimizations that aren't possible outside of the language. We can't afford to sacrifice the performance of the standard library and the quality of the source code in order to have better toolchains.

There are several aspects of this situation that should be acknowledged, both by the community and by the compiler vendors:

First, a good compiler should have a good standard library. However, this depends on the compiler as a whole. For a language lik
generated_result.2:
. Modern compilers are often very complicated. This article shows why a modern compiler is such a large and complicated machine; and why one should not assume modern compilers are inherently robust, and instead use existing solutions from old versions.

What is a modern compiler?

Modern compiler implementations include:

compilers like GCC, Clang, MSVC, and LLVM, to name just a few.

optimization techniques like SSA and AVX2, to name a few.

support for multiple backends, like Clang's C++ backend or Microsoft's VC++ project.

systems programming languages, like C and Java, which are the basis for most modern languages.

Meanwhile, NBC is reporting that Dear talked about abortion after he was arrested, making reference to "baby parts," according to NBC's law enforcement sources.

If the F-35B is indeed operational and ready for war—should it not be out there on the front line supporting America's efforts to roll back the Islamic State?

The United States
reference_text:
has deployed some of its most advanced warplanes to fight over Syria and Iraq. But where are the U.S. Marine Corps' newly operational F-35B Lightning II stealth fighters?

Despite having been declared operational at the end of July by Marine Corps. commandant Gen. Joseph Dunford, the stealthy jump-jet is nowhere to be seen in the theatre.

Last year, despite no air threat or even significant air defense systems to contend with, the U.S. Air Force deployed its prized Lockheed Martin F-22 Raptors into the fray. It was the first time those stealthy air superiority fighters had been sent into battle since the jet became operational in 2005. The Raptors—which have excellent sensors—have proven to be useful over Syria even without advanced threats to defeat, Air Force officials including Air Combat Command commander Gen. Hawk Carlisle have stated repeatedly.

If the F-35B were not available and there were no F-35s in the air, the United States would lack its ability to provide support, training and advise to allied forces. The F-35B would not allow the United States to attack Islamic State bases and forces in Syria.

There are a few other things to say about the Pentagon's decision to delay production of the F-35B. There is no question that the F-35 program was originally supposed to have started in 2003, and that we all now know that the program was not a success. However, no one can deny that at the time this decision was made, it was a strategic move that was not only necessary, but also necessary for the United States and our allies.

The Pentagon did not want to be locked into a long-term agreement with Germany and other allies

But the F-35B is the single largest contributor to the fight in Iraq and Syria, and it will take the best and brightest to build and sustain the program—not to mention the millions and millions of dollars it will cost.

It is critical that we understand what all of these challenges are before we throw our financial resources into a program that seems destined to end in financial failure.

The F-35 is a great airplane, but it is not an air strike fighter. It will have to fly in a highly contested environment for a very long period of time. In Iraq, coalition forces lost over 3,500 aircraft during the Iraqi operations. And in Syria, we are losing over 2,500 aircraft. In both conflicts, the F-35C is not designed to perform these roles well.

Why your marriage sucks Passion has died, argues author Cristina Nehring, taking domestic bliss with it. But is romance really in crisis?

reference_text:
marriage? The unmarried among us have surely begun to ask this question. (No doubt the married have, too, though in the past tense.) If it is possible, the "hard work" it requires will wring the partnership of all passion and wonderment and joy. From the narratives of wifely grievance routinely published in women's magazines to the spectacular public bust-ups of numerous celebrity marriages in which we have placed our bruised faith, it's easy to glean that we currently inhabit a vast and bleak landscape of marital discontent.

Volkswagen is facing €8.2bn ($9.1bn; £7bn) in damages claims from 1,400 German investors over its emissions scandal, a
reference_text:
state court has said.

The regional court in Braunschweig near VW's Wolfsburg headquarters said it received 750 lawsuits on Monday alone.

A year ago, an investigation in the US found that VW had cheated emissions tests for diesel cars by using special software.

VW faces a flood of actions and has set aside €16.2bn to cover the lawsuits.

The court said it brought in extra staff to process the claims submitted by shareholders, who were concerned that 18 September, the day VW's manipulations were uncovered a year ago, may be the deadline to file.

It said most of the cases were bundled actions containing claims from multiple plaintiffs, in many cases private investors.

The controversial thesis at the center of this study is that, despite the importance of slavery in Athenian society, the most distinctive characteristic of Athenian democracy was the unprecedented prominence it gave to free labor. reference_text:
house in London. The international auction house Bonham's says it has sold a small, patchy disc of mold for $14,597. The off-white, nearly 90-year-old swatch of microbes has a rather extraordinary history: it was first created by Alexander Fleming to make penicillin, a revolutionary discovery that brought the world its first antibiotic. Bonham's sold the mold Wednesday, March 1 during an auction in London. The germs are preserved in a glass case and feature an inscription by Fleming on the back, identifying it as "the mould that first made penicillin." (AP Photo/Alastair Grant)

LONDON (AP) — How much is an old, dried out piece of mold worth? Apparently more than $14,600 if it was created by the doctor who discovered penicillin.

Famed microbiologist Alexander Fleming didn't invent penicillin. He wasn't even in the labs where he made it. The discovery came in the lab of a University of Texas laboratory technician in the 1950s, says Bill Storch, an author of the book Penicillin: The Unofficial Biography of the World's Most Controversial Discovery and the man with the original cast-iron canning jar that helped make the antibiotic so successful.

It was then that Fleming was inspired by other microbes like Salmonella to make a compound he dubbed penicillin. This is the first time the compound has sold for more than $700 million. Storch says the first successful antibiotic is expected to sell for $1 million to $1.5 million on the secondary market, though it's far too early to say how much it will sell.

prefix_text: Dan Drezner has written a valuable essay for Foreign Affairs on the need to repair Republican foreign policy thinking. He argues that Republican credibility on foreign policy has been badly damaged by the party's fixation on
reference_text:
the "war on terror," the tendency to hype and inflate threats, its refusal to come to grips with complexity in international affairs, and a bad habit of treating foreign policy issues as extensions of domestic political and cultural fights. Here is the core of his thesis:

Since 9/11, however, Republicans have known only one big thing — the "global war on terror" — and have remained stubbornly committed to a narrow militarized approach. Since the fall of Baghdad, moreover, this approach has produced at least as much failure as success, leading the American public to be increasingly skeptical of the bellicosity that now defines the party's foreign policy. Republicans need to start taking international relations more seriously, addressing the true complexities and requirements of the issues rather than allowing the subject to be a plaything for right-wing interest groups. And if they don't act quickly, they might cede this ground to the Democrats for the next generation.

prefix_text:
TRENTON — Last month's elections continued what has become a striking trend in New Jersey recently: People are voting at historically low rates.

Though U.S. Sen. Cory Booker —
reference_text:
a nationally known politician — won his first full term in Washington and all 12 of the state's seats in the U.S. House of Representatives were up for grabs, only 36 percent of New Jersey's registered voters cast ballots in November's midterm elections. It was the lowest voter turnout for a regularly scheduled federal election in state history.

In fact, each of New Jersey's last seven statewide elections have set some kind of record for low turnout — a stretch of voter apathy that experts blame partly on citizens being frustrated with partisan bickering and campaign finance issues.

"I think people are fed up with government," said Patrick Murray, director of the Monmouth University Polling Institute. "How do you expect people to go out and vote for an institution in which about one in 10 have any faith in?"

reference_text:
, 2017, after a close to three-year run. Ali Ewoldt will remain as Christine and Rodney Ingram will remain as Raoul through the Phantom's 30th anniversary on Jan. 26, 2018.

Barbour's successor is set to be announced soon, according to the press office.

There have been 15 Phantoms in the several decades the show has been on Broadway.

Laird Mackintosh, currently playing Monsieur André, will assume the role for the three weeks between Barbour and his to-be successor. Kayley Ann Voorhees, recently seen in the "Prince of Broadway," will play Christine at certain performances starting November 6.

ino, has encouraged people to stand atop the fourth chair to share their own messages to the public in part of a project called "Anything to Say?"

POLICE must be given the power to arrest suspects on the spot to issue them with apprehended domestic violence orders, according to a multi-party report.

A NSW upper house committee has called for
reference_text:
the Crimes Act to be toughened to better protect victims of domestic abuse. The committee said the law should allow police to arrest and detain aggressors immediately. It should also allow third parties to apply for orders on behalf of someone who is physically or mentally impaired.

Another one of the 84 recommendations urges the government to allow police ranked sergeants or above to issue interim ADVOs.

Among the 84 recommendations delivered to the NSW government yesterday five ask for the Act to be toughened.

Assistant Commissioner Mark Murdoch told the inquiry that when police were about to apply for a provisional AVO, they could not arrest the suspected aggressor unless he refused to stay put until the order is served.

Upper House Labor MP Helen Westwood said in many cases the person fled by the time officers returned. "This change would give police the power to serve the AVO and the conditions would apply immediately," she said.

But it flagged some issues with existing legislation that would need to be addressed when the bill was introduced.

the move, which would allow police to arrest someone for domestic violence offences without the requirement for court hearings.

One of the report's recommendations is that victims have the authority to make an apprehended domestic violence order, without having to go through any court process or hearings.

A proposed police reform package includes a requirement for victims of domestic violence to give 24 hours' notice of the offence before police are permitted to arrest the person on the spot.

The reform package, published in the NSW Parliament today, also included a provision to change the existing domestic violence offences from a summary to a summary or summary of facts for victims.

Arab foreign ministers on Sunday demanded that the United States rescind President Donald Trump's decision
reference_text:
to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital, calling it a "grave" development that puts Washington on the same side as "occupation" and the violation of international law.

In a resolution long on rhetoric but short on concrete actions, the ministers denounced what they claimed was an "illegal" and "dangerous violation" of international law. "It's a dangerous development that places the United States at a position of bias in favor of the occupation and the violation of international law and resolutions," the resolution said.

It said it would seek a U.N. Security Council resolution rejecting the U.S. move.

The two-page resolution adopted by the emergency meeting, which began Saturday night, did not include any punitive actions against the United States, like a call for a boycott of American products or suspending or downgrading ties with Washington.
