Advertisement


The YFP is modeled after programs in New Orleans and Denver that have made significant strides in improving mental health in high-risk youth. The program is modeled on the Colorado Youth Program, a 10-month program based on the research of John Hopkins School of Medicine that has had a profound impact on reducing suicide among young people.

It's still early days for YFP. But one recent study found that those participating in the program experienced a 51 percent decrease in suicidal ideation and a 29 percent decrease in attempted suicide compared to participants who didn't take the program. TB Statistics United States – National, drug resistance & state

National TB statistics United States 2016 & 2015

The preliminary TB statistics for the United States for 2016 show a total of 9,287
reference_text:
TB cases reported, compared with a total of 9,546 for 2,015. This is a very slight decline and a much higher rate of decline is needed if the goal of the elimination of TB in the United States is to be reached in the foreseeable future. This was a decrease in incidence from 3.0 per 100,000 to 2.0 per 100,000.

The incidence in 2016 ranged from 0.2 cases per 100,000 in Wyoming to 8.3 in Hawaii. Alaska, Arkansas, California, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Maryland, Minnesota, New Jersey, New York, North Dakota, and Texas, as well as Washington DC, all reported incidences that exceeded the overall national incidence. Four states, California (2,130), Texas (1,333), New York (763) and Florida (602) accounted for 50.9% of all cases. Among the individuals for whom the information was available, 5.7% were HIV infected, 4

cases of tuberculosis, a 25.5% decrease since 2015. While the number of cases decreased by 26.8%, the age-adjusted burden of TB is 1.03% lower, with 2,842.5 cases of persons aged 10 years and younger.

The preliminary TB statistics for the United States for 2015 show a total of 8,743 cases of tuberculosis, a 23.5% decrease from the year before. While the number of cases decreased by 23%, the age-adjusted burden of TB is 1.09% lower, with 1,949.8 cases of persons aged 10 years and younger.

The preliminary TB statistics for the United States for 2014 show a total of 5,061 cases of tuberculosis, a 26.6% decrease from the year before. While the number of cases decreased by 26.4%, the age-adjusted burden of TB is 1.03% lower, with 1,948.1 cases of persons aged 10 years

Treatment of drug resistant TB patients includes using a treatment regimen specific to a particular drug. However, treatment does not prevent the spread of drug resistance in TB.

A National Foundation for Infectious Diseases (NFID) advisory committee convened in January 2018 to consider how to strengthen New Jersey's TB treatment guidelines. Much of Los Angeles suffered a power outage after the city's devastating 6.7 earthquake in 1994. The blackout decreased the city's light pollution and residents got a rare look at the stars as they hadn't seen them before. But no, the image above doesn't show that blackout in 1994.

Photographer Thierry Cohen creates photo mash-ups depicting the night sky over major cities, as if all the lights had gone out. The Harsh Realities of Recycling in the Rockies

Lifting the lid on waste removal in the Canadian Rocky Mountains.


This article originally ran as "Out of Sight, Out
reference_text:
of Mind" in the Winter 2014 issue of Highline Magazine.

"What's in the bag?" I whisper, watching the hairs on my buddy's neck stand on end. My accusatory heckle hisses through the shadowy night in a quiet residential neighbourhood in Jasper. I'm taking out the trash from a post-housewarming soiree. My friend, who didn't see me coming, is disposing of what looks to be his dog's fecal matter.

Meeting someone at the garbage is always a social occasion.

I'm slinking to the bins in the dead of night to dump a salmon carcass. I'm not sure if the remnants should go in compost or garbage, and frankly, I'll use the cloak of darkness to conceal my confusion. As for my buddy, he's just being a responsible dog walker.

Is he going to compost that? I wonder.

We can't see the mountains from here (unless we are on a topographic map) but we have a good view of the town of Salida, where we have arrived on the last leg of our trip. prefix_text: Ecuador's President Correa was well-rewarded for his trip last week to China, but this could have grave impacts for the Amazon and the people who live there. On Wednesday, Beijing
reference_text:
agreed to lend Ecuador $7.53 billion to help the heavily oil-dependent economy cope with the recent drop in global crude prices. This latest sum – the largest China has ever lent Ecuador – brings Chinese financing to Ecuador to nearly $25 billion, over a quarter of the nation's GDP. In 2013 Beijing provided 61% of Ecuador's external financing and purchased 83% of Ecuador's oil; this latest loan will undoubtedly bring both numbers much higher.

Since he took office in 2007, Correa has shifted attention and dependency away from the US and towards China. When Chinese state broadcaster CCTV asked Correa whether Ecuador was "merely changing from a dependency on the US to a dependency on China," Correa rightfully criticized Western financial institutions. He described the "relationship between equals" that Ecuador enjoys with China, saying, "This will not be about submission, like Latin America has long had to suffer. Now, it is really about cooperation between friendly countries, between countries that are friends."

generated_result.0:
and Quito signed an agreement to boost cooperation on both sides of the border.

The agreement marks the first major Chinese contribution to the country's efforts to curb deforestation. China is the second-largest importer of timber from Ecuador, after Brazil. In the past year alone, Ecuador has purchased more than $2 billion worth of Chinese timber, and has agreed to provide Ecuador with $30 million for wood projects. Correa hopes his visit will help push the country to reduce its dependence on lumber exports.

Correa hopes to bring new attention to his country's environmental policies, including his "Rainforest Protection and Management Act." The act, which he signed last week, calls for increased forest protection as well as increased logging in order to boost sustainable livelihoods and protect ecosystems from climate change.

Correa has previously spoken out against logging in his home country. During a visit to Indonesia in late May, he declared that logging was ruining the country's forests. But a recent repor

China's leadership may have some influence in helping Ecuador to set a clear, concrete vision for the future of Amazonia, but it may not be enough.

reference_text:
acorns, seeds, nuts, and insects — but Athens squirrels are far from ordinary.

"We had suspected for quite some time that there was something unique about the squirrels that roam college green," Dr. Jane Hernandez, an Ohio University nutrition professor and researcher told The Black Sheep. "But we hadn't expected to find such a dramatic departure from the usual dietary habits of squirrels."

The study suggests that over the many generations of living in a college town, local squirrels have changed their food preference from nuts, seeds, and insects, to discarded sub sandwiches, abandoned burritos, and most of all, half-eaten pieces of pepperoni pizza.

prefix_text: The news comes on the heels of Twitter's latest quarterly report, which not only revealed that it would be laying off 350 employee, but that it was also restructuring to be profitable in 2017. And no
reference_text:
wonder -- though it continues to make money, Twitter has never turned a profit and user growth has remained stagnant. Even after co-founder Jack Dorsey took over as CEO last year, the company just couldn't seem to turn its fortunes around.

2016 in particular has been rough for Twitter. Not only did it see an exodus of executives, it also faced increasing scrutiny over its constant harassment problems. The problem reached a fever pitch this year when SNL's Leslie Jones received a barrage of racist and sexist tweets, leading her to briefly quit. Twitter did eventually ban the leader of that mob as well as implement quality filters and a safety council, but the damage was already done. Plus, those efforts don't seem to have solved matters either. Marvel writer Chelsea Cain was also recently driven off Twitter due to abusive comments she received about her work.

This turned out to be a sticking point when Twitter sought to sell itself a few months ago. Several companies were interested in the deal -- Sales

And yes, Apple has been hit by an antitrust lawsuit, but as a private company it's not obligated to disclose what it pays Apple in the event the company is sued. Apple does not need to disclose which competitors it is being sued by in order to avoid a costly legal battle.

Still, the $300 million loss Twitter announced yesterday is another major blow to the company. And the timing couldn't be more unfortunate.

Requirements

This requires the Twitter gem and a registered Twitter application. Follow instructions for the Twitter gem in an empty directory first.

Config

In order to use this repo, you must
reference_text:
first generate a twitter application. Make sure to set the permissions to "read and write" (or optionally "read, write, and send direct messages").

Enter your twitter app credentials in the user_scraper.rb as follows:

client = Twitter::REST::Client.new do |config| config.consumer_key = "YOUR_CONSUMER_KEY" config.consumer_secret = "YOUR_CONSUMER_SECRET" config.access_token = "YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN" config.access_token_secret = "YOUR_ACCESS_SECRET" end

Usage

There are three modules - the tweet scraper, the user scraper, and the follower.

Use the tweet scraper to scrape tweets of other users. You can tweet those as your own, or use them however you'd like.

The user scraper searches for keywords and scrap

first generate a secret key. Create a file called secret_key.pem, copy the following code from it, and put it in your.gitignore file:

$ ( curl -O http://example.com | openssl -deserialize -inform PEM -noout | gpg --import )

Generate the app's secret key:

$ git clone git@github.com:app-for-android/app.git $ cd app

Now you can use your app's secret key as your Twitter app's secret key. This will allow you to tweet with a Twitter app on your Android smartphone with a secure token. You can now start and stop the Twitter application by calling the following command:

$ gem install twitter

And restart your phone.

For a full list of available gems visit the official GitHub page. If you have any questions, feel free to contact us via twitter.

Indianapolis protesters on Monday won a round in a fight to save an old-growth forest from a Veterans Affairs project.

Cheers erupted from about two dozen people massed near a construction entrance to the 15-acre forest on the north side of Crown Hill cemetery after hearing word that the VA had ordered crews to hold off cutting trees, some of which are believed to be hundreds of years old. The VA is planning a monument to hold veterans' urns.

"Sometimes it takes people who are willing to stand out in the cold," said Russ Sipes, an attorney who filed an unsuccessful federal lawsuit seeking to stop the construction project on the site near 42nd Street and Clarendon Road.

"This whole process was messed up in the beginning because the VA didn't give enough public notice to people."

The conclusion is consistent with the PMRA's previous reviews, including the re-evaluation decisions in 2005, 2007, 2008, and 2013.

The PMRA review determined that all forms of 2,4-D are not mutagenic or genotoxic and that "the overall weight of evidence indicates that 2,4-D is not carcinogenic in rats, mice, and dogs."

In addition to the toxicity studies in animals, the PMRA considered expert assessments from numerous epidemiological studies on human exposure.

"I got these papers," the man told him. "I don't know what they mean."

What they meant was the man was owed a sizable chunk of money from the years he'd worked in mining in Colorado. He was due a sizable annuity and retirement payments of $600 a month.

"He ended up getting a check for like $15,000. It was a wonderful thing to be able to help him out," Kessler said.

One of the most famous experiments in quantum physics, which first showed how particles can bizarrely behave like waves, has now been carried out on the largest molecules ever.

Researchers have sent molecules containing
reference_text:
either 58 or 114 atoms through the so-called "double-slit experiment," showing that they cause an interference pattern that can only be explained if the particles act like waves of water, rather than tiny marbles.

Researchers said it wasn't a foregone conclusion that such large particles would act this way.

"In a way it's a little bit surprising, because these are highly complex and also flexible molecules; they change their shape while they're flying through the apparatus," said Markus Arndt of the University of Vienna in Austria, a co-leader of the project. "If you talk to the community, maybe 50 percent would say this is normal because it's quantum physics, and the other 50 percent would really scratch their heads because it's quantum physics."

Indeed, the double-slit experiment, one of the foundations of quantum physics, was voted the "most beautiful experiment" ever in a 2002 poll of Physics World readers.

Beautiful experiment

The experiment could lead to better treatments for conditions such as blindness caused by damage to the light-sensitive retinal nerves, which detect light and convert it into nerve impulses which trigger the muscle contractions necessary for eye movements.

The scientists from the Max Planck Institute for Plasma Physics and the Université de Montréal and the Université de Montréal in Quebec, Canada, are believed to be the first to conduct a quantum opto-electronic microscope.

"It's really exciting that you can go a step further and test molecules with atomic-scale properties," said Max Planck physicist Jean-Christophe Béjar.

The same principle applies to how atoms or molecules interact with their environment," said professor of chemistry Martin van Poppel at the Max Planck Institute for Chemistry.

The results of this latest experimental research, published in the journal Nature Physics, were reported recently at the American Association for the Advancement of Science meeting in Washington.

The experiments at the University of Warwick were carried out using a quantum tunnelling microscope, which sends a beam of atoms into another part of the laboratory and then bounces it back.

The researchers saw that a particular combination of conditions made the atom move in the opposite direction than it would have normally done if it were still just a solid atom.

reference_text:
The French Interior Ministry told the Associated Press that 3.7 million marched throughout France, making the demonstrations the largest in the country's history.

Adding to the symbolic weight of the demonstrations, more than 40 world leaders joined the start of the Paris march, linking arms in an act of solidarity. But as Reporters Without Borders points out, their policies at home are far from compatible with the solidarity for free speech on display throughout France.

The organization said Sunday that it was "appalled by the presence of leaders from countries where journalists and bloggers are systematically persecuted such as Egypt (which is ranked 159th out of 180 countries in RWB's press freedom index), Russia (148th), Turkey (154th) and United Arab Emirates (118th)."

"The attacks in Paris, and the recent shootings in San Bernardino, illustrate the dangers of allowing extremists to spread their violence into our communities," Deputy Secretary of State Antony Blinken said in a statement.

Blinken said the US "will continue to stand with all allies against all who seek to harm us or who commit acts of hatred or intolerance."

Letters of recommendation are an important part of your application to medical school. Medical schools rely on letters of recommendation to learn about important aspects of your potential as a medical
reference_text:
student that they cannot glean from your GPA and MCAT score: in particular, your communication skills, interpersonal skills, and intellectual curiosity.

It is essential that you develop good relationships with some of your professors if you want to obtain strong letters of recommendation. Ask questions in class, go talk with them during their office hours, and ask them about their research interests. Developing relationships with your professors is an important part of your intellectual growth. If you have learned a lot from a professor and enjoyed his or her teaching style, consider taking a second class with the same professor. Doing so will provide you an opportunity to learn more, get to know the professor even better, and perhaps obtain an even stronger letter of recommendation.

Most medical schools require a minimum of three letters of recommendation. prefix_text:
This is post 4 out of 10 in the LXC 1.0 blog post series.

Running foreign architectures

By default LXC will only let you run containers of one of the architectures
reference_text:
supported by the host. That makes sense since after all, your CPU doesn't know what to do with anything else.

Except that we have this convenient package called "qemu-user-static" which contains a whole bunch of emulators for quite a few interesting architectures. The most common and useful of those is qemu-arm-static which will let you run most armv7 binaries directly on x86.

The "ubuntu" template knows how to make use of qemu-user-static, so you can simply check that you have the "qemu-user-static" package installed, then run:

sudo lxc-create -t ubuntu -n p3 -- -a armhf

After a rather long bootstrap, you'll get a new p3 container which will be mostly running Ubuntu armhf. I'm saying mostly because the qemu emulation comes with a few limitations, the biggest of

generated_result.0:
on your local network. If you just need to host some containers on a different machine or port, you need to manually change this setting in your /etc/systemd/system/config/lxc-container.conf file. The following is the syntax for this parameter, which can also be used inside of LXC :

[XC=<arch>]

where <arch> is either "x86_64" or "x86_64_64". When adding new architectures, LXC will ask you to select one of the available architectures from the list, in this case x86_64.

Adding more architectures

The next step is to automatically add more architectures to the list automatically.

By default, LXC will only let you run containers of one of the architectures on your local network. If you just need to host some containers on a different machine or port, you need to manually change this setting in your /etc/system
generated_result.1:
(32-bit or 64-bit ARM, x86, or i386). Since I don't have anything specific in mind (such as building a 64-bit ARM and using it from LXC) I decided to try running containers of multiple architectures. I did this as part of an experiment which I would like to write a writeup on but I don't have anything in mind yet.

Installing dependencies

In order to compile this application on several different platforms I will need to install some dependencies (e.g. GPG key, git, and curl, etc.). Since these dependencies aren't installed by default on Fedora 19 I downloaded a copy of Fedora 19 from Fedora's site (http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Fedora_19_installation) and edited the Fedora 19 dependency files to point at the.tar.xz file I downloaded. I then downloaded gpg-agent and installed it with the following commands:
generated_result.2:
(x86 and ARM). For these to work, you'll need to make a couple of changes to the following section in the file ~/.config/lxc/xen/lxc.cfg :

host_vars:

lxc.architecture=lxc64 for x86_64 lxc.architecture=arm64 for arm64

When running containerized applications, all LXC operations (like loading a module, mounting a volume etc) will only run when the container is booted up with the correct architecture. To check if the host machine is configured to boot with one of these architectures (or any other) in your system, you can use a command like this:

lxc status

If the LXC daemon is running (as mentioned above it will be by default), you'll see the following.

lxc info

On a 64-bit system, we get the following.

lxc daem

prefix_text: According to reports out of Korea, Chinese audiences won't be able to watch South Korean television shows on streaming services anytime soon, due to an ongoing political dispute disrupting ties between the two countries.
reference_text:
Over the weekend, Korean news outlet Yonhap reported that China has blocked videos of South Korean music and television dramas from streaming services. The move came as part of continued economic backlash by the Chinese government in response to South Korea deploying the United States' Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) system near Seoul.

South Korea is stationing the anti-ballistic missile system on its soil as a deterrent against North Korea, but China objects to THAAD, on the grounds of its ability to threaten Chinese territorial security, while simultaneously raising tension between the Koreas.

Many Chinese streaming services have stopped updating video clips of South Korean entertainment. According to Yonhap, one website posted on its social media account that "everybody should be aware of the reason for this," referencing the Chinese government's toughened stance on Korean cultural imports.

South Korea television dramas and variety shows are extremely popular in China, with popular shows garnering billions of views on Chinese streaming sites

generated_result.0:
According to the Korean Herald News, the two countries are reportedly locked in a dispute, with the two sides trying to reach a resolution to end the dispute.


Following the South Korean government's call for a diplomatic solution to the dispute, China's China Radio International (CRI) announced that it will not air any South Korean-produced TV dramas on its service.


In response, South Korea's cable television channel KBS said it would suspend all South Korean programming and television dramas from October 14 to November 19.


But according to local reports, it won't be the end of the line. According to the WSJ, China's CCTV will continue to broadcast South Korean dramas in China over the next two months, including a remake of a popular Hong Kong soap called I Hear You Knocking, with original cast members.

prefix_text: In every respect but one, Iowa's Republican caucuses delivered a conventional result on Tuesday. In 2008, Iowan churchgoers laid hands on an affable rock guitarist, Mike Huckabee. This time, they
reference_text:
have lifted up the much less likable Rick Santorum. In any event, the corporate-funded wing of the Party will now muster its financing, polling, and ad-making machine to assure the nomination of its candidate, Mitt Romney. It would be very surprising if it failed.

The unconventional aspect was the vote for Ron Paul. After raising expectations high, Paul finished a close-run third in Iowa, so his media momentum may slip. And yet never before has a candidate running on such a radical, and specifically libertarian platform—abolish the Federal Reserve, withdraw from all foreign entanglements, end the war on drugs—done so well. The size and character of his vote suggest his candidacy will matter right until November. His supporters included many young people, out-of-state volunteers, and cyber-activists. They are not going to melt away. Yet they are not going to secure the Republican nomination for their man, either. What, then?

This looks

If I were to summarize the result, I might say "the Christian right's greatest achievement has been to stop the Clintons," or the New York Times would have to cover the GOP convention in some detail. However, the reality is much more complicated, and you wouldn't get that impression reading the news coverage. (The most recent New York Times story on the Christian right on Tuesday was about one-third of a sentence. The same article was published three months earlier about the Clinton Foundation, a long article that was only slightly longer.)

The Christian right has been a thorn in the side of the Republican Party for decades. If you follow the news at all, you'll notice that it was the Christian right who broke up the New Deal coalition and gave Ronald Reagan the momentum to triumph in 1980 and 1981. They are the primary force behind the Tea Party and right-

The state must also prove that Zimmerman reasonably believed that he was faced with imminent danger of death or great bodily harm.

prefix_text: When it comes to weird tourist attractions, it's hard to beat a stuffed black bear that died of what many people consider the worst cocaine overdose in history. Nicknamed Pablo EscoBear, the unique
reference_text:
tourist attraction is currently on display at the Kentucky for Kentucky Fun Mall, in Lexington.

On December 23, 1985, the New York Times reported about a 175-pound black bear that had apparently died of an overdose of cocaine in Georgia's Chattahoochee National Forest. Three months earlier, drug smuggler Andrew Thornton II had dropped large quantities of drugs from an airplane over that area, before jumping from it himself. Unfortunately, Thornton got tangled in his parachute and fell to his death in someone's yard, in Knoxville, Tennessee. Before turning to a life of crime, Kentucky blue blood Andrew Thornton II had worked as a narcotics officer of all things, and then as a lawyer. It is believed that he had built his network of connections during his time on the right side of the law, before becoming a drug smuggler. He was on a coke-smuggling run from Colombia when he dropped 40 plastic containers full of cocaine in Chattahoochee National Forest.

Luxury Goods and Status Symbols in Trouble in China

A friend recently mailed us an article from the Hong Kong Standard which describes how extremely high retail shop rents in Hong Kong can no longer
reference_text:
be paid even by retailers of luxury brands.

Gucci store in Hong Kong, Central

Photo via flickr

Not only is this testament to the fact that Hong Kong's real estate bubble has gotten out of hand quite a bit, but the waning demand for luxury goods is also highly interesting from a sociological and economic perspective. As the Standard reports:

Business is getting tougher for Hong Kong's retailers with the value of total retail sales dipping 1.6 percent in the first half of 2015 from a year back, according to the Census and Statistics Department's latest data. Valuable gifts, including jewelry, watches and luxury goods, were hardest hit, with sales falling for 10 consecutive months. Sales value slumped 10.4 percent in June compared with a year earlier, despite efforts by several luxury brands – including Italian fashion house Prada – to boost sales by cutting prices. Squeezed by slimmer pickings in Hong Kong and the mainland market, top global luxury brands

generated_result.0: absorb high-value, luxury goods. This was a rather surprising development, as a decade ago, the city's average retail rent at retail outlets was about $2,000 per square foot, with retail in Central, Kowloon, and Tsuen Wan on the high end. At that time, retail rents were generally not enough to support even the most high-end stores, but the new "super-luxury malls" that appeared in Hong Kong have a rents that are at least twice as high, in some cases six or seven times the average retail rent. In Hong Kong, the highest-end stores are increasingly being built in the high-end shopping district of Harcourt Road. When you change the viewing angle of your device by tilting it in any direction, any graphics present on the screen will appear to move. This adds a realistic layer of depth to iOS 7. prefix_text: When it comes to compression on the web, GZIP reigns supreme. In the 18 years since GZIP was first supported by browsers, other compression methods have been introduced but none have matched
reference_text:
GZIP's combination of speed, support and results.

Brotli, the compression algorithm Google released as open-source back in September, may soon change that. Chrome (version 49, due in early to mid March) will be shipping with Brotli support, and Firefox (version 44) already has it. Particularly given Chrome's significant reach on the Android platform, this means that Brotli support will go from zero to sixty in no time--bringing reduced file sizes along with it.

To get a better understanding of just how big those savings could be, and what the trade-offs are, we ran a few independent experiments.

Testing the Top 1000 URL's According to HTTP Archive

For the first set we took a list of the top 1000 URL's on the web (pulling the list from HTTP Archive) and downloaded the HTML for each page, as well as all JavaScript and CSS assets. For each asset, we recorded the original weight

the performance and ease-of-use of GZIP.

Although GZIP supports a wide variety of media file types, the most popular formats are most often used: GIF and PNG. While GIF and PNG are also compressed to GZIP as well, both are considered to be poor representations of images that can be represented by these other formats, which in turn are often perceived to be smaller files. Since all modern browsers are capable of displaying the compressed GIF and PNG images, those images cannot be compressed to GZIP without a significant performance impact.

GZIP can also be decompressed into an uncompressed, lossless compression format called Lossless (XZ). This compression format has also been found to provide better image quality than GZIP. In this case, the browser must be able to display the compressed image as intended. Lossless compression requires that the viewer cannot be deceived about the size of the file and does not rely on clever tricks to show th

That same month, Microsoft released Internet Explorer 6.0 and its compatibility with GZIP was officially removed. Even Chrome, which is an extension of the Chrome Web Store, is not yet compatible with GZIP.

the speed and efficiency of GZIP. We've looked at how to use GZIP in HTML and CSS, but what about a desktop app?

As I mentioned in a previous post, we've been working on a tool to make this process easier: zlib-webpack.

How does it work?

The idea of zlib-webpack is quite simple. First, you tell it what assets you want to compress, or how many files you want to compress, and then it finds those assets with a webpack dev tool, compresses them, and then creates a new file. It then combines these files into a new compressed file.

With webpack, this is called asset bundling. With zlib-webpack, it's called bundle-loading.

The bundle-loading part

What is it like to work at the DEA?
Does anyone know what it is like to work at the bench as a forensic chemist for the DEA? What kind

reference_text:
I wrote this blog post in 2011 on a different blog. I'm transferring it here to add to my list of topics under the Holistic Healing for PTSD tab. I might move a few other posts from that blog as well.

I can honestly say that now my family's life is not at all this intense around here. Time and experience and focusing on my own healing has improved things, even though both my husband and I had to hit our own bottoms before things have turned around for our family.

I have talked quite a bit on this blog about my insecurities and anxieties about my own capacity as a mother. Midway through my 40th year now, I spent about a year and a half examining the factors that have created my anxieties and feelings of inadequacy in mothering. I'm not sure how much it has helped. Sometimes I fall into the same patterns of behaving. But I keep searching for solutions.

reference_text:
in the past 15 years. In 2014, nearly one in two Americans (46.7 percent) selected cremation as an alternative to burial. This compares to only about one in four people (24.8 percent) who chose cremation in 1999. These findings come from the Cremation Statistics Annual Report produced by CANA, the preeminent source on cremation data for the United States and Canada.

Planning a burial at sea? Let owner Donna Capara, an expert in the field, help you arrange your ash scattering service at sea. With many ports to chose from Donna will arrange your private charter. Did you know the cost of a family attended private charter for 6 passengers is as low as $500.00? Larger vessels average $700.00 to $900.00 with a few a bit more.

Cremations were once extremely rare, but now, as much as half of the deceased at sea die without access to a funeral home. In some cases, they may die at sea at a time when there are no funeral homes, even in remote places like the Great Barrier Reef.

As a result, cremation has expanded to include cremation and burial at sea as well. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) says that in 2014, cremation at sea was used for 4.4 percent of all international maritime interments and burial at sea for 1.7 percent. In Europe, this is almost four-to-one with respect to cremation.

reference_text:

What was so clear was that a vast amount of conservation work has been done by landowners. Even more impressive is that the Wallowa Soil and Water Conservation District (SWCD) officials found promising results of improved water quality through their monitoring program.

Bill Moore, the OCA's past president, showed examples of how riparian areas have responded to grazing and total exclusion, along with the fact that weeds were a reoccurring problem in the non-grazed areas. Moore also showed significant challenges in addressing legacy issues, such as channelization projects funded by government programs more than 20 years ago, which are now believed to adversely affect water quality.

prefix_text: "Aggravated felony" is a term of art used to describe a category of offenses carrying particularly harsh immigration consequences for noncitizens convicted of such crimes. Regardless of their immigration status, noncitizens who
reference_text:
have been convicted of an "aggravated felony" are prohibited from receiving most forms of relief that would spare them from deportation, including asylum, and from being readmitted to the United States at any time in the future.

Despite what the ominous-sounding name may suggest, an "aggravated felony" does not require the crime to be "aggravated" or a "felony" to qualify. Instead, an "aggravated felony" is simply an offense that Congress sees fit to label as such, and today includes many nonviolent and seemingly minor offenses.

This fact sheet provides an overview of "aggravated felonies" under federal immigration law and the immigration consequences of being convicted of an "aggravated felony."

What Makes a Crime an "Aggravated Felony"?

An offense need not be "aggravated" or a "felony" in the place where the crime was committed to be considered an "agg

generated_result.0:
commit these crimes can face multiple punishments. Aggravated felony offenses carry sentences ranging from prison sentences to life in prison without parole.

Noncitizens convicted of these offenses will also have their deportation orders removed.

Noncitizens who receive a deportation order because of a prior deportation order are not automatically denied re-entry into the United States. However, under a different interpretation of the Immigration and Nationality Act ("INA"), deportation orders are denied to noncitizens convicted of felonies even if the immigrant is granted a pardon. So long as an individual has a valid deportation order, a judge may order that the noncitizen be deported under the INA or an immigration judge may grant a motion for a stay. Once the noncitizen is deported, he can seek relief under the INA or under federal law, such as the "Guideline for the Determination of Immigration Liability for Civil Immigration-Related Violations" or the "Guideline for the Determination of Immigration Li

Assassin's Creed Unity will run at 30 frames per second because "it feels more cinematic" and 60 frames per second
reference_text:
is difficult to accomplish, according to two of the game's developers.

Nicolas Guérin, the world level design director on Assassin's Creed Unity, told TechRadar that 60 frames per second was a prior goal for the open-world game, but that target wasn't a good fit. "At Ubisoft for a long time, we wanted to push 60 fps," he said. "I don't think it was a good idea because you don't gain that much from 60 fps, and it doesn't look like the real thing. It's a bit like The Hobbit movie, it looked really weird.

Exit Theatre Mode

"... So I think collectively in the video game industry we're dropping that standard because it's hard to achieve, it's twice as hard as 30 fps, and it's not really that great in terms of rendering quality of the picture and the image."

generated_result.1:
because "it feels more impressive and dramatic."

In an interview with IGN, Unity executive producer Alex Amancio explained his decision to drop frames per second and why he feels it's important for the player to experience his character's life on the ground at all times.

"We wanted to make it more cinematic," Amancio told IGN. "It felt more cinematic to us to let your character run around and jump around in the air and it felt more impressive and dramatic to let your character move in real time and interact with the world around them in a way that felt more believable than just looking at a character moving on a screen."

By Mary Ellen Klas

Miami Herald

QUINCY, Fla. — The 284 women housed in C-dorm at Gadsden Correctional Institution lived for months without hot water or
reference_text:
heat, faced flooded bathrooms daily and endured water rations when the septic tanks were jammed with food waste.

After state Rep. David Richardson demanded action following a series of surprise visits over the past 18 months, the private prison operator that runs the facility — Management Training Corp. of Centerville, Utah — received approval from the state to repair and replace the water heater, at a cost to taxpayers of nearly $10,000. But Warden Shelly Sonberg never authorized the work.

prefix_text: Even under the best of circumstances, writing is a difficult task. It requires a great deal of concentration, as well as plenty of time for daydreaming, experimenting, and chasing potential dead ends.
reference_text:
So when the British novelist Kazuo Ishiguro, who won the Nobel Prize in Literature today, found himself stalled on a book, he and his wife developed a plan. He would set aside four weeks to devote himself exclusively to writing. And his wife, Lorna? She would take care of everything else.

In an article written for The Guardian back in 2014, Ishiguro explains that this division of household labor was essential in the creation of his Man Booker Prize-winning novel The Remains of the Day:

I would, for a four-week period, ruthlessly clear my diary and go on what we somewhat mysteriously called a "Crash." During the Crash, I would do nothing but write from 9am to 10.30pm, Monday through Saturday. I'd get one hour off for lunch and two for dinner. I'd not see, let alone answer, any mail, and would not go near the phone. No one would come to the house.

Italian Marxist Raniero Panzieri on the capitalist use of technology and machines.

Introduction to Panzieri

It is well known that, for Marx, capitalism revolutionizes both "
reference_text:
the groupings into which society is divided" and "the technical processes of labour". What is less well known is that Marx theorizes the unity of these two moments (social groupings and technical processes) as constituting "a specifically capitalist mode of production" (our emphasis). Taken in isolation from the technical processes of labour the social groupings (i.e. wage-labourers and capitalists) constitute what Marx calls a formal subsumption of labour under capital; but on the basis of this formal subsumption there is erected a set of "methods,means and conditions" of production which Marx terms the real subsumption of labour under capital. This is elaborated at length in Marx's recently published Results of the Immediate Process of Production (the so-called 'lost chapter' of Capital) - but the same perspective is abundantly clear in Capital itself, as was demonstrated nearly twenty years ago in the article by Raniero Panzieri printed below.

It is natural that, as the world of economy is transformed into that of machinery, "all previous modes of existence in the sphere of production [i.e., the economic sphere] disappear," including those of life. But even now, we can see that, however large the role of the economic revolution, it is still only a stage on the way to the realization of another stage – that of political economy. Thus, although the "economic revolution" is a positive process which transforms "life" (and by extension, the way men live and think), this transformation comes about through the economic mechanism, not through the "life" or "thought" of men. The statement said the Russian pilot ignored Estonia's air traffic control despite its responders being switched on.

There have been regular squabbles between the Nato alliance and Russia in the Baltic region, which is close to the Russian border. Both sides accuse the other of ignoring transponders, though according to Postimees newspaper most Russian planes are fitted with Soviet-era transponders which render Western civilian radar "blind" to them.

A spokesperson for Amazon says the company will begin collecting state sales taxes in March. (Photo courtesy Amazon.com/MGN)

Amazon will start collecting Arkansans sales tax starting in March
reference_text:
, according to a spokeswoman for the company.

"Amazon will begin collecting sales tax in the state of Arkansas beginning March 1, 2017," Jill Kerr of Amazon said in a short statement to Channel 7 News.

Amazon currently collects sales tax in 38 states and the District of Columbia.

In the Arkansas legislature two separate bills aimed at attempting to collect sales tax from out of state retailers without a physical presence in the state have been proposed.

House bill 1388 proposed by Rep. Dan Douglas (R-Distrcit 91) passed the House Wednesday and has been referred to the Senate.

Senate bill 140 proposed by Sen. Jake Files (R-District 8) passed the Senate last week and has been referred to the House.

The spokeswoman declined to comment on whether or not the bills were a determining factor in the company starting to collect sales tax.

Recently Amazon began collecting sales tax in several other states where legislation was passed or pending that would put

generated_result.0:
, a spokesperson for the online retail company told The Associated Press.

The tax would help fund state road and park budgets and pay for public safety and environmental work to help reduce flood risks, spokeswoman Brooke Buchanan-Jones said.

"It's about time," Buchanan-Jones said. "It's a common sense tax that's needed to save Arkansans money."

Arkansas doesn't have a sales tax in place because it is not a state.

Arkansans have already received letters from the IRS stating that the online retailer is required to collect tax from the first $15 of an Amazon purchase, according to a copy posted by NewsChannel 15. The company told Arkansas legislators that it "will collect $15 of taxes from each Amazon order if we have a legal obligation to do so under federal law."

Amazon currently sells products in Arkansas at 10 states, and it has warehouses in 13 states, according to the company's website. Amazon's main office i
generated_result.1:
.

The company released a statement Wednesday afternoon saying, "We are the first in Arkansas to collect sales taxes in the state. By law, sales tax must be collected by March 1, 2018, which is April 10, 2018. As a state we will collect taxes on all taxable purchases during the first quarter."

Arkansas sales tax is 3.9% for items bought online, 4.5% for grocery and drug stores, and 6.1% for grocery and drug stores.

A spokesman for the state said Amazon is one of three corporations that pay state sales tax. The state collects 5.25% sales tax, 2.975% for retailers with sales in the state and another 1.25% for retailers that sell more than $50,000 worth of goods.

generated_result.2:
, the company announced Monday.

The move follows other states, which already have started collecting sales tax.

Arkansas sales tax is based on the rate of a sales tax paid in a state. For example, sales tax would be charged in the same way a shopper pays a car dealer in Arkansas. This is a common practice in many states, but not in many areas, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures.

To collect sales taxes, a company must submit an annual income tax return with a 1099-MISC reporting sheet. A company can file a state-wide return in the same form, but not for a single business.

In Arkansas, there is a separate sales tax return for all sales of tangible personal property and services, which are not services.

Businesses in the state also can pay a state-wide tax for each business.

The latest release of Australian unemployment data has largely caught economists, and by extension the market, sharply by surprise.

In fact, rather than coming in at the forecasted 5.9% the
reference_text:
unemployment rate actually declined to 5.7% in April. Subsequently, the labor market appears to be going through resurgence but just how robust the current gains are remains to be seen, Economic Calendar reported.

The employment change figures for April showed a gain of around 37.4k jobs, which followed on from a rise of 60k in March. Obviously, this is a welcome strengthening of the labor market and should lead to some inflationary gains over the medium term. However, the headline rate was a little less impressive with full time positions declining by nearly 11.6k in April. Subsequently, the rise in part-time employment is a relatively concerning trend in the Australian economy.

In fact, the total hours worked metric declined by around 0.3% whilst part time employment has risen by over 111,300 positions in the past year. This all highlights the underlying reasons why the unemployment rate and job gain figures can be somewhat misleading. It also goes some of the way

The reason?

This latest number is based on the labour force participation rate, or how many people are in the labour force, rather than actually looking at total jobs in the economy.

The participation rate – in other words how many people are working or looking for work – has fallen sharply in the past year and the latest number shows it has just dropped below 62%.

How bad is this?

That's the big question. The ABS said its final estimate of 6.5 million jobs created between September 2014 and August 2015, for the full year, would leave Australia with a total unemployment rate of 6.5%, or 8.5% in July.

But the latest ABS figures actually show a much higher level of 6.3 million jobs added, and the decline of 2.1% is actually less drastic.

The size of the labour market

The size of the labour force in the economy has been a closely watched measure of the economy's ability to absorb changes in the labour market.

The ABS has been publishing quarterly estimates on the size of the labour force since its inception in 1981.

In June, it saw the labour force swell by 24,000 (compared to July's 26,000), which was well above the 5.2% forecast.

It's important to note that the figures cover all those aged 15-64, and that this is an under-estimate.

Published Aug 24, 2006 10:19 PM

Milena Del Valle didn't get the chance to greet her loved ones at Logan International Airport on
reference_text:
July 10. While traveling with her spouse to the airport, Del Valle, a working-class Costa Rican living in Boston, was crushed to death when three-ton concrete ceiling panels in the Inter state 90 tunnel connector let loose and fell on the couple's car. Angel Del Valle survived with minor physical injuries.

Ongoing investigations since the tra gedy have found many structural design flaws. One of the most serious: The bolts used to secure the panels weren't capable of supporting their weight for the length of time the general contractors, the Bechtel Group and Parsons Brickenhoff, said they would.

The Laborers and Iron Workers unions, among others, had raised concerns about these flaws for years. They were ignored.

prefix_text: Back in the mid 1980s, GE and NASA began testing on a new propulsion system that used counter rotating fan assemblies in an attempt to boost efficiency. The testing ultimately led to the design of the GE
reference_text:
36 experimental aircraft engine, but was then set aside to explore other options. Now, GE and NASA are planning on revisiting the design and adding some new technology to the mix.

The design is ultimately a hybrid between a Turbofan and Turboprop, which was aptly named a Propfan or Unducted Fan. The process begins by using a turbofan engine with the fans relocated to the outside of the engine housing. As the exhaust from the turbofan engine is forced out, they pass over a turbine which is connected to a prop on the exterior, while the other prop is driven by the turbofan.

Both sets of props have variable pitch blades that featured a dramatic curve, similar to a scimitar, which would allow the engine to reach speeds close to Mach.75. Along with the high flight speeds, the engine also showed a 30% to 35% decrease in fuel consumption. The only real drawback to using a Propfan engine

generated_result.0:
's own Reaction Control System (RCS) which had very low thrust and was limited to just four rotors (2 per rotor) to reduce drag. But there was no way to eliminate the need for thrust vectoring. Thus, GE became interested in using the same fan assembly in a more powerful version, the GE90.

But what if instead of four rotors the GE90 had five? There were a number of ideas that went around the design development table.

In the end it was decided that the five rotors should be mounted as a single system because at that point no other propulsion system would be capable of increasing the power level.

A concept design sketch of the GE90.

The GE90's configuration would have six engines, two on each side of the engine and the other three on a common lower hub. The engine would be mounted in an air-filtration duct and at the back of the duct would be a compressor with compressor motors,
generated_result.1:
6-bladed fan system with 2-3-4-6-blade motors for the Space Shuttle's External Tank. The engine itself is a 1,400 horsepower V2S combustion chamber design and is located in the External Tank. These fans are mounted to the front of the tank and produce an internal pressure of 1,700 psia with a flow rate of 18,000 fpm. GE says that these engines will reduce the size of the internal tank by 12 to 13 percent and the overall weight of the tanks by 20 to 25 percent.

The GE 6-blade fan system can increase the thrust from a minimum of 2.5 lbs to 4.4 lbs. and provide an additional 30 to 40 percent fuel savings in the tank. To improve the performance of the engine system, each fan is independently adjusted for the specific lift to altitude (SLA) and thrust envelope (TPE) requirements. In particular, these fan blades were designed for the thrust envelope of the ST
generated_result.2:
RS-68. This engine is a counter rotation system consisting of two vertical turbine blades in a conventional thrust chamber. The engines are powered by the combination of a fuel-rich oxidizer mix and water which is separated from the exhaust flow, the latter being routed through a high pressure turbine to generate high-pressure thrust. The GE RS-68 is powered by a conventional combustion chamber with two liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen jets each feeding a pair of electric turbopumps. The RS-68 engines were made up of four identical bladed rotary flanges that fed one and all four fuel pumps. As the engine burned, its cooling system removed exhaust heat from the combustion mixture, which was directed onto the rotary blades. This system helped reduce the thrust generated and made the engine more efficient than a fuel-rich oxidizer mixture in a conventional chamber. The RS-68 was produced at the GM factory in Flint, Michigan.

prefix_text: Most Americans think that miles of machine-planted row crops and crowded feedlots are required to feed everyone—that without large-scale, industrial agriculture, with its chemical inputs and GMOs, we
reference_text:
would all starve to death.

Even people who know that organic agriculture is just as productive as industrial agriculture often think you need to have acres of land to grow all your own food. Here's why this is totally false…

How Much Land is Enough?

As any of the millions of subsistence farmers and smallholders around the world will tell you, depending on the quality of your land and the size of your family, you can grow all the food you need in a very small space.

It simply requires designing a food production system that works with natural processes to make the most of what you have. (See above image of the Russian dacha neighborhoods where everyone's yard is full of food.)

If you want to develop your land for food production, the following infographic shows just how much land is needed to be self sufficient, including generating all the solar energy you need to run your home.

According to this image, you need a mere 2 acres!

generated_result.0:
'd all be eating grass. But these are false premises. The truth is that if everyone had access to food, we'd all be healthier and more happy.

According to a recent study by the Natural Resources Defense Council, food wasted and wasted at the supermarket is twice as bad for you as food wasted on the farm. Many studies show that it's cheaper and healthier to eat the food you're currently eating than to go out and buy more and more. This is especially true when it comes to growing your own food and using it to produce more food.

Advertisement


Even worse, the use of pesticides and fertilizers makes it even harder for you to reach your nutritional needs. To illustrate this point, try this simple experiment. The researchers analyzed the effects of pesticides on rats' teeth over time. They found that in areas with an intensive crop farming industry, teeth of the rats that ate a chemical-rich diet (which typically used herbicides), grew worse over time. I
generated_result.1:
would all starve. They don't know, for instance, that the food we get from a single industrial farm, or from the few industrial crops planted in a given field, isn't the same as the food we get from the people who grow the crops and harvest them. As one blogger put it:

If one of the crops was a good thing for the people growing it, then one would expect many farmers to have chosen to plant it over other crops, so as to ensure that each individual could get the best possible price. The problem is that so many of them have opted to grow just one crop and the price for each has soared to $35/lb, far higher than the usual average of $16/lb. It seems to me that the only rational conclusion from this is that many farmers are so far behind on their land purchases, loans, etc., that they are just about to be bankrupted by their greed.

Of course, we all know this is jus

You get the Lenovo IdeaPad Yoga 11 — a Windows RT tablet which will be available in December for $799 and up.

Like its 13 inch sibling, the Yoga 11 gets its name from its flexible hinge. You can use the computer in laptop mode. Or you can push the screen back until its resting on on the base of the computer, letting you pick up the device and use it like a tablet.

That should be a little easier to do with the smaller model since it's thinner and lighter than the Yoga 13 — although it's not nearly as light as a tablet that doesn't have a keyboard attached.

The IdeaPad Yoga 11 measures 11.7″ x 8″ x 0.6″ and weighs about 2.8 pounds. It features an 11.6 inch, 1366 x 768 pixel display, a 5-point capacitive multitouch touchscreen, up to 2GB of RAM and up to 64GB of storage.

reference_text:

The report, by the Hotline for Refugees and Migrants, is based mainly on interviews with 72 detainees. It covers the Saharonim and Givon prisons, the open detention facility at Holot and the Yahalom lockup, where illegal entrants facing deportation are held. Altogether, these facilities hold some 5,000 people, including asylum seekers from Eritrea and Sudan and foreign workers or tourists without valid visas.

The report charged that overcrowding at these facilities violates the law. At Saharonim, for instance, interviewees said there were 10 detainees per cell, double the capacity in the prison's master plan. Human beings love being outside —
reference_text:
an estimated 8 billion visits are made annually to natural protected areas, a number that's larger than the total world population.

But could spending time in natural scenery also have larger implications for how we behave politically, or how we treat one another?

A new study suggests the answer is yes.

The paper, just out in the Journal of Environmental Psychology, is by psychologist John M. Zelenski and several other colleagues from Carleton University in Ottawa, Canada. In the study, the researchers wanted to test the idea that there's a link between actually experiencing the natural world, and behaving in a sustainable way. "We hypothesize that participants exposed to nature will make more cooperative, and thus sustainable, choices," they wrote.

And how can we forget the efforts of the Santa Ysabel tribe who are threatening to launch their own online poker website without the state's permission.

With so many possible scenarios capable of being played out over the next couple of weeks let's take a look at what will happen under the most likely scenario, which is the legislature not acting —The senate bill has already been pulled off the table according to the LA Times and the Assembly bill starting to look like a lost cause as well— and what that will lead to in California.

It's time to get serious about online poker in California.

California: Can We Pass a Law Against Online Poker Now?

California has passed at least a dozen online poker bills over the years, including the California Online Gaming Law (2010), which has now been put on hold because the House and Senate have not even reached an agreement on a draft bill. This leaves only the current bill before the legislature.

California has consistently led online poker legislation in the United States, making it a must-pass issue. The bill has been amended numerous times to keep up with changes in state gaming regulations and the federal government. This is an important state issue that must be dealt with soon if we want to keep
generated_result.1:
day. If you've ever wanted to start putting together your big money online pot, now is your chance.

The California Electronic Poker Association, a gaming industry group, released a statement this afternoon stating that they would continue to work with legislators to try and find a solution in 2014.

"We appreciate all of the good will we have received from members of the gaming community since we began our efforts with a draft bill," stated the EAPA President Matt McEntee. "But at this critical time in the gaming industry, EAPA will continue to seek ways to help our members by sharing information with policymakers and legislators."

The next couple of weeks are vital, with a flurry of online poker bills being released this week. The most current piece of legislation is being circulated by the Nevada Gaming Commission, and it's looking to add online poker games to their state's legalized casinos.

The draft bill has not been scheduled yet, but the bill is expected to b
generated_result.2:
deadline. The only hope is to have a statehouse bill signed into law by the end of the year. Otherwise, California will lose its online poker monopoly status.

Online poker should not be "gambling" in any form. But it can be a great business opportunity for the state's gaming industry.

I know online poker has its critics, but with a lot of hard work and an active media campaign the game can still come back from that corner. Let's hope it does.

Being 10-years-old is hard enough -- and add in an isolating syndrome like Asperger's and making friends can be even more difficult
reference_text:
.

Such is the case of Colin. He is a 10-year-old boy who lives in Michigan and is on the lower end of the autism spectrum. Despite his efforts to make friends, he is usually made fun of and eats his lunch in the school office because other kids won't let him sit at their tables, according to his mother.

When Colin's mother, Jennifer Cunningham, asked him if he wanted a birthday party, he responded that there wasn't any point because he didn't have friends. That's when she decided to surprise him by creating a "Happy Birthday Colin" Facebook page.

"I created this page for my amazing, wonderful, challenging son who is about to turn 11 on March 9th. Because of Colin's disabilities, social skills are not easy for him, and he often acts out in school, and the other kids don't like him," Cunningham wrote on February 2, when she created the page. "So I thought, if

generated_result.0:
, according to research by the British charity Help Autism Now.

The organization, which runs the world's largest autistic network, conducted two studies on 20 and 25-year-old adults with Asperger's syndrome and autism.

The first study involved nearly 700 adults with Asperger's and the second about 790 adults with autism and a non-specific autism spectrum disorder. Both groups came from the London school system, the authors wrote in the journal Autism Research & Therapy.

The study participants had been diagnosed with autism between their early teens and mid-30s and given an extensive questionnaire to measure their experiences. These included the number of friends with autism or Asperger's and whether their relatives or friends seemed autistic to them, as well as social interactions.

Among the adults, those with Asperger's and autism said they were much less likely to have had an autism-related conversation in the past year, while they were also much less likely to say
generated_result.1:
. But that's where the internet comes in.

Asperger's syndrome can be the reason for your most memorable moments of the day or a friendship you'd never have imagined. In the world of Facebook, you can be friends with someone who is as autistic as they are, with a name like "Polar Bear."

As per usual, these friends share lots of interesting and often unexpected things about their lives, their experiences, and how they relate to the web.

We've done a lot of legwork over the years to collect as much of this as possible, so let's take a deep dive into some of the most interesting Facebook friends that I've come across.

Polar Bear

This guy is really kind of an odd one. He's got three eyes and a pair of eyebrows on each side of his head, and he seems to get into the most unusual conversations on Facebook.

He's a pretty interesting guy, so it's
generated_result.2:
. I remember when friends who were born after I became a teenager asked me to meet them as I was growing up. I would say that was weird -- after all, there are people like me and there aren't.

We've come a long way from that, thanks to people like Mark Zuckerberg and Larry Page. Now we can all share the same space. I'm one of those new friends. It's weird.

And now there are 10 more of us to make the party last just as long as I did.

Just who are these people, doing the holiest thing a human being can do: running towards the injured and dead instead of running away from them.

There is something about seeing first responders going about their work that restores our hope in humanity. Just as importantly, there is something about seeing them that can teach us a lesson in theology.

prefix_text:
Content and scheduling

Each integration course consists of a language course and an orientation course. The general integration course comprises 660 lessons, and depending on the focus of the course that applies to you, the
reference_text:
course could last for up to 960 lessons in total.

The language course

The language course comprises a total of 600 lessons on the general integration course, and up to 900 lessons on special courses.

The language course will cover important aspects of everyday life, e.g.

work and career,

basic and further training,

bringing up and raising children,

shopping/trade/consumption,

leisure time and social interaction,

health and hygiene/human body,

media and media use, and

housing.

You will also learn to write letters and e-mails in German, complete forms, make telephone calls and apply for jobs. Topics will vary depending on which type of course you attend. If for example you attend a youth integration course, you will deal with topics which are of particular interest to young people such as applying for an apprenticeship.

You will take intermediate tests during the language

generated_result.0:
lessons may cover a range of languages.

Some languages are covered in both the general course and the orientation course. For example, a German integration course will cover German to English translation and grammatical analysis. The German integration course is typically 6-9 hours long. The orientation course, on the other hand, is generally 30 minutes long (about 50 lessons in total). The orientation course, however, is typically one week long (about 75 lessons in total), although the content of lessons from that one week may vary slightly, depending on the program.

There are a number of programs offering multiple integration courses, each focused on a different language area, such as a German to French or English to German integration course.

In addition to a language course, you'll probably also receive a text course that can complement either the language course or the orientation course (depending on the program). A text course consists of a few hours of lectures, followed by a number of reading assignments (about 10
generated_result.1:
number of lessons may be less than a typical general integration course.

The orientation course comprises 140 lessons. Each one of these 140 lessons is a different language lesson, and some of them are not particularly related to the main goal of the course.

At the end of the orientation course, the student can then choose from four of the courses: general, integration, linguistic proficiency and other.

The choice of course will be decided on the basis of the following criteria:

The course description is clear and unambiguous and shows the course in the context of language learning in general

The integration requirements meet the needs of the integration course

The language level of the student meets the expectations of the language level of the language course (if applicable)

The quality of the lesson presentation meets the expectations of the language level of the language course (if applicable)

If the integration requirements for each course overlap, these courses are combined and students are considered one course. This
generated_result.2:
amount of time required may vary.

The English language course is a series of lessons, each devoted to a single topic. The integration course can be broken down into more than a dozen segments, each devoted to a particular topic. The main goal of the course is to develop your understanding of English grammar and vocabulary.

What you will learn

Throughout the course, we provide you with a variety of lesson structures in the form of short videos, audio files, and lesson notes. You may watch these material as a series of videos on YouTube or in a single audio file.

We are happy to work with you to decide what topics and what kind of content are most appropriate for your teaching style and to tailor the content to meet your needs.

prefix_text:
DIY gardening is on the rise in Tokyo, reflected in the city's changing landscape and on its dinner plates.

Tucked away in an oasis of calm in Tokyo's Setagaya
reference_text:
ward, Yoshi's apartment is like many others in urban Japan, save for one key difference. If you crack the window in his living room you'll find a good-sized ledge with a number of pots where the 31-year-old white collar worker tends to his growing "mini-farm".

"This is my little garden," he told The Diplomat, pointing to different pots from which tomatoes and other low maintenance greens can be seen sprouting. "I really like the idea of growing some of my own food, even if it's just a small part of what I eat."

While Yoshi's crops may be modest, he is part of a global trend: an increasing number of urbanites are developing a green thumb. The movement – urban farming or DIY gardening – operates on the belief that localizing our food production is a good idea indeed.

As National Geographic points out, a number of pressing issues have put food production at the forefront, from the population explosion

generated_result.0:
ward is Nogami Tofu, a new business created by the owner of Nogami Shokudo and a fellow student at Kansai University.

Nogami Tofu sells dried Tofu balls in a "pouch" in the garden of his parents' house. Each pouch holds 40 to 50 balls and costs around 300 yen ($3.80 to $4.50). It is quite a bargain for a snack that may be a little on the light side if you're a carnivore, but will be on the lighter side if you're a fan of fried tofu.

For those who are more adventurous and would like to try a taste of what Nogami Tofu offers as well as some of his own creations, he plans to open a larger shop in the spring of this year, said Yoshio.

Related: The Foodie Next Door (and Beyond)

Nogami Tofu was founded by a
generated_result.1:
ward is the Yamabe Tofu House, where the best and biggest in the area are served.

The place is run by veteran chef Hidekazu Yamabe and his wife Kajiko, and they use only local tofu — a key ingredient in their delicious Tofu Bites.

One serving of the humble tofu, the type most people in the developing world eat in a pinch, can be found in a meal priced at around 10,000 yen (NZ$114) each.

It's the first and most popular dish on the menu at the restaurant, which has a number of other high-priced entrees as well including'shoukei' - which means hot and not spicy-dipping sushi.

As a Japanese woman and a vegetarian, being able to eat tofu with my dinner was a dream come true.

After my taste test session in the food court, I went to the restaurant for my second one to tes
generated_result.2:
Ward, a neighborhood full of shabby apartments and shabby shops, is Takamatsu Garden, the place to start your garden.

It's been around since the 1700s and has been maintained through the years by volunteers, most notably the late Mr. Nobutaka Shirogane.

His sons, Kenichi and Kiyoshi, took over in the mid-1990s and continue to maintain the garden and keep it going.

"We don't do anything fancy, just the basics: make sure to water, fertilize and keep the soil healthy so that you have a good yield," says Mr. Kenichi, who is 61.

Kenichi remembers that it was an accident when the family moved in. They didn't know if they were supposed to garden and when they saw a sign for Takamatsu Garden they assumed it was a Japanese garden.

However, they were surprised to find that it was a nursery for flower gardens.

"It's a question you had about time, and in the past few months, you said that you've used your personal account for two minutes and you've done some work from your personal account, so that's two minutes," she said. "But is it ever — is it ever appropriate — is it ever appropriate to have two emails on your personal device?"

"It is not," she replied.

That was a clear rebuke of Republican arguments that Clinton might not have used a separate server for her personal email, even though FBI Director James Comey said they were necessary for convenience.

Item #: SCP-1473

Special Containment Procedures: SCP-1473 is to be kept in Containment Locker #
reference_text:
512 at Site-23. All testing subjects experiencing the object's effects are to be monitored at all times until the cessation of the testing session, which may extend up to three (3) months, via either video feed or direct personnel contact. No printers are to be kept within 100m of the object in any direction and all documents printed within Site-23 are to be triple-checked for discrepancies before being distributed. If such discrepancies are found, all personnel involved with reviewing the documents are to be tested for the presence of SCP-1473-B and administered Class-A amnestics if the infection is found.

Description: SCP-1473 is an HP LaserJet 4M printer that affects random documents upon their printing. Access is not to be permitted within 300 meters of any area in which SCP-1473 is located. Personnel are not to be permitted to access the interior, unless authorized. The door is to be monitored for any deviations.

Description: SCP-1473 is a series of circular, yellow-white glass spheres measuring approximately 0.6 m in diameter, composed of glass of varying quality, with an extremely durable inner coating. Each of these spheres has its own anomalous property, which is unknown. The spherical contents retain the ability to alter and change over time, as SCP-1473 itself is able to alter and change within the confines of its interior. The contents of SCP-1473 appear to resemble water droplets; the interior of the spheres themselves is composed of a solid, transparent, and odorless substance of unknown origin.

EPA employees are calling their senators to complain about President Donald Trump's choice to head the agency, according to The New York Times.

They are furious Trump nominated Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt to lead
reference_text:
the agency. Pruitt has battled the EPA numerous times in court, earning the hatred of many of the agency's employees.

"Employees of the [EPA] have been calling their senators to urge them to vote on Friday against the confirmation of Scott Pruitt, President Trump's contentious nominee to run the agency, a remarkable display of activism and defiance that presages turbulent times ahead for the E.P.A," reports The New York Times.

Agency employees are likely concerned about budget cuts, as leaked memos from Trump's transition team call for $513 million in cuts to the "states and tribal assistance grants," and claim $193 million in savings from eliminating agency global warming programs and $109 million in savings from cutting "environment programs and management."

"Many of the scientists, environmental lawyers and policy experts who work in E.P.A. offices around the country say the calls are a last resort for workers who fear a nominee selected to run an agency he has made

generated_result.0:
the EPA after months of inaction by top members of his own administration.

Pruitt and Republican lawmakers have opposed climate science and climate policies, and Pruitt has opposed regulating the emissions from cars, trucks and power plants.

In an opinion piece, Pruitt told The Post that it was time for the federal government to "stop overreacting" to climate change, citing his refusal to label global warming a hoax.

On Tuesday, White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer announced Pruitt would serve as Oklahoma's attorney general.

"The President believes, and the Attorney General believes, that the primary thing EPA should focus on is environmental protection, and the attorney general believes that it should focus on this as an area that is so vital to the state and the nation," Spicer said in an appearance at his daily press briefing.

Senate Environment and Public Works Chairman Jay Rockefeller, a New York Democrat, announced Monday he would bring charges against Pruitt over a pair of cases Pruitt has sued over
generated_result.1:
the EPA, which is tasked with protecting the environment. Their objections stem from his long-term campaign against Obama's Clean Power Plan, which has led to the closure or delay of more than a dozen coal-fired power plants. He has also sued to stop the EPA's regulation of ozone, a pollution that's deadly to the lungs of billions of people globally.

And Pruitt has received a glowing review by conservative groups who see him as being anti-environmental and would undo Obama's environmental legacy.

"Scott Pruitt has made it clear that he views climate change as a hoax perpetuated by the Chinese," wrote 350.org, which advocates for efforts to reduce carbon emissions, in a statement. "And because he has no experience running the federal government, the only reason he's been confirmed is because Republicans in Congress, looking for a new conservative voice, have chosen a climate-change denier as their nominee."

This week, the conservative watchdog organization Heartland Institute releas

the EPA's enforcement branch. They say that Pruitt, a vocal critic of environmental rules and a prominent fund-raiser for fossil fuel companies, is unfit for the job, because he sued the EPA more than two dozen times during his time as attorney general.

Pruitt also once sued the EPA's own inspectors general for allegedly mismanaging federal water resources, according to the Times. It's not clear who would lead the office overseeing the agency's enforcement functions at the Justice Department — it is currently headed by the acting EPA administrator, Carol Browner, who Pruitt would replace.

Related Story: http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/article/2596511

The Times is writing that Trump's decision to pick Pruitt as the next EPA administrator is creating "uncertainty over how much oversight the agency will have."

prefix_text: Today, whisk(e)y writer Jim Murray, the most well-known name in the judging of brown spirits, announced the winning whiskies among those judged for his annual release of the Whiskey
reference_text:
Bible (available November 24), his guide to every whiskey (over 1,000 of them) that he graded over the course of 2015. The guide is always controversial: last year Murray gave the top award to Yamazaki Sherry Cask 2013, marking the first time that a Japanese whisky took the title; he didn't include a single bottle from Scotland on the shortlist. This year, however, marks the high-water mark for Murray's controversy. The 2016 World Whisky of the Year is an offering from Crown Royal, a company that was second in US whiskey sales only to Jack Daniels in 2014. The distillery's new release, Northern Harvest Rye, scored 97.5 points on Murray's 100-point scale to take home the title. The runner-up is another rye; third place goes to an Irish whiskey, a first for the island nation; and again, no Scottish bottles made the top five.

reference_text:
