NATIONAL CHILDHOOD
reference_text:
VACCINE INJURY ACT, PREEMPTION, TORT LAW, PERTUSSIS, DTP, DTaP

After their daughter suffered severe health problems following a routine vaccination for diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis ("DTP"), Russell and Robalee Bruesewitz sued Wyeth, Inc., the manufacturer of the vaccine, alleging that Wyeth's DTP vaccine was outmoded and inadequately designed. In response, Wyeth argued that Section 22(b)(1) of the National Childhood Vaccine Injury Act ("NCVIA") exempted vaccine manufacturers from all design-defect claims, including the one asserted by the Bruesewitz family. The Third Circuit Court of Appeals agreed with Wyeth and dismissed the claim. The Supreme Court must now determine whether to sustain the categorical preclusion of all design-defect claims advanced against vaccine manufacturers, or whether to expose vaccine manufacturers to potential design-based litigation

This Battle of Antietam had many implications for both sides - both sides knew that it was going to affect the outcome of the war in the south, and at least partly because it was going to bring about the end of slavery in the south, the Confederate soldiers took it as a personal insult. A 24-year-old Brazilian fighter, Paredes had been training in California for more than a year, but he began training in the Philippines the same day as his mother and was scheduled to fight the night before. Police have said that Paredes had stopped taking prescribed medication and drank the bottle of liquor he had bought from the local store just hours before the fight. He was the last of three fighters to suffer a bout of bleeding and then die. He was 27.

May 24, 2013: Scott Mitchell died after a bout in Mexico

Mitchell was training in Mexico for a couple weeks when he suffered a heart attack. An autopsy revealed he died of a heart attack or heart attack-related causes, not from the fight itself. The fight was stopped after the referee had waved off the bout. Mitchell was 22.

prefix_text: Like many of his projects, Guillermo del Toro's planned stop-motion animated adaptation of Pinocchio seems to have found itself stuck in limbo, with very little in the way of movement.
reference_text:
In January, del Toro announced that he was still working on the film, and had enlisted Emmy winner Patrick McHale to help pen the screenplay. And now in an interview with IndieWire, the filmmaker has revealed that it is ready to go, but he's having troubled finding the necessary financing.

"I've been looking for financing for almost ten years," said del Toro. "We have the puppets, we have the design. I always or almost always complicate my life. None of the movies I want to do are easy. And they don't belong to anything anyone wanted to do at that time. No one wanted to do superheroes when I did Hellboy, no one wanted to do monsters when I did Pacific Rim. In response to the controversy, del Toro has decided to create a Kickstarter campaign to solicit the funds needed to finish the project. The campaign is currently on top of its funding goal.

The Kickstarter campaign will allow del Toro to raise the $1.25 million it will require in order to get the project completed, with an estimated completion date of fall 2015. According to the Kickstarter announcement, del Toro is attempting to raise $150,000 for the budget-cutting project.

Del Toro's Pinocchio, a book that is now in its 50th year, has been adapted multiple times over the years. Originally being featured in 1928 as an original story, the movie was first released theatrically in 1940. Then in 1972, the film was re-released with the original story and a new title of The Lion King. However, Disney took the rights to Pinocchio and the film eventually saw release in 1983 under the title of Pinocchio and the Snow Queen. Disney
generated_result.1:

As mentioned, Disney would like to use Pixar as a reference point for the "Pinocchio" story, and Disney and Pixar are currently in negotiations to see if that would be possible. In addition to this deal, this new animation is expected to be made at an unspecified delay, which means that it could be several years before the "Pinocchio" project appears on screen, though that delay isn't necessarily a bad thing.

The answer lies in the studio behind the film. Universal Pictures has an ownership stake in the production, but the film was supposed to begin shooting in September. As of December, a new report has revealed that the Pinocchio project has been pushed to February of 2018, and that Paramount Pictures is the studio behind the project. It's being produced by Scott Rudin and Phil Lord & Christopher Miller, who have directed several horror films, most notably the recent Hell Fest. The studio seems to have decided not to go ahead with any 3D versions of the film, or even a reboot of Pinocchio.

prefix_text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — Commissioners in a Florida county are so tired of spending money on President Donald Trump's frequent visits to his Mar-a-Lago resort that some are suggesting
reference_text:
a special tax be levied against the property if the federal government doesn't reimburse its costs.

Palm Beach County spends more than $60,000 a day when the president visits, mostly for law enforcement overtime — almost $2 million since January. Sheriff Ric Bradshaw says the county was expected to spend $250,000 during Trump's recent meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping, the president's sixth trip to his Winter White House in the 12 weeks since his inauguration.

County Commissioner Dave Kerner has suggested turning Mar-a-Lago into a special taxing district and imposing a levy on the resort to pay the president's security costs. Because Mar-a-Lago is incorporated as a club, it pays lower property taxes than hotels. It also gets a tax break because Trump surrendered development rights after he purchased the property from the estate of cereal heiress Marjorie Merriweather Post for $10 million in 1985.

The 500 members pay $14,000 annually

The county commissioners are considering asking for the rebate at a meeting in March.

At their meeting Thursday, the commissioners discussed ways to cut back on the county's current budget.

If the county commissioners decide to take up the issue, they will be taking aim at one of President Donald Trump's signature political campaign promises. The county had sought a $21 million federal subsidy for a "Mar-a-Lago resort tax break" for the president — $16 million of which went for upgrades at the Palm Beach club. The plan was scrapped in July after Trump vowed to keep his Florida resort open during the current shutdown.

Commissioner David Roberts, a Republican who is retiring, said he supported the plan that gave Trump the tax break during his campaign but said the county's spending needs to come under control.

Explore seven surprising facts about Joan of Arc, 600 years after the courageous teenager rose from obscurity to lead the French army.

1. Joan's real name was Jehanne d'Arc,
reference_text:
Jehanne Tarc, Jehanne Romée or possibly Jehanne de Vouthon—but she didn't go by any of these.

Joan didn't hail from a place called Arc, as the typical Anglicization of her father's surname, d'Arc (sometimes rendered as Darc or Tarc), might imply. Instead, Jehanne—or Jehanette, as she was known—grew up in Domrémy, a village in northeastern France, the daughter of a farmer and his devoutly Catholic wife. During her trial before an ecclesiastical court in 1431, Joan referred to herself only as "Jehanne la Pucelle" ("Joan the Maid") and initially testified that she didn't know her last name. She later explained that her father was called Jacques d'Arc and her mother Isabelle Romée, adding that in her hometown daughters often took their mothers' surnames. 3. Her real first name wasn't Anne and was just Joan.

4. Joan wore her hair pulled back and her face painted, not dyed like many women today, in an effort to avoid suspicion.

5. Joan's first husband was a French military commander named Louis le Blay, not an English nobleman.

Joan of Arc is not just a name, she was a political reformer who believed in the church's role in helping reform the world.

prefix_text:
Everybody's Golf Review – Golf for Everyone (PS4)

If you haven't been following the series, it might be easy to be confused about what Everybody's Golf is. If I said
reference_text:
Hot Shots Golf, would that ring a bell? Similar to the Resident Evil series having another name in Japan (Biohazard), Hot Shots Golf has always held the title of Everybody's Golf on the other side of the Pacific. Everybody's Golf PS4 marks the first US release of the game to drop the Hot Shots title and have parity with the original Japanese name. The name may be new, but it's a PlayStation series that has persisted for 20 years.

The series' first foray onto the current generation of consoles is a beautiful treat to behold. There's contrast in the grass and the bright sky bring every course to life. The staple cartoony graphics are still here with the avatars, but the courses themselves bridge a valley between realism and a fictional world. Though I would have liked to see the avatars take on less of a "Mii-esque" appearance, I was impressed by the sheer amount of customization available for the characters. Honestly, that cartoon vibe is part

generated_result.0:
there was a title that's similar in its combat system to other Golf games, you might guess that it was Golf For Everyone, but actually it's a little different.

What makes Golf for Everyone different? Well, I mentioned it's a hybrid in that it has Golf For Everyone, Golf, Golf, and Golf – all packed into one package. And just like the Golf games, the core game is very forgiving, but you'll have to be really confident in your shots to get the best out of it. And don't be surprised if you're the kind of player that's capable of playing at a Golf course with friends.

I'm looking forward to what's to come for my old golf pals after that.
generated_result.1:
you had to put in the effort to understand what every piece of the experience meant, I'm telling you it's a lot of work – especially considering that you're only going to get to play the first half of this game's package.

On the one hand, we're getting a great-looking adventure. On the other hand, it's easy to get overwhelmed in a golf course where you have to make tough decisions about where to putt, how to hold up a club and even when to lift up a club for a backswing – making it easy to lose track of time in each round.

But even without a visual or a gameplay change, it's still hard to not want to play this game. That's because there is so much to explore and do that the game won't let you play it over and over again.

prefix_text: A 10-year-old girl with cerebral palsy has been detained by federal immigration authorities in Texas after she passed through a Border Patrol checkpoint on her way to a hospital to undergo emergency gall bladder surgery

The girl, Rosamaria Hernandez, who was brought over the border illegally to live in Laredo, Tex., when she was three months old, was being transferred from a medical center in Laredo to a hospital in Corpus Christi around 2 a.m. on Tuesday when Border Patrol agents stopped the ambulance she was riding in, her family said. The agents allowed her to continue to Driscoll Children's Hospital, the family said, but followed the ambulance the rest of the way there, then waited outside her room until she was released from the hospital.

By Wednesday evening, according to family members and advocates involved in her case, immigration agents had taken her to a facility in San Antonio where migrant children who arrive alone in the United States from Central America are usually held, even though her parents, who both lack legal status, live 150 miles away in Laredo.

Soviet troops take Berlin May 2nd 1945

Hitler was dead and now everyone knew it. The end was immediate, apart from a handful of fanatical holdouts, resistance in the city had crumbled. The 28th Army of the 1st Ukrainian Front and the 2nd Army of the 1st Belorussian Front came together on the Charlottenburg Chaussee, the main civic artery from central Berlin to the west at the Charlottenburg Palace.

Berlin 1945.

On May 2nd, 1945, Allied forces drove Soviet troops out of Berlin, thereby ending the Second World War in Europe.

For a complete collection of all historical images, visit our Germany page.

History

On May 2nd, 1945, the Berlin Wall, an Iron Curtain, first came down in the east and was subsequently shattered in the west. The German armed forces retreated to the Eastern Front, where they were beaten into retreat after the initial shock of the liberation had worn off.

The next day, Germany declared war on the United States of America. At the start of the war in 1939, Germany had declared war on the United States of America due to its intervention in WWI in the aftermath of World War I. When the American occupation forces moved north into German-occupied western Poland on March 22nd, 1944, Germany declared war on the United States.

On the 2nd of May, during an attack on Berlin, the Red Army and its allies managed to seize over 100 square miles of the German capital. The occupation of Berlin, which started the day before, ended a week later, when Soviet troops and their allies drove the invading Germans to the outskirts of the city.


On June 1st, the last Soviet troops were withdrawn from Berlin, after a two-week siege in which German forces had managed to make it across the Ruban river into the Russian capital, Stalingrad. The city was effectively completely abandoned, and the Soviet leaders immediately issued orders for its liberation.


The fighting was fierce and the outcome was far from obvious. In a single night, the Red Army captured the western half of Berlin, as well as the eastern and southern parts, with the German Army, which was not prepared to fight, holding on to the western half of the city.

The Soviets used the Reichswehr's armored and mechanized divisions, as well as the German armed forces with their air forces, and some tanks.

At 6:00 a.m. on May 2nd, 1945, Soviet troops landed on the outskirts of the city of Berlin and took control of the area until a halt was ordered. The Soviets then pushed the Germans out of the city, and occupied the city center and the surrounding countryside in the most brutal way possible.

Recently, the FAA Air Traffic Organization (ATO) has advised of an increase in, "Wrong Surface Landing Incidents" in the National Airspace System
reference_text:
(NAS).

Incidents include:

Landing on a runway other than the one specified in the ATC clearance (frequently after the pilot provides a correct read back)

Landing on a Taxiway

Lining up with the wrong runway or with a taxiway during approach

Landing at the wrong airport

Investigations of these incidents reveal some common factors that pilots should be aware of so we can try and reduce future occurrences:

Airports with parallel runways are prone to wrong surface landings

Parallel runways with different dimensions and/or surface color may confuse pilots

Offset parallel runways may be problematic due to the potential of the longer or wider runway being more prominent

Airports with similar configurations and in close proximity are prone to wrong airport landings

In this posting, I will summarize the relevant guidelines regarding what constitutes a "Wrong Surface Landing Incident" and describe some of the ways in which these types of accidents can be prevented.

What's a Wrong Surface Landing Incident?

A wrong surface landing incident, also known as a "Wrong Surface Landing Incident" or a "U-turn," is an incident where the pilot loses control or becomes airborne too early, causing the aircraft to travel in the wrong direction, or turn into the wrong direction, causing the aircraft to go off course. (Note: In a wrong surface landing accident, the pilot is considered the responsible party if he or she does not intervene as soon as he or she realizes the problem and, if possible, takes control in time.)

Heinrich Mallison, a scientist at the Museum of Natural History in Berlin, has designed computer models of Kentrosaurus, a cousin of Stegosaurus, to see if males could have risked mounting the females. A thick crust of bird droppings is piled on the gilded balustrade of one of Britain's most expensive properties. Pigeon skeletons lie among shattered mirrors and water streams
reference_text:
through broken cornicing. This is The Tower, a £30m palace in "Billionaires Row" in north London whose spectacular ruin has been kept secret until now.

It is one of 10 mansions in the middle of The Bishops Avenue - the heart of London's spiralling property market - that have stood almost entirely vacant since they were bought a quarter of a century ago, it is believed on behalf of members of the Saudi Arabian royal family. Their Grecian columns are cracking into pieces and mosaic-tiled swimming pools are filled with rubble. Nature has taken over to the extent that owls have moved in.

It is a desolate scene repeated up and down the supposedly prestigious avenue that Lloyds Bank has calculated is the second most expensive street in Britain. The Air Force is losing training time, experienced teachers, and its combat edge.

During his confirmation hearing, U.S. Air Force Chief of Staff General David Goldfein said his service
reference_text:
could not surge enough combat-ready forces to conduct a single major regional contingency operation without stripping other regions of the airmen and aircraft needed to meet their basic security needs. He further noted that less than half of Air Force combat units are ready for "full-spectrum" (high threat, high intensity) combat. This lack of readiness could jeopardize the lives of aircrews and other service members who depend upon them in combat, and put mission-essential tasks at greater risk.

How did it come to this? Fighter force readiness has been declining since 2003, but it took a big dive in fiscal 2013, when funding cuts forced the Air Force to temporarily ground half of its active-duty, combat-coded squadrons and reduce overall flying hours by 18 percent.

It got worse. In 2014, additional cuts led to shortages of spare parts and aircraft maintenance workers. Fighter pilots, who once averaged over 200 flying hours a year, struggled to get 120 hours that year.

reference_text:
It's pretty important to be sure that the code being moved to a new instance is identical. We don't want to have a user re-create the blueprints or workflows because it's prone to user error. Luckily for us, we have a solution. VMware has the vRealize Code Stream Management Pack for IT DevOps which I though about nicknaming vRCSMPITDO but that didn't really roll off the tongue. VMware previously nicknamed this product "Houdini" so for the purposes of this post, we'll use that too! This article will kick off a few more posts on using the product but for now we'll focus on installing it.

A recent change to our integration testing workflow is that we now have a set of automated test-instructions (TIF) that are triggered on an entry-point function of a single vSphere product: vCenter Operations Manager 5.0 for vSphere and vRealize Automation and vCenter Operations Manager 5.0 for Hyper-V and Storage. There is a process of building (or moving) components to one environment/project, then moving them back into another. This typically happens as part of the test integration. The component that is going to be moved can be added or removed from a solution configuration. A solution configuration for a specific application is stored on a service provider, or a vApp is built from this configuration. The application is created and deployed to a specific deployment location. That deployment location is configured by a deployment script, which does all the actual build and deploys.

generated_result.2:

vRealize Automation supports many types of build settings. The build settings used here are the same as you'd use in the command line, where each build configuration applies an initial build step.

You could just put in a command line build configuration like this:

vRAxComponents.configure = true

However, we'd get error messages as if we'd manually created the build configurations from scratch and not used the vRAxComponents.configure. This means that you can't use vRAxComponents.configure to manually configure your vRealize Automation environment. Students in UW-Madison's dorms will see a new charge on their housing bill next year. The university will require residents to deposit a minimum of $1,400 on their WisCard, to be used exclusively in dining halls.

According to Dining and Culinary officials, residents will pick a set amount of money — between $1,400 and $3,100 — to deposit on their card. The money can only be used in dining halls or unions and will be forfeited if not used up by the end of the academic year.

The change to a "tiered" resident meal plan is an attempt to be "upfront" and "transparent" with parents concerned their student was spending more than anticipated in dining halls, according to Director of Dining and Culinary Services Peter Testory.

The rules include meal restrictions that must be observed for every type of meal sold — including pizza and pasta — as well as whether the restaurant should have a waitstaff or an on-call employee.

The final rules include restrictions on food service in bars, restaurants and grocery stores.

The restrictions take effect immediately.

The UW System's $1.1 billion budget for 2013-14 is less than half of what is requested by a budget proposal in 2011. That proposal was more than $100 million less than the $1.3 billion passed by the Legislature in 2012-13.

The Clinton campaign also indicated that the presumptive Democratic nominee will, if elected, push for reduced regulatory barriers for startups and entrepreneurs.

"Hillary will challenge state and local governments to identify, review and reform legal and regulatory obligations that protect legacy incumbents against new innovators," the campaign said.

prefix_text: Electroplating copper to aluminum is a simple process if you follow a few simple guidelines regarding chemical reactions. Depending on the strength of the battery used in the process and the density of each metal,
reference_text:
electroplating may be completed within a few hours up to three days after immersion. Both metals are inexpensive to obtain and give off a lustrous coat, which gives the finished product a brilliant shine.

Combine three parts baking soda with one part vinegar and clean both the copper and aluminum surfaces by rubbing the cleaning paste over each metal with a cloth diaper. Wear gloves when handling the metal to avoid transferring skin oils, which interfere with the electroplating process.

Rest two dowel rods on opposite rim edges of a large glass bowl and place an alligator clip on each dowel..

Strip 1 inch of insulation back from each end of both circuit wires. Clip one end of the red wire in one alligator clip with the exposed end resting approximately halfway down the bowl wall. Repeat the process using the black wire in the other clip.

Clip the copper plating metal against the exposed end of the red wire and the aluminum metal to the black wire.

prefix_text: Last May, the U.S. Supreme Court issued what was perhaps the most significant death penalty ruling in a decade when it rejected Florida's standard for putting to death defendants who may be intellectually disabled.
reference_text:
The U.S. Supreme Court has said that capital punishment for the intellectually disabled is unconstitutional. But Florida was one of several states that was arguably doing it anyway, by making the standard for proving disability so onerous that almost no one could meet it.

While the Supreme Court only struck down Florida's law, the ruling paved the way to challenge other state provisions that make it near-impossible to prove that a state is about to illegally put an intellectually disabled man to death, such as those in Georgia and Texas. But this week, a county judge rejected a legal challenge in Georgia, finding that death row inmate Warren Hill has "not cited any new law or evidence sufficient to overcome the procedural bar."

Seven different mental health experts who have evaluated Hill all now agree that he has an intellectual disability (previously referred to by the courts as "mentally retarded."). Hill also has an IQ score of 70. But all of that wasn't enough to meet Georgia's near-

generated_result.0:
The court ruled 7-0 that Florida failed to make its law just and reasonable, given what evidence had emerged over the years. The court also said a key part of the state's law was unconstitutional.

That decision, in an 8-0 decision, gave the U.S. Supreme Court the opportunity to overturn the state's execution methods for intellectually disabled prisoners. The state had sought to use a mentally retarded state resident named Brandon Jackson, who committed the murder of a 12-year-old neighbor in 1999, as an example of just how hard a case it was.

Jackson's attorneys said the mentally retarded are less prone to violence and may have a higher chance of rehabilitation than the average patient, and argued that the state's method was cruel and unusual punishment.

But the state countered that the procedure it used to execute the intellectually disabled violated the U.S. Constitution by using a condemned inmate "to test and prove the wisdom" of a law that was adopted with
generated_result.1:
The Florida Supreme Court had set out a test of "mentally retarded" defendants who "pose a substantial risk of imminence" of harming others and have exhibited "no intellectual development."

The standard of "imminence" would not be met if the defendant had been "impaired with respect to speech, seeing, hearing, or understanding" his conduct in advance, but the court had not defined "imminence." The decision also rejected the state's attempt to reduce the potential sentence.

"No rational jury could have found [the defendant] not guilty because 'imminence' is not a crime-specific standard, but rather a broad, generic one," wrote Justice Sonia Sotomayor for the majority.

The ruling was unusual in its breadth. In cases on the state's books with an average sentence of 24 years, no one has been executed with the Florida standard. It was rare to read about anyone being executed with the new
generated_result.2:
In 2010, the high court struck down all of the four death penalty convictions of a mentally disabled defendant, saying that intellectually disabled defendants are not entitled to the death penalty because they are not entitled to legal counsel at trial or the ability to effectively communicate their plight to a jury at sentencing. It said the standard violates the Eighth Amendment and does not provide any additional protection for these defendants than would the death penalty itself.

prefix_text:
Cinnamon Can Help Lower Blood Sugar, But One Variety May Be Best

toggle caption iStockphoto

If I say cinnamon, you say... sugar? It's a popular combination, of
reference_text:
course.

But if you're interested in the health-promoting effects of cinnamon, you may want to think anew about the spice.

For instance, says John Critchley, executive chef at Bourbon Steak Restaurant in Washington, D.C., why not add it to savory dishes? He uses cinnamon to create a spice and herb rub for lamb loin. He also whips up a great spinach salad with raisins, pine nuts and cinnamon.

Critchley is a fan of the intense aromatics in cinnamon, especially in Saigon — a cousin of the cassia varieties of cinnamon most commonly used in the U.S. and Europe. And he says adding cinnamon to spice blends is a great way to layer flavors when you're cooking.

And when you start to look at the potential health-promoting effects of the spice, there's even more incentive to experiment with it in the kitchen.

Cinnamon comes from the bark

generated_result.0:
course.

The real secret? The type of cinnamon.

People who have been eating cinnamon (a spice that's not even considered a spice) tend to be leaner and lower their risk for type 2 diabetes, and they tend to be more patient with their blood sugar, researchers at the University of Wisconsin-Madison report in the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism.

But it turns out that the type of cinnamon the dieters are eating may actually be just as important as what they are eating.

A study published last year in the Journal of Cerebral Blood Flow & Metabolism showed that individuals eating a higher ratio of sweet to bitter in their cinnamon didn't find it to be as addictive as those eating a sweeter variety. People eating a cinnamon-sweet mixture in the study were more likely to show improved results when they tried to exercise, compared with those eating a different blend of spices.

The takeaway: If you like a cinnam
generated_result.1:
course.

But the benefits of this spice don't necessarily extend all the way up the food chain — and that's the way the science is right now.

"It's just a little thing. It's sort of like a sugar molecule, but it's also a bit of something else, which is called neuropeptide Y," explains lead author Dr. Amy O'Neil. "That's a chemical that people are very much looking for as a treatment for Alzheimer's disease."

So instead of just chewing the sugar out of food, some researchers are focusing on the chemical's other effect.

Cinnamon has neuropeptide Y and research at Washington University in St. Louis has found it may have similar properties to the drug metformin. Those drugs are used to prevent or prevent the development of Alzheimer's, but researchers wanted to know if they had the same effect on the brain, O'Neil explains.

The researchers found that the neur
generated_result.2:
course, as you can't make bread or pasta without the sweet stuff.

This sweet stuff is used all over the place, and it's no surprise. Cinnamony has many health benefits. But cinnamon has another, more complicated role: It helps lower blood sugar.

Cinnamon has an essential oil. It goes to work when our bodies need it. But we don't need it to stay healthy. And some people, like diabetes patients, may experience symptoms from too much cinnamon. A good source of cinnamon is not going to be cheap. It must be organic or non-GMO. The healthiest cinnamon is from a cinnamon tree.

There are two types of cinnamon. One is the refined cinnamon variety, and the other is the more refined cinnamon, which is not processed.

The best cinnamon is fresh, meaning it's picked straight from the tree and unrefined.

The Churn language needed to be a workable language, because I wanted to use it in the Churnwalker's written story, but also to be accessible in some way to our players. When the Churn is turned inward, it causes the spirits inside the area to suffer. They become chaotic, and there is a sense of fear when they enter into the Churn.

The Vainglory team has been looking into the potential of having multiple portals open in the world of Vainglory. What do you think? Are there any plans for it?

WayForward Technologies have wrapped up work on Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, which is coming to Nintendo 3DS (and Wii U), and plan to release the game sometime this Fall. In a recent interview with Siliconera, series director Matt Bozon explained how they went about designing the game, which is heavily inspired by Metroid's non-linear gameplay—a first for Shantae.

Pirate's Curse isn't the first time that WayForward have experimented with Shantae in different ways either, although most of those other experiments haven't worked out. Back in the Game Boy Advance days, WayForward prototyped a game called Shantae 2: Risky Revolution, which was to be a sequel to the original Game Boy Color Shantae. Israel's defense minister said Tuesday that the country had interpreted Iran's conversion of some enriched uranium to fuel rods for civilian use as evidence that Iran had delayed ambitions to build a nuclear weapon.

The
reference_text:
assertion, by Defense Minister Ehud Barak in an interview with The Daily Telegraph, a British newspaper, amounted to the first explanation from him as to why he and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu softened their position in September over the possibility of a military strike to thwart what they called Iran's drive toward imminent nuclear weapons capability.

Their tough position on Iran, which they consider Israel's most dangerous enemy, had generated tensions with the Obama administration, which has contended that Iran is many months away from the ability to make a nuclear weapon.

Mr. Barak, who was visiting London, was quoted by the newspaper as saying an immediate crisis had been averted this summer because Iran had chosen to use a third of its enriched uranium for use as fuel rods in a medical research reactor. The conversion of that uranium, which was reported by the International Atomic Energy Agency in August, makes it much more difficult to use militarily.

Advertisement Continue reading the main story

The Iranian decision, Mr

generated_result.0:
comments, by Israeli Defense Minister Ehud Barak, come amid tensions in the region following a U.S. missile strike against a Syrian air base earlier this month and fears of a more bellicose response.

"After a very thorough analysis and a careful review of the situation, Israel believes, based on the latest information that emerged from Iran, that the conversion of Iranian nuclear material to nuclear fuel is a clear indicator of Iran's willingness to delay that capability," Barak said.

Barak said Israel had conducted two nuclear inspections of Iran since it joined the nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty in 1968. He added that the Islamic Republic had yet to produce sufficient fissile material to build a nuclear bomb.

Deborah O'Reilly, Elizabeth Fleming, Cian White, Sasha the dog and Joseph McMurray all enjoying their day in Muff in 2013.

One of the oldest fairs in
reference_text:
the country, if not the oldest, will kick off tomorrow, Wednesday, August 12, just outside Kingscourt.

The annual horse Fair of Muff is said to be the oldest traditional fair in the country, possibly going as far back as the 12th Century.

Music comes from K and Nashville Sound at the festival and later Michael D (not that one!) will perform at Hughies's, who also provide bar facilities at the fair itself.

The one-day hoolie at the crossroads will see stalls from all over the country to offer their wares and crafts on the approach roads to the historic day.

Muff Fair was always about selling horses and ponies and patrons still come from as far away as Connemara to barter and sell on the cross.

The day is also one for family but with a carnival feel for people from all over who come not just to see about horses but also the many other creatures for sale,

generated_result.0:
Scotland's biggest city, Muff is the ideal location for an event like this, attracting hundreds of visitors from all over the world for its eclectic nature.

And the best part? It's free to attend and everyone can help out to make it the best fair it can be.

As they have with so many other things around Edinburgh, Muff has a 'dance to' bar, where they host events for all to join in.

With three generations of family still involved in the festival, its roots stretch back to its original founders, Hugh Mackenzie and his son John Macleod, who were running a bar that celebrated their Scottish roots in 1842.

Their bar, Muff Hall, was moved to Muff in 1869 where a further six generations later, the festival's first festival was held, in 1891.

Today the festival continues to be held on the Sunday closest to Holyrood.

reference_text:
end. On indefinite hiatus since late 2012, the pair released a statement Tuesday, in which Williams says, "I am saddened and disappointed by the ending of this duo, to say the very least. JP is a tremendous musician, and I will always be grateful for the music we were able to create together."

"I would like to express sincere thanks to all who were a part of the arc of the Civil Wars — from the beginning, to the end, and all points in between," adds White. "My deep appreciation goes out to all who supported, disseminated, and enjoyed the music. Whatever shape or form the next chapter takes, thanks for being a large part of this one."

The reason for the duo's breakup is one of the best-kept secrets in contemporary music history. It was exactly a year ago today that Williams told Rolling Stone the two were not on speaking terms, but wouldn't pinpoint the cause of the split. Still, she was hopeful for a

generated_result.0:

It's been a pleasure to play their music, and it has been a pleasure to see them grow and improve on their music. "We have always been very loyal to this label. We really did want to work with them on this album. It was always in the back of our mind. "We will be closing the doors of Capitol and have decided it's best for us to move forward as The Civil Wars."

Alaska brothers James and Giono Barrett have a dream: that some of the scores of cruise ship passengers who crowd the streets of the state capital each summer will one day use their
reference_text:
shore excursions to kick back and light up a joint in a pot store's lounge.

Continue Reading Below

The Barretts own Juneau's first marijuana retail store and want to tap into the $260 million or so that tourists dropped in the small coastal city last year.

Regulators could decide soon whether to make that happen. At a meeting Thursday in Juneau, they will consider allowing marijuana retail stores statewide to provide separate areas of their businesses for onsite consumption.

It's the first time the matter has been addressed at the state level in the U.S., said Chris Lindsey, a senior legislative counsel with the Marijuana Policy Project. Recreational marijuana is legal in eight states and the District of Columbia. Denver is considering licenses for marijuana social clubs.

Even if the Alaska board approves onsite consumption, don't expect to walk into a store on Friday for a sit-and-smoke. Retail stores must file applications for such a lounge,

generated_result.0:
boats to cruise over the state's waters as part of a movement against the Pebble Mine in Northern Pebble Island, the site of the largest open-pit coal mine in the world.

They have the support of thousands of the state's miners and fishermen, and some of their ideas may sound outlandish to people outside their ranks. They want to get people out to the water on their own or at least organize groups with other like-minded people to use the vessels they built to haul cargo to shore.

But their idea is being taken seriously, and in some ways a bit beyond what they predicted a year ago. In 2014, Alaska was called the "world's most popular vacation destination" in a survey by the annual Travel and Leisure magazine, and this year, the Daily Beast has called the state "the most attractive destination in the West."

But the Barrett brothers aren't here to pitch their idea to people. A few of them have decided to make it happen.

bikes to commute.

"The world is getting more urban," Mr. Barrett said.

But unlike Alaska's two older brother states in the north — Canada and Europe — and in the midsection of America, where bikes are not uncommon — Alaska is one of only a few places in the world where most residents can't walk to a store to buy food. And there are only a handful of communities where that is not the case.

"It's very difficult to cycle through Alaska without some sort of car," said Dr. John Skelton, director of the Alaska Bicycle Coalition. "It is very difficult to bike here."

There's one big reason: the vast majority of those who can bike to a store are older adults. Of those who are not, many are elderly women who were previously forced to use the car to get to work. "That's been our reality," Dr. Skelton said.

"We have to have a strong
generated_result.2:

But to put their plan to work, they had to break some of Alaska's rules.

"Our idea was a great idea and we have to put it in the pot," James said, pointing to a table in the dining room of the Sea of Cortez.

They had to go through a bureaucratic maze that ended Monday with a decision that meant Alaska will not be able to offer them any federal money to run their project. The brothers say they will take their idea to the federal government's Bureau of Economic Analysis, a process they say is "complicated and lengthy."

prefix_text: On-site verifications last year at GVK Biosciences showed irregularities "in each and every one of the nine trials inspected," the European Medicines Agency said in a May report (AFP
reference_text:
Photo/Miguel Medina)

European Union nations have until August 20 to suspend the sale of some 700 generic drugs made in India, the EU's executive confirmed on Monday.

The European Commission took the action after an Indian firm contracted by drug companies to test the medications was found to have manipulated data.

On-site verifications last year at GVK Biosciences showed irregularities "in each and every one of the nine trials inspected," the European Medicines Agency said in a May report recommending the suspension.

The broad scope of the problems, which stretched back years, "highlights critical deficiencies in the quality system in place at GVK Bio's clinic in Hyderabad," the EMA said.

The company tests for "bio-equivalence," to see if the generic versions of drugs are identical in impact to the original.

Prior to the economic crisis, Olafur Hauksson was police commissioner in Akranes, a small port town of 6,500 inhabitants stranded at the end of a frozen peninsula some fifty kilometres from Reykjavik. Since 2009, he tracks down and brings to justice those who played a role in the country's economic collapse of 2008.

At the end of 2008, the Icelandic bubble burst as a consequence of the subprime crisis in the United States. Two weeks after the dramatic fall of Lehman Brothers, the country's three major banks – valued at 923% of gross domestic product (GDP) – collapsed. The crisis swept through the island, the Icelandic krona dropped in value and no intervention could halt its downward spiral. On October 6, 2008, live on national television, the then-prime minister ended his speech by asking God to "save the island".

We've been watching the British banks go bust over the past two years and we can't see it ending soon. Our governments have let them slide: the Treasury just set a rate that is one of the lowest in the world. Yet at a time when our own banks are in trouble, those at the top appear immune to the damage they've caused.

What can be done? The banks could do better to hold their managers to account. They could act more responsibly. But the banks should be accountable to shareholders and customers in an open way. They should publish information about their profitability. That's a very different approach to the status quo and the regulators just won't do it.

prefix_text: Anders (Sweden) had hiked to the top of Mt. Pu with some friends on the morning of December 26, 2004 and was there to witness the waves coming ashore. He had his
reference_text: digital camera with him and took these awesome (and sobering) pictures of the tsunami hitting North Beach in Koh Pu. The first picture is Anders and his family celebrating Christmas on the porch of their hut at Andaman Beach Resort. The group shot half-way down the page is a before-tsunami dinner at Koh Jum Seafood with friends. Him and his wife Helen were staying at Andaman Beach Resort when the tsunami hit and the pictures on the second half of the page are of the damage to the bungalows. They were in the yellow/purple one and lost everything, including his laptop with a couple thousand digital pictures they had taken of their trip to Thailand. That hurts. Below that is a great shot of all the coral that got rinsed up onto shore by the waves. The beach has since been cleaned up, but you can see the mess the waves left behind. Cheers, Anders. Today's post was written by Seth Patton, senior director of product management for the SharePoint team.

In February, we shared our vision on the evolution of SharePoint, outlining our plans for
reference_text:
continued cloud innovation with SharePoint in Office 365, and providing a glimpse of the work underway to deliver our next on-premises server release, SharePoint Server 2016. With Ignite just a few weeks away, we're getting ready to share more details on the innovation we're bringing to SharePoint 2016. In the meantime, I wanted to provide an update on release timing and share some of the key enhancements and new capabilities we're focused on.

Today, we are confirming that SharePoint Server 2016 will become generally available in Q2 2016, with a public beta planned for Q4 2015. We also want to confirm our commitment to delivering on-premises releases of SharePoint for the foreseeable future. We envision a future where we will continue to have customers who choose a combination of on-premises, cloud and hybrid deployments for many years to come. We're excited to start sharing information on our SharePoint investments at Microsoft Ignite, so below I've highlighted some of the most

generated_result.0:
the future of SharePoint and the evolution of the Web Office platform. This is our "big break," an open invitation to the world of SharePoint. Our vision for SharePoint has changed a lot since then. At SharePoint Today, we're starting to see an openness to the concept of the Web Office platform emerge as a dominant option for delivering enterprise-grade documents and solutions. If you've been looking for an open invitation for all of the details, it's time to dive in.

SharePoint Web Office 2015 introduces new ways for users to publish documents to SharePoint, in addition to an enhanced publishing experience for SharePoint 2013 to create and share a single document. At the moment, we know there are a few reasons why people are eager to embrace the Web Office platform in enterprise solutions today:

There is a strong community that builds features that make publishing to SharePoint even more user-friendly. A blog post about an upcoming feature at SharePoint Today talks about som

prefix_text: The M60E3 7.62mm machine gun is a lightweight, air-cooled, disintegrating metallic link-belt fed, portable or tripod mounted machine gun designed for ground operations like its
reference_text:
predecessor, the M60. It is gas operated with fixed headspace and timing which permits rapid changing of barrels. (Associated components: mount, tripod, machine gun, 7.62mm, M122). Slightly different from its "parent," the M60, the M60E3 has a receiver-attached bipod which easily deploys for stability. It has an ambidextrous safety, universal sling attachments, a carrying handle on the barrel, and a simplified gas system that does not require safety wire to prevent loosening. However, the light weight barrel is not safe for overhead fire and is not capable of sustaining a rapid rate of fire of 200 rounds per minute without catastrophic failure of the barrel.

Originally based on the British Type 59 or 61 machine gun, the M60E3 is a compact weapon with a rotating magazine and fixed sights. An additional weapon-mounted rail allows the use of the M60E3 for a range of other platforms. The 5.56x45mm NATO cartridge is a standard round for the M60E3 and is compatible with all current NATO and Russian 7.62x51mm weapons.

The ammunition for the M60E3 is produced at BAE Systems' factory in Chorley, United Kingdom and its US subsidiary in Northridge, California

The M60E3 was intended as the most effective, rugged, light combat machine gun on the planet and it achieved this by cutting corners and being very robust, but being very cheap. The weapon has been used in a wide variety of conflicts around the world including Iraq, Korea, Indochina, and Vietnam. This game controller allows you to control your tracks, or your vehicles in a variety of ways, either using the gamepad or using your thumb. One of the things I enjoy the most about this controller is the ability to do just that – control all of the game.

prefix_text: Sen. Mike Crapo (R-ID) pulled his endorsement of Donald Trump in early October over the 2005 tape revealing the GOP nominee's vulgar comments about women, but just two weeks later the

Republican senator now says he will vote for Trump after all.

"The choice we still have today and the choice we will have is between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton," Crapo told conservative radio host Neal Larson on Friday, according to the Idaho State Journal. "In that context, I have to tell you, though I thought and felt we needed a different choice, that's not what we're going to get, and we cannot elect Hillary Clinton for many reasons. … Given that choice, I will vote for the Republican ticket: Trump and (vice presidential nominee Mike) Pence."

Crapo said that he wants a president "who will appoint strong Supreme Court justices, who will interpret the Constitution as it was written and who will help lead us to a stronger free market and a more limited government."
